questions.text: A 16-year-old girl comes to the pediatrician in autumn for a well-child visit accompanied by her parent. There are no changes to her health since the last visit, but they disclose that she wants to become sexually active and would like to discuss contraception options. She eats a variety of foods and rarely consumes sugary drinks. Her periods are regular, and her last menstrual period was one week ago. Recommended vaccinations prior to this visit are up-to-date, and her last hearing test was at age 12. She had a normal complete blood count and lipid panel at age 11. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, blood pressure is 110/68 mmHg, weight is 128 pounds, height is 64 inches, and BMI is 22 kg/m2. On physical examination, she is pleasant and engaging in communication. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are unremarkable. In addition to performing a chaperoned genital examination and discussing safe sexual practices and contraceptive options, which of the following is most appropriate to include at this visit?

choices.text: Papanicolaou test     Discuss academic performance     Lipid panel     Seasonal influenza vaccine
Sexually transmitted infection screening     Hearing screening     Papanicolaou test     Discussion about online bullying

questions.solution:
The well-check visit for this 16-year-old adolescent should include a meningococcal vaccine and discussion of self-care, including oral hygiene. An HIV test can be offered at this time as well. This patient is due for a hearing test, as her last one was before the age of 15. Influenza and COVID-19 vaccinations should be offered based on the season. Therefore, this patient should be offered the Meningococcal vaccine and a hearing and HIV screening; oral hygiene should be discussed as well.       

The well-child visit for an adolescent is an opportunity for healthcare providers to engage with patients and their caregivers about a number of components of health promotion, including routine screenings, immunizations, and conversations about health and behavioral topics. All adolescents should have a discussion about self-care at their well-check, including topics such as healthy eating, physical activity, sleep, and oral hygiene. Biologically female patients should be asked about their menstrual patterns and any symptoms related to menses. Timing of immunizations is age-specific but will include a Tdap, HPV vaccine series, and meningococcal vaccines during the adolescent years, in addition to seasonal influenza and COVID-19 vaccinations.        

Recommended screening tests for an adolescent include a lipid panel at ages 9-11 and 17-21, a hearing test (once between ages 11-14, 15-17, and 18-21), and a vision test at ages 12 and 15. A hemoglobin level can be used to screen for anemia if the patient has risk factors, such as a diet that’s low in iron or menorrhagia. It is also recommended to screen adolescents for hepatitis C once between ages 18-79 and for HIV once between ages 15-18. Sexually active adolescents should be offered screening for sexually transmitted infections.  

Option Analysis

✅  Meningococcal vaccine     Hearing screening     HIV screening     Discuss oral hygiene    :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌  Papanicolaou test     Discuss academic performance     Lipid panel     Seasonal influenza vaccine    :
Incorrect: Seasonal influenza vaccination and review of academic performance are appropriate at a 16-year-old well-check. A chaperoned genital examination should be done; however, a Papanicolaou test is not indicated until at least age 21. This patient is not due for her next lipid panel until age 17-21. 
❌  DTap vaccine     Meningococcal vaccine     Hepatitis C screening     Discuss sleep habits    :
Incorrect: The meningococcal vaccine and discussion of sleep habits would be appropriate at a 16-year-old well-check. However, the DTap vaccine is last given by the age of 6. Tdap vaccines are given at age 11 and either Td or Tdap is given every 10 years thereafter. Hepatitis C should be screened for once between ages 18 and 79. 
❌  Sexually transmitted infection screening     Hearing screening     Papanicolaou test     Discussion about online bullying    :
Incorrect: A hearing screen is indicated at this time as well as a discussion of online bullying. Screening for sexually transmitted infections is appropriate given this patient reports sexual activity. A chaperoned genital examination should be done; however, a Papanicolaou test is not indicated until at least age 21. 
❌  Discuss oral hygiene     Lead level      HPV vaccine     Discussion about healthy eating    :
Incorrect: Discussion of oral hygiene and healthy eating are indicated at this visit; however, a lead level is typically checked twice by the age of 2 years and then is not routinely checked after that. HPV vaccination could be offered at this age if not already given but it is usually offered starting at age 9 and it is noted that this child is up to date on vaccines.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy comes to the primary care office for a well-child visit accompanied by his parent. They report no changes to his health since his last visit. He is doing well in school and exercises five days per week. Vaccinations are up to date. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, blood pressure is 108/64 mmHg, weight is 125 pounds, height is 68 inches, and BMI is 19 kg/m2. He is pleasant and alert with good eye contact and is engaging in conversation. The physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is a component of an evidence-based approach to promoting health in this adolescent patient?

choices.text: Screen the patient for depression and suicidal ideation
Interview the patient only when parents are present
Assure complete confidentiality about everything the patient says
Avoid asking about access to weapons and avoid counseling about firearm safety because of the second amendment

questions.solution:
This 14-year-old adolescent presenting for a well-child visit should be asked about self-harm and depression. An effective way to open this conversation is to ask about the child’s mood for the previous two weeks to determine whether they’re experiencing any symptoms of depression or anxiety. The provider can also ask how the child expresses their feelings, including any coping strategies for dealing with strong emotions, and ask if they have trusted people to confide in. Adolescent patients should also be screened for depression and suicidal ideation. The Patient Health Questionnaire-A (PHQ-A) is a survey that can be administered to adolescents to screen, diagnose, and monitor depression.        

A core aspect of health promotion in the well-child visit for an adolescent is the HEADSSS assessment. HEADSSS is a mnemonic used to highlight the important aspects of the patient interview and stands for Home; Education and Employment; Activities; Drugs and substance use; Sexuality, Gender Identity, and Relationships; Self-harm and Depression; and Safety. It is ideal for this part of the patient interview to be conducted without the parent present to build autonomy, strengthen the physician-patient relationship, and allow the child to ask questions they might otherwise be reluctant to ask. The environment should be non-judgmental and supportive so that the adolescent can openly express concerns about sensitive issues. The table below includes the key topics to cover during the HEADSSS assessment.        

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741, or visit www.iasp.info/suicidalthoughts/ for international resources. You are not alone.  




Option Analysis

✅ Screen the patient for depression and suicidal ideation  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Interview the patient only when parents are present  :
Incorrect: Adolescents should be offered the opportunity to have a discussion with their healthcare provider without parents present as it builds autonomy, strengthens the physician-patient relationship, and allows the child to ask questions they might otherwise be reluctant to ask. 
❌  Avoid discussing body image :
Incorrect: The well-child check is an important time to discuss body image, using the adolescent’s perceptions about weight and appearance to help identify signs of disordered eating. 
❌ Assure complete confidentiality about everything the patient says:
Incorrect: Certain things a patient may disclose, especially regarding self-harm or thoughts of harming others, require reporting. A physician should not provide reassurance that everything said is fully confidential as this would erode trust if the physician then has to disclose information. 
❌ Avoid asking about access to weapons and avoid counseling about firearm safety because of the second amendment :
Incorrect: Asking about whether an adolescent has access to weapons, especially guns, is an important part of the safety assessment that can be done at every well-child visit, and it is not prohibited by the law or by the second amendment.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with sudden onset severe right testicular pain that started one hour ago. He reports associated nausea and vomiting that started after the pain began. He was at soccer practice earlier that day, which he states was particularly strenuous. He is currently sexually active with two partners and uses protection inconsistently. He denies dysuria and penile discharge. Temperature is 37ºC (98.6°F), heart rate is 106/min, blood pressure is 135/90 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 20/min. The patient appears to be in distress due to pain. Urinalysis is negative. Which of the following physical examination findings would be expected given the likely underlying condition?

choices.text: Pain relief with elevation of the right scrotum
Marked diffuse swelling and tenderness of the right scrotum

questions.solution:
This patient presents with sudden onset severe right testicular pain, nausea, and vomiting following strenuous physical activity, suggesting acute testicular torsion. A distinctive feature of testicular torsion is the finding of marked diffuse swelling and erythema of the scrotum.

Acute testicular torsion typically presents in adolescent males with sudden, severe, unilateral testicular pain often accompanied by nausea and vomiting. The pain often begins during sleep or following physical activity. Risk factors include increased vascularity, inflammation or trauma of the testicle, abnormal fixation of the testes, and rapid growth in the patient.

Clinically, the affected testicle may appear high-riding and assume a horizontal or transverse orientation due to twisting of the spermatic cord. On examination, there is typically marked diffuse tenderness and swelling of the scrotum. A key diagnostic feature is the absence of the cremasteric reflex on the affected side, where stroking the upper inner thigh fails to elicit the normal elevation of the testicle. In patients with diffuse scrotal pain and absent cremasteric reflex on the affected side, a presumptive diagnosis of testicular torsion can be made. 
     



Option Analysis

❌ Pain relief with elevation of the right scrotum:
Incorrect: Pain relief with elevation of the scrotum (also known as Prehn’s sign) is associated with epididymitis, not testicular torsion. This patient with acute testicular pain after vigorous exercise more likely has testicular torsion. 
✅ Marked diffuse swelling and tenderness of the right scrotum:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Positive right-sided cremasteric reflex:
Incorrect: Positive right-sided cremasteric reflex would be unlikely in the setting of acute testicular torsion of the affected side. The cremasteric reflex, which involves the elevation of the testicle when the inner thigh is stroked, is typically absent on the side of testicular torsion due to twisting of the spermatic cord.  
❌ Absent left-sided cremasteric reflex:
Incorrect: An absent left-sided cremasteric reflex would not be expected in a patient with right-sided testicular torsion. 
❌ Purulent urethral discharge:
Incorrect: In this patient with acute testicular pain associated with nausea and vomiting that occurred after strenuous exercise, testicular torsion is more likely than an STI with urethritis and/or epididymitis, which can present with purulent urethral discharge.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department for vomiting and progressive abdominal pain for two days. Her parents report she has been drinking more water lately and wetting the bed at night after previously having dry nights. Past medical and family history are unremarkable. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 38/min, blood pressure is 108/65 mm Hg and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. Mucous membranes are dry with poor skin turgor. The patient is tachypneic with deep, labored breathing and a fruity smell to the breath. Lungs are clear bilaterally. Cardiac and abdominal exams are unremarkable. Labs are shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 

 Laboratory value      Result     
 Blood glucose      530 mg/dL    
 Serum sodium     146 mEq/L     
 Serum potassium      3 mEq/L    
 Serum beta-hydroxybutyrate (BHB)     7    
 PH     7.02    
 PCo2     50 mmHg    
 Serum bicarbonate      10 mEq/L    
 Urine ketones      Positive
questions.solution:
This 3-year-old girl presents with polyuria, polydipsia, vomiting and abdominal pain. Physical examination reveals Kussmaul breathing (rapid fast deep breathing) and signs of dehydration. On laboratory studies, she has hyperglycemia, metabolic acidosis, and ketosis, which confirm diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). Initial management of DKA includes fluid resuscitation with intravenous fluids such as isotonic saline or Ringer’s lactate.   

Diabetic ketoacidosis can be the initial presentation in children with a new diagnosis of type I diabetes mellitus (DM). Risk factors for DKA in children with an established diagnosis of diabetes include missing insulin doses, previous episodes of DKA, inadequate dosing of insulin, and infections. Symptoms of persistent hyperglycemia include polyuria, polydipsia, polyphagia, and weight loss. Clinical signs may progress rapidly to DKA, and patients may have vomiting, abdominal pain, dehydration, weakness, and lethargy. Associated dehydration can cause tachycardia, delayed capillary refill time, poor skin turgor, and dry mucus membranes. Kussmaul respirations, as seen in this patient, refers to a deep, rapid pattern of breathing. In addition, ketoacidosis may result in a fruity odor to the breath.    

The most serious complication of DKA is severe neurologic injury and development of cerebral edema. Warning signs include headache, bradycardia, irritability, altered mental status, unresponsiveness, and coma. Laboratory values necessary for diagnosing DKA are hyperglycemia with a blood glucose level >200 mg/dL, venous pH < 7.3 or serum bicarbonate level < 15 mEq/L, ketonemia (blood b-hydroxybutyrate concentration ≥3 mmol/L), and ketonuria.   

In the setting of diabetic ketoacidosis, an ABCDE assessment should be performed. If the patient is unstable, the first step is to stabilize the airway, breathing, and circulation. In patients with signs of dehydration, as seen in this patient, intravenous fluid administration is the first step to correct dehydration, acidosis, and reverse ketosis. Fluid replacement should begin before starting intravenous insulin therapy. Electrolyte repletion and monitoring sodium and potassium levels, along with monitoring urine output and neurological status is essential. Once the patient is stabilized, continuous vital sign monitoring and oxygen as needed can be provided.    

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous isotonic saline :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intravenous sodium bicarbonate  :
Incorrect: Sodium bicarbonate administration is not recommended in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) and has not shown benefit in the resolution of DKA. Sodium bicarbonate administration should be reserved for the treatment of severe hyperkalemia or severe acidosis (pH < 6.9) causing impaired cardiac contractility, which is not seen in this patient.  
❌ Intubation  :
Incorrect: Intubation is required in unstable patients with diabetic ketoacidosis who are severely obtunded or unconscious and cannot protect their airways, which is not noted in this patient.  
❌ Oral antiemetics  :
Incorrect: While oral antiemetics may help provide symptomatic relief in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis and vomiting, this patient requires urgent treatment with intravenous fluids before other therapies.  
❌ Subcutaneous insulin  :
Incorrect: Subcutaneous insulin can be used in patients with mild to moderate diabetic ketoacidosis; however, this patient requires intravenous fluids before insulin administration and continuous intravenous insulin is the preferred method of insulin delivery in this case.

questions.text:
A 13–year-old girl presents to the pediatrician with her parents for evaluation of fatigue for the past three months and difficulty concentrating at school. The patient experienced menarche at age 11 and her periods have been irregular. They occur every 2-10 weeks and last up to 10 days. She eats a well-balanced diet. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 110/68 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears pale and tired. Cardiac exam demonstrates tachycardia with a soft 2/6 systolic murmur heard best at the left sternal border. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally without increased work of breathing. Nails appear brittle with central indentations. Laboratory work is ordered, and results are shown below. Which of the following would be expected given the most likely underlying diagnosis? 

 Laboratory value     Result    
 Hemoglobin     10.2 g/dL    
 Hematocrit     30%    
 Leukocyte count     8.5/mm3    
 Platelet count     213/mm3    
 Mean Corpuscular Volume (MCV)     68 fl    
 Serum Ferritin (SF)     5 ng/mL    
 Transferrin Saturation (TSAT)     163 mg/dL    
 Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC)     440 mcg/dL    
 Lead level     2.0 µg/dL (<3.5 µg/dL)

choices.text: Residence in a house built in the 1980s
Consumption of 1 cup of milk per day

questions.solution:
This patient presents with fatigue, trouble concentrating, and heavy menstrual bleeding. Physical examination shows pallor and tachycardia and lab results (low hemoglobin, mean corpuscular volume, transferrin, and ferritin; and high total iron binding capacity) confirm the diagnosis of iron deficiency anemia. Iron deficiency anemia can be associated with pica, which refers to the intense craving for non-nutritive (nonfood) substances like dirt and ice. Pagophagia is pica for ice where patients have an intense desire to consume or chew on ice. 

Risk factors for iron deficiency anemia include heavy or prolonged menstrual bleeding, lead poisoning, chronic conditions (e.g., inflammatory bowel disease or chronic kidney disease), participation in high-intensity or endurance sports (iron loss through sweat, urine skin GI tract), a diet that is low in iron or high in milk consumption, and certain medications. Patients with anemia often complain of vague symptoms such as fatigue, lightheadedness, poor endurance, lack of concentration, and palpitations. Behavior changes can include irritability and pica.

On physical examination, patients may have tachycardia or tachypnea depending on the degree of anemia. Patients often have pallor which can be noticed in the conjunctiva and nail beds. Nails can appear brittle, with koilonychia (nails appear concave or spoon-shaped). Patients can develop glossitis (i.e., smooth, glossy tongue with loss of papillae), or angular stomatitis/cheilitis, which is inflammation and cracking at the corners of the mouth.       

Option Analysis

✅ Constant desire to eat ice:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Residence in a house built in the 1980s:
Incorrect: Houses built before 1978 are a risk factor for lead poisoning. This can impede iron absorption and result in iron deficiency anemia. However, living in a home built in the 1980s is not a risk factor for iron deficiency anemia from lead poisoning. 
❌ Consumption of 1 cup of milk per day:
Incorrect: Milk inhibits iron absorption, and normal milk intake at this age can be up to 3 cups/day. Consumption of one cup of milk/day is not a risk factor for iron deficiency anemia. 
❌ BMI in the 8th percentile:
Incorrect: There is an association between obesity and iron deficiency anemia. A BMI in the 8th percentile is considered healthy and is not a risk factor for iron deficiency anemia. 
❌ Frequent Use of acetaminophen:
Incorrect: Certain medications such as NSAIDs and proton pump inhibitors are associated with iron deficiency anemia. Frequent use of acetaminophen would not contribute to this patient’s iron deficiency anemia.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician with his parents for a routine well-child visit. He is a picky eater and primarily eats white pasta and bread. Parents give him 30 oz/day of milk to make sure he is full. They report that he needs two naps per day despite sleeping for 12 hours at night. They are not currently giving him multivitamins. Temperature is 37.3°C (99°F), pulse is 145/min, respirations are 30/min, blood pressure is 90/58 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Length is at the 60<sup>th</sup> percentile, weight is at the 82<sup>nd</sup> percentile, and head circumference is at the 45<sup>th</sup> percentile. On physical examination, he appears pale with cracks at the bilateral oral commissures. On cardiac exam, there is tachycardia with a soft 2/6 systolic murmur heard at the left sternal border. Lungs are clear to auscultation and there is no increased work of breathing. Nails appear brittle. Which of the following laboratory results is most consistent with the likely underlying diagnosis?

choices.text: HemoglobinMean Corpuscular Volume (MCV)Serum Ferritin (SF)Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC)LowLow Low High
HemoglobinMean Corpuscular Volume (MCV)Serum Ferritin (SF)Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC)LowNormalNormalLow
HemoglobinMean Corpuscular Volume (MCV)Serum Ferritin (SF)Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC)Low  Low Low Low
HemoglobinMean Corpuscular Volume (MCV)Serum Ferritin (SF)Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC)NormalNormalLowNormal
HemoglobinMean Corpuscular Volume (MCV)Serum Ferritin (SF)Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC)LowLowNormalHigh

questions.solution:
This patient has poor iron intake and a large volume of milk consumption. Milk causes poor absorption of iron and can exacerbate iron deficiency. On physical examination, the patient has signs and symptoms consistent with iron deficiency anemia including pallor, tachycardia, brittle nails, and angular cheilitis. Laboratory findings associated with iron deficiency anemia include low hemoglobin, low mean corpuscular volume (MCV), low serum ferritin (SF), and an elevated total iron binding capacity (TIBC).

When there is concern for iron deficiency anemia, it is important to obtain a complete blood count (CBC), as the hemoglobin and hematocrit will identify anemia and its severity. The mean corpuscular volume (MCV) can help differentiate between several types of anemia. A low MCV is associated with iron deficiency and lead toxicity. Mentzer Index refers to a calculation used to differentiate iron deficiency anemia from beta-thalassemia. If the MCV (fL) divided by RBC (millions/uL) is greater than 13, iron deficiency anemia is more likely.

Patients may have iron deficiency without anemia where the body lacks sufficient iron for normal growth and development; however, there is still adequate production of healthy red blood cells. This can be caused by malabsorptive conditions like celiac or inflammatory bowel disease. Iron studies should be performed if iron deficiency or iron deficiency anemia is suspected or if patients have conditions that can be associated with either. Studies should include reticulocyte hemoglobin concentration, serum ferritin, transferrin saturation, and total iron binding capacity (TIBC). Diagnostic findings of iron deficiency with and without anemia are summarized in the table below. It is important to remember that ferritin is also an acute phase reactant and may be elevated in the setting of inflammation from inflammatory conditions and chronic disease.
   

Option Analysis

✅ HemoglobinMean Corpuscular Volume (MCV)Serum Ferritin (SF)Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC)LowLow Low High :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ HemoglobinMean Corpuscular Volume (MCV)Serum Ferritin (SF)Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC)LowNormalNormalLow:
Incorrect: The patient in this vignette who consumes mostly bread and pasta and drinks large volumes of milk most likely has iron deficiency anemia. Iron deficiency anemia causes low hemoglobin, low MCV, low ferritin, and high TIBC. 
❌ HemoglobinMean Corpuscular Volume (MCV)Serum Ferritin (SF)Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC)Low  Low Low Low:
Incorrect: The patient in this vignette who consumes mostly bread and pasta and drinks large volumes of milk most likely has iron deficiency anemia. Iron deficiency anemia causes low hemoglobin, low MCV, low ferritin, and high TIBC. 
❌ HemoglobinMean Corpuscular Volume (MCV)Serum Ferritin (SF)Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC)NormalNormalLowNormal:
Incorrect: This set of blood results would be seen in a patient who has iron deficiency without anemia. Iron deficiency anemia, which is the most likely diagnosis for this patient, causes low hemoglobin and MCV, and a high TIBC.  
❌ HemoglobinMean Corpuscular Volume (MCV)Serum Ferritin (SF)Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC)LowLowNormalHigh:
Incorrect: This patient has iron deficiency anemia. Iron deficiency anemia causes a low serum ferritin level.

questions.text: A 42-day-old boy is brought to the emergency department for new-onset fever. The infant was born at 39 weeks and 2 days and is fed a combination of breast milk and formula. The pregnancy was complicated by breech presentation requiring a c-section. He was doing well until earlier that afternoon when he felt warm to touch and was difficult to soothe. Parents deny upper respiratory or gastrointestinal symptoms. There are no known sick contacts. Temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F), pulse is 185/min, respirations are 46/min, blood pressure is 75/45 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears tachypneic without increased work of breathing. Which of the following findings on history or physical examination would indicate the need for further testing and treatment?

choices.text: Maternal history of herpes simplex virus (HSV) treated during pregnancy with antiviral therapy
Maternal history of group B streptococcus
Erythematous papules and pustules over the face and scalp
Four wet diapers in the last 24 hours

questions.solution:
This 42-day-old infant has a new-onset fever. At this age, infants are at risk for invasive bacterial infections including bacteremia, urinary tract infections/urosepsis, and meningitis. A bulging anterior fontanelle can be seen in infants with acute meningitis and would be the most concerning finding in this clinical scenario and would require lumbar puncture and empiric antibiotics/antivirals.       

An extensive perinatal and birth history should be obtained for children with fever who are 0-60 days old. It is important to note whether the infant was premature, had an extended hospital stay following delivery, and the course of development since delivery. Parents should be asked about perinatal complications that require additional or more frequent evaluation and care. Maternal infections including group B streptococcus, herpes simplex virus (HSV), Neisseria gonorrhea, and Chlamydia trachomatis should be noted. If there is maternal history of an infection, follow-up questioning should include whether the mother was treated, received prophylaxis, or started on suppressive therapy.       

Children <60 days old with fever often present with non-specific symptoms such as fussiness, lethargy, and poor feeding. Depending on the source of the fever, they may also have diarrhea, vomiting, rash, cough, and congestion. Questioning regarding sick contacts can point to the source of fever. On physical examination, children <60 days old with a fever will likely demonstrate tachycardia associated with the fever. A sunken-in fontanelle is concerning for dehydration. Other signs and symptoms of dehydration include decreased urine output (concerning if <4 times/day), dry mucous membranes, and delayed capillary refill. A bulging fontanelle is concerning for meningitis or increased intracranial pressure. The rest of the physical exam should focus on trying to localize the source of infection.   

Option Analysis

✅ Bulging fontanelle:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Maternal history of herpes simplex virus (HSV) treated during pregnancy with antiviral therapy       :
Incorrect: An active maternal HSV outbreak during vaginal delivery puts an infant at risk for HSV infection and subsequently, HSV meningoencephalitis. However, the risk of transmission is dramatically reduced in c-section deliveries, compared to vaginal deliveries, and when mothers are on antivirals. A bulging fontanelle, seen in infants with meningitis, is a more concerning finding that would require further testing and treatment. 
❌ Maternal history of group B streptococcus:
Incorrect: Vaginal delivery of an infant to a mother with a history of group B streptococcus puts the infant at risk for infection. However, C-sections are minimal risk for vertical transmission of group B streptococcus. A bulging fontanelle, seen in infants with meningitis, is a more concerning finding that would require further testing and treatment.  
❌  Erythematous papules and pustules over the face and scalp:
Incorrect: Erythematous papules and pustules on the face and scalp would likely be due to neonatal acne, which is a benign, self-limited condition that can occur around one month of age. A bulging fontanelle, seen in infants with meningitis, is a more concerning finding that would require further testing and treatment. 
❌ Four wet diapers in the last 24 hours:
Incorrect: Four wet diapers in 24 hours are considered normal for a 1-month-old. Infants that have less than four wet diapers in 24 hours should be evaluated for dehydration. A bulging fontanelle, seen in infants with meningitis, is a more concerning finding. And would require further testing and treatment.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old girl presents to the office for dizziness, weakness, numbness and tingling in her hands and feet and headaches for 3 months. She reports feeling fatigued and has been noticing palpitations for the last week. There is no history of fever, peripheral edema, polyphagia, vomiting, or diarrhea. She does not use any medication. She has no significant surgeries. There is no family history of hypertension or renal disease. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and respirations are 18/min. Cardiopulmonary exam is normal. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Lab results are shown below. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be seen given the likely diagnosis? 

 Laboratory value     Result     
 Hemoglobin      12.5 g/dL    
 Serum sodium     148 mEq/L    
 Serum Potassium      2.5 mEq/L    
 Serum osmolality      250 mOsm/kg    
 PH     7.48    
 PCO2     40 mmHg    
 Bicarbonate     28 mEq/L    
 Blood urea nitrogen (BUN)     10 mg/dL    
 Creatinine      0.4 mg/dL    
 Urine sodium     20 mEq/L    
 Urine creatinine      230 mg/dL    
 Urine osmolality      350 mOsm/kg     
 Fractional excretion of sodium (FENa)     1%
questions.solution:
The patient’s history of fatigue, weakness, palpitations, and headaches with hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and fractional excretion of sodium (FENa) ≅ 1% is consistent with a diagnosis of primary hyperaldosteronism which can cause hypervolemic hypernatremia. Hypertension is a common finding in primary hyperaldosteronism and is often the reason the condition is discovered.

Patients with hypervolemic hypernatremia may present with a history of shortness of breath and weight gain; hypertension and tachypnea may be seen on examination, without or without peripheral edema, depending on the underlying cause. Excess salt load and primary hyperaldosteronism are causes of hypervolemic hypernatremia. Patients with primary hyperaldosteronism tend to have hypertension, which may be incidentally discovered, or they can present with muscle weakness, paresthesia, and persistent headaches from hypertension, as seen in this patient.

Primary hyperaldosteronism results from excessive adrenal aldosterone production, which can be caused by a primary adrenal tumor (i.e., Conn syndrome), or from bilateral adrenal hyperplasia. Excessive aldosterone production increases renal sodium and bicarbonate reabsorption, and potassium excretion, which leads to hypernatremia, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. FENa can help differentiate primary hyperaldosteronism from excess salt load in patients with hypervolemic hypernatremia. FENa ≅ 1% confirms the diagnosis of primary aldosteronism. If FENa is > 2%, excessive salt load secondary to hypertonic saline administration through intravenous fluids or dialysis can be the cause of hypervolemic hypernatremia.    

Option Analysis

❌ Dry mucous membranes :
Incorrect: Dry mucous membranes are seen in patients with hypovolemic hypernatremia secondary to fluid loss. This patient has no recent gastrointestinal illnesses with vomiting or diarrhea. She has evidence of primary aldosteronism, which causes hypervolemic hypernatremia. 
✅ Blood pressure of 138/86 mmHg  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Weight loss :
Incorrect: Weight loss can be seen in patients with hypovolemic hypernatremia secondary to fluid loss. This patient’s history, exam findings, and labs are consistent with primary aldosteronism, which can cause hypervolemic hypernatremia associated with weight gain and hypertension. 
❌ Excessive sweating  :
Incorrect: Excessive sweating may lead to hypovolemic hypernatremia secondary to insensible fluid loss. Patients with hypovolemic hypernatremia present with signs of dehydration and urine osmolality > 750 mOsm/kg which is not noted in this case. 
❌ Jaundice  :
Incorrect: Jaundice is a common sign of sickle disease crises which occurs secondary to dehydration and affects kidney functions, leading to hypovolemic hypernatremia. The patient’s normal hemoglobin and kidney function makes sickle cell disease unlikely.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old girl presents is brought to the clinic by her parents who have noticed excessive drinking of water and an increased frequency of urination for 2 months. Symptoms started gradually but have progressively worsened. There is no history of edema, polyphagia, fever, head trauma, chronic cough, recent weight gain or loss, or seizures prior to onset of symptoms. She uses lithium for treatment of bipolar disorder. Past surgical and family history are non-contributory. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg. Physical exam reveals moist mucous membranes and capillary refill is 2 seconds. Cardiopulmonary exam is normal. Abdomen is soft and non-tender with no hepatomegaly. Lab results are shown below. Which of the following should be done next to confirm the diagnosis?  

 Laboratory value      Result    
 Serum sodium     149 mEq/L    
 Serum Potassium     3.5 mEq/L    
 Serum Calcium      9.2 mg/dL    
 Serum Osmolality      370 mOsm/kg     
 Blood urea nitrogen (BUN)     15 mg/dL    
 Creatinine      0.5 mg/dL    
 Random blood glucose      74 mg/dL    
 Urine specific gravity      1005     
 Urine Osmolality      100 mOsm/kg
questions.solution:
The patient presents with polyuria and polydipsia, with normal heart rate and blood pressure, moist mucous membranes, and the absence of weight gain or loss, suggesting euvolemic hypernatremia. Labs show hypernatremia, urine osmolality < 300 mOsm/kg, serum osmolality > 300 mOsm/kg, and diluted urine indicating diabetes insipidus (DI). She has a history of bipolar disorder and is taking lithium, which is known to cause nephrogenic DI. Therefore, the best next step to confirm the diagnosis is a desmopressin challenge test.

DI can result from vasopressin deficiency (central DI) or vasopressin insensitivity at the level of the kidney (nephrogenic DI). The diagnosis of DI is established if the serum osmolality is >300 mOsm/kg, and the urine osmolality is <300 mOsm/kg. In this patient, a desmopressin challenge test is indicated to establish the diagnosis of DI and to differentiate central from nephrogenic causes. Nephrogenic DI can be congenital or acquired. Congenital nephrogenic DI is less common and may be seen in the first several weeks of life. Acquired nephrogenic DI can result from medication intake such as lithium and amphotericin B, or electrolyte abnormalities such as hypercalcemia or hypokalemia.

Desmopressin challenge test is performed by giving the patient desmopressin and evaluating the urine osmolality after 1 hour. If the urine osmolality increases by 50% or less with no change in urine volume, the kidneys are not responding to vasopressin, which confirms nephrogenic DI. However, if urine osmolality increases by more than 50% with an increase in urine volume, that indicates vasopressin deficiency and that the kidneys are responding normally to vasopressin. Central DI can be diagnosed in this scenario, which usually occurs in the setting of head trauma, intracranial tumors like craniopharyngioma, anatomic pituitary or hypothalamus defects, or intracranial surgery.    

Option Analysis

❌ Abdominal computed tomography scan (CT scan) :
Incorrect: Abdominal CT scan may show evidence of adrenal hyperplasia or Conn syndrome which can lead to hypervolemic hyponatremia. This patient does not have signs of hypervolemia, and she has normal blood pressure and normal potassium levels, making primary hyperaldosteronism unlikely.  
❌ C-peptide levels  :
Incorrect: C-peptide levels can help confirm the diagnosis of diabetes mellitus. This patient presents with polyuria and polydipsia. However, the normal random blood glucose levels and diluted urine make diabetes insipidus the most likely diagnosis in this case.  
✅ Desmopressin challenge test :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Fractional excretion of sodium (FENa) :
Incorrect: Fractional excretion of sodium (FENa) can help differentiate the causes of hypervolemic hypernatremia. This patient does not have a history of weight gain, hypertension, or edema on physical examination, which makes hypervolemic hypernatremia unlikely. 
❌ Microscopic urine examination :
Incorrect: Microscopic urine examination may show muddy brown casts in patients with acute tubular necrosis (ATN). ATN with polyuria can lead to elevated creatinine and hypovolemic hypernatremia, which is not noted in this patient.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought by her parents to the emergency department for evaluation of a new limp. The patient has had fevers over the past 4 days and has been complaining of left groin pain. For the past day she has refused to walk and to move the left leg. The patient was ill with a viral upper respiratory tract infection (URI) one week ago but has no significant past medical history and does not take any medication. The patient was born full-term, and vaccinations are up-to-date. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), blood pressure is 88/45 mmHg, pulse is 140/min, respiratory rate is 28/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is in no acute distress. She is sitting in bed with the left hip flexed, slightly abducted, and externally rotated. Examination reveals tenderness to palpation of the left groin. She starts crying when the examiner attempts passive motion of the joint. The patient refuses to move the left leg and to bear weight on the left lower extremity. Which of the following findings is most concerning for a serious bacterial infection?

choices.text: Refusal of active and passive range of motion of the affected joint

questions.solution:
This pediatric patient presents for assessment of a limp with left hip and groin pain, fevers, and refusal to bear weight and move the leg. The fact that the patient is holding the leg flexed, slightly abducted, and externally rotated and refusing to walk along with the finding of pain with passive movement of the hip are concerning for septic arthritis of the hip.

Septic arthritis refers to a bacterial infection of the synovium and joint space. Transient synovitis (toxic synovitis) is noninfectious synovial inflammation and can present similarly. Differentiating the two is important since the treatment is different. Transient synovitis is a benign and self-limited illness, whereas septic arthritis requires drainage of the joint and antibiotics to prevent permanent bone, joint damage, and multisystem involvement. 

Pediatric patients with septic arthritis typically experience acute onset monoarticular joint pain and swelling (most commonly the knee, hip, or ankle), as well as systemic signs and symptoms, like fever, malaise, and decreased appetite. Most patients will demonstrate limited range of motion and refuse to walk on the affected limb. Infants and non-ambulatory children may display “pseudoparalysis,” which refers to the inability to move the affected joint due to pain. Patients are usually ill-appearing, with signs of erythema, warmth, and swelling of the skin overlying the affected joint.

Patients with transient synovitis typically present with monoarticular joint pain and swelling that usually affects the hip. Unlike constant joint pain seen with septic arthritis, joint pain with transient synovitis may wax and wane, and most patients will be afebrile or have a low-grade fever. Patients may show an improved range of motion soon after the use of NSAIDS. Most patients can bear weight on the affected extremity, though they may show a limp. History will often reveal a recent upper respiratory infection or episode of acute gastroenteritis. Physical examination typically reveals a well-appearing patient with possible joint effusion, in combination with limited range of motion of the affected joint due to pain.    

Option Analysis

✅ Refusal of active and passive range of motion of the affected joint:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Fever :
Incorrect: Both transient synovitis and septic arthritis can present with fevers. Generally, the fever in patients with septic arthritis is higher. However, it does not serve as a clear clinical differentiator between the two disorders. Refusal of active and passive range of motion of the affected joint is more concerning for septic arthritis. 
❌ Limping:
Incorrect: Limping occurs in transient synovitis and septic arthritis. Refusal of active and passive range of motion of the affected joint is more concerning for septic arthritis. 
❌ Monoarticular involvement:
Incorrect: Monoarticular involvement occurs in patients with transient synovitis and septic arthritis. This clinical feature cannot be used to distinguish the two conditions. Refusal of active and passive range of motion of the affected joint is more concerning for septic arthritis. 
❌ History of recent URI:
Incorrect: History of a recent upper respiratory tract infection is suggestive of transient synovitis as opposed to septic arthritis. Transient synovitis is usually a benign condition and is not secondary to a bacterial infection. Refusal of active and passive range of motion of the affected joint is more concerning for septic arthritis.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy is brought by his parents to the emergency department for evaluation of a limp. The parent reports that the symptoms were preceded by a cough and congestion one week ago. The patient has no significant past medical history and does not take any medication. He is up-to-date on his vaccinations. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), blood pressure is 91/46 mmHg, pulse is 142/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is comfortable and in no acute distress. There is limited range of motion at the right hip secondary to pain. He can bear weight on the lower right extremity. An ultrasound of the right hip demonstrates evidence of a moderate effusion. Blood work and arthrocentesis are obtained, and results are shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?  

 Laboratory value      Result     
 Hemoglobin     12.8  g/dL     
 Leukocyte count     13,100/mm3     
 Platelet count     320,000/mm3     
 CRP     0.2 mg/dL     
 ESR     6 mm/h     
 Synovial fluid analysis     
 Gram stain, culture      Negative, no growth     
 Fluid      Clear, yellow          
 Cell count      6500 WBC/mm3
questions.solution:
Transient Synovitis 

This pediatric patient presents for assessment of right hip pain after a recent viral illness. He has multiple clinical features suggestive of transient synovitis. Blood work shows a mildly elevated white blood cell count and there is evidence of a moderate effusion on hip ultrasonography. Arthrocentesis of the hip involved demonstrates no evidence of septic arthritis with no growth on culture. The findings are consistent with transient synovitis which is typically self-limited and resolves on its own within 2 weeks. The initial recommended treatment for this condition involves rest and NSAIDs.

Septic arthritis refers to a bacterial infection of the synovium and joint space. Transient synovitis (toxic synovitis) is noninfectious synovial inflammation and can present similarly. Differentiating the two is important since the treatment is different.

If there is enough suspicion, formal diagnosis of septic arthritis and transient synovitis can be confirmed via joint aspiration, with evaluation of synovial fluid cell count with differential, gram stain, and culture. When children present with hip pain and there is concern for septic arthritis, arthrocentesis should be performed. In patients with septic arthritis, synovial fluid analysis will typically reveal bacterial growth, cloudy or purulent fluid, as well as a cell count > 50K WBC/mm3. These patients will also typically have positive blood cultures. In contrast, patients with transient synovitis will have a negative gram stain and culture, clear or yellow fluid, and a cell count of 5K - 15K WBC/mm3.

Treatment of septic arthritis involves empiric intravenous antibiotics based on the patient's age, clinical status, and risk factors. Antibiotics are tailored to the synovial fluid culture and sensitivity results. Arthrocentesis is both diagnostic and therapeutic and is necessary to decompress the joint space and remove inflammatory debris. Surgical consultation may be necessary for arthroscopic drainage or arthrotomy. In contrast, transient synovitis is managed conservatively, with treatment focused on pain control, rest, and supportive care.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administer ibuprofen:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Admit for observation:
Incorrect: This patient has transient synovitis and there is no indication for observation. This patient can be discharged home. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications such as Ibuprofen are recommended to help with pain and to reduce inflammation. 
❌ Administer intraarticular glucocorticoids:
Incorrect: Administration of intraarticular glucocorticoids is not indicated in the treatment of transient synovitis. Administration of glucocorticoids can be considered for patients with juvenile idiopathic oligoarthritis. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications such as Ibuprofen are recommended to help with pain and to reduce inflammation in patients with transient synovitis. 
❌ Consult orthopedics:
Incorrect: Orthopedic surgical consultation is indicated in the setting of septic arthritis, as these patients will typically require a washout of the joint space. This patient has transient synovitis, which does not require orthopedic consultation. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications such as Ibuprofen are recommended to help with pain and to reduce inflammation. 
❌ Administer nafcillin:
Incorrect: This patient’s clinical presentation is consistent with transient synovitis. Antibiotics are not clinically indicated. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications such as Ibuprofen are recommended to help with pain and to reduce inflammation.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic by his parents due to right leg pain. Several weeks ago, he developed pain in the right leg that is worse at night and has been increasing in intensity. There was no preceding injury or trauma. The pain resolves quickly with naproxen. He has had no associated fever, chills, weight loss, or rash. Vital signs are within normal limits.  The patient is well-appearing and is not in acute distress. Physical examination reveals localized tenderness to palpation and swelling at the right proximal thigh with limited range of motion of the right hip. Plain radiographs of the right hip and femur are ordered. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 12-year-old boy presents with several weeks of right leg pain without a preceding injury. The pain is worse at night. Physical examination shows localized tenderness and swelling of the right proximal thigh and limited range of motion of the hip. The pain adequately responds to the use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as naproxen. Based on this constellation of findings, the most likely diagnosis is an osteoid osteoma.

Pediatric patients with bone tumors typically present between the ages of 10-20. They may have localized bone pain and, in some cases, localized swelling or a palpable mass. Occasionally, there is limited range of motion of the adjacent joint. The findings may be associated with a pathologic fracture. Malignant bone tumors may be associated with a dull pain that awakens the child from sleep at night and associated systemic findings, such as fatigue, malaise, fever, and weight loss.

Patients with benign bone lesions may present with pain, but often patients are asymptomatic, and the bone lesions are found incidentally when radiographs are obtained for other reasons, such as trauma. Osteochondromas and non-ossifying fibromas are typically asymptomatic and found incidentally. Patients with Langerhans cell histiocytosis may present with localized pain and multisystem involvement.

Osteoid osteomas are benign bone tumors that have a nidus of prostaglandin-producing cells. Patients with osteoid osteomas typically present with pain that is worse at night and resolves quickly (within 20 to 25 minutes) with the use of NSAIDS (i.e., prostaglandin inhibitors). If a patient with a bone lesion has bone pain that does not resolve quickly with NSAIDs, other diagnoses should be considered.
       

Option Analysis

✅ Osteoid osteoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Osteochondroma:
Incorrect: Osteochondroma is a benign bone lesion that is often asymptomatic and detected incidentally when radiographs are done for a different reason (e.g. trauma). The most common location of an osteochondroma is the distal femur, whereas the most common location of an osteoid osteoma is the proximal femur. The location of this patient’s pain, in addition to the degree of pain and the fact that it is worse at night and relieved with naproxen, makes osteoid osteoma the most likely diagnosis. 
❌ Non-ossifying fibroma  :
Incorrect: Non-ossifying fibroma is an asymptomatic benign bone lesion that is typically seen as an incidental finding when radiographs are done for a different reason (e.g. trauma). The most common location of a non-ossifying fibroma is the distal femur, whereas the most common location of an osteoid osteoma is the proximal femur. The patient’s pain, in addition to its location at the proximal femur and relief with naproxen, makes osteoid osteoma the most likely diagnosis. 
❌ Simple bone cyst:
Incorrect: Simple bone cysts typically present in the setting of pathologic fractures, otherwise they are usually asymptomatic. This patient has significant pain that is worse at night and responds to naproxen, which is consistent with an osteoid osteoma.  
❌ Langerhans cell histiocytosis:
Incorrect: Langerhans cell histiocytosis can present with localized bone pain but typically causes systemic symptoms, such as rash. In addition, this patient’s pain is worse at night and relieved with naproxen, making osteoid osteoma the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy comes to the pediatric clinic because of several weeks of dull localized left upper arm pain that is worse at night. He has not had recent trauma and has not done any strenuous physical activity recently. He has no fever or weight loss. He has no significant past medical history and does not take any medication. Temperature is 37.0 ºC (98.6 ºF), heart rate is 90/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and blood pressure is 110/68 mmHg. He is well-appearing, comfortable, and not in acute pain. Physical examination reveals a large, tender, palpable soft tissue mass in the left proximal upper arm. Plain radiographs of the left arm are ordered. Which of the following imaging findings would be the most concerning for malignancy?

choices.text: Sclerotic borders around a well-defined lesion

questions.solution:
This 16-year-old boy presents with several weeks of localized bone pain that is worse at night and not associated with trauma or systemic symptoms. Physical examination reveals a large tender soft tissue mass increasing the index of suspicion for a bone tumor, most likely an osteosarcoma. Radiography is used to help diagnose bone tumors in children, and findings can indicate if the lesion has high-risk features consistent with malignant or destructive lesions or minimal risk features consistent with benign lesions. The finding of a lesion with poorly defined borders is a high-risk feature that is associated with malignant tumors.

Pediatric bone tumors may be benign or malignant and must be diagnosed and treated promptly since malignant tumors can be limb- or life-threatening. A plain radiograph is used to assess for high-risk features which include poorly defined borders, sclerotic lesions, and an aggressive periosteal reaction. High-risk features are associated with malignant bone tumors including osteosarcomas and Ewing sarcomas, as well as benign, yet destructive, aneurysmal bone cysts.

Benign bone tumors/lesions are not associated with high-risk findings on radiography. Benign bone tumors include osteoid osteomas, osteochondromas, non-ossifying fibromas, simple bone cysts, and Langerhans cell histiocytosis. If any high-risk findings are detected on radiography, then magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) should be performed. Bone biopsy should be done for histologic confirmation and staging.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Lesion with poorly defined borders:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lesion without periosteal reaction:
Incorrect: The presence of an aggressive periosteal reaction, (i.e., new bone production in the periosteum caused by irritation), is alarming and considered a high-risk finding associated with malignancy. Alternatively, lack of periosteal reaction is more suggestive of a non-malignant, less-aggressive lesion, though lack of periosteal reaction does not exclude a malignant lesion. In addition to an aggressive periosteal reaction, lesions with poorly defined borders, and sclerotic lesions on x-ray are concerning for malignancy. 
❌ Sclerotic borders around a well-defined lesion:
Incorrect: While a sclerotic lesion is a high-risk finding associated with malignancy, the finding of sclerotic borders around a well-defined lesion is indicative of a benign bone lesion. In addition to sclerotic lesions, lesions with poorly defined borders and an aggressive periosteal reaction on x-ray are concerning for malignancy.  
❌ Well-defined lytic lesion:
Incorrect: Non-ossifying fibromas and Langerhans cell histiocytosis can be seen on radiographs as well-defined lytic lesions. These are both benign bone lesions. X-ray findings of sclerotic lesions, and lesions with poorly defined borders, or an aggressive periosteal reaction are concerning for malignancy. 
❌ Cartilage-capped bony spur :
Incorrect: Osteochondromas are benign lesions that appear as cartilage-capped bony spurs on radiography. X-ray findings of sclerotic lesions and lesions with poorly defined borders or an aggressive periosteal reaction are concerning for malignancy.

questions.text: A 6-month-old girl presents to the emergency department for evaluation of an episode of cyanosis and poor tone. The mother reports the patient was playing with toys when she suddenly became limp and "turned blue” for approximately 30 seconds. The patient had a pulse throughout the episode, and no cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) was delivered. The patient immediately returned to baseline and has been acting appropriately since the episode. The patient was born full term without complications and has no significant medical history. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 99/60 mmHg, pulse is 130/min, respiratory rate is 36/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient is evaluated by the emergency room physician and is deemed appropriate for discharge home without further evaluation. Which of the following findings is most likely to have been found during physical examination?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with several clinical findings consistent with a brief, resolved, unexplained event (BRUE). The patient had an episode of cyanosis and hypotonia lasting less than one minute. After evaluation by the emergency room physician, the patient is deemed appropriate for discharge home without further workup. Therefore, the patient must be considered low-risk. Patients with low-risk features will have a normal physical examination at the time of evaluation. An open anterior fontanelle is appropriate for a patient who is 6 months old.

BRUEs are witnessed episodes during infancy, lasting less than one minute, that are characterized by cyanosis or pallor; absent, decreased, or irregular breathing; a marked change in muscle tone; or altered responsiveness; followed by a return to the infant’s baseline state of health. A BRUE is diagnosed when no underlying cause for these symptoms can be identified after a thorough history, physical examination, and occasionally lab work and further evaluation. Based on historical features and exam findings, infants who meet the criteria for a BRUE can be classified into high or low-risk categories.

When a BRUE is suspected, a careful history and physical examination should be performed to assess for high-risk BRUE features, the presence of which will guide further workup and management. High-risk features include age <60 days old, history of prematurity, more than one BRUE episode, episode >1 minute, and history of cardiopulmonary resuscitation by a medical provider. Patients are also considered high-risk if they have concerning historical features or physical examination findings such as, but not limited to, respiratory illness, access to medications, episodic vomiting or lethargy, congenital anomalies, bulging anterior fontanelle, or abnormal bruising. Patients with high-risk features should be further evaluated for targeted precipitating factors or physical examination findings that might suggest an underlying infectious process, inborn error of metabolism, cardiovascular anomaly, GERD/laryngospasm, epilepsy, or potential child abuse. Most patients with low-risk features will have a normal physical examination.    

Option Analysis

✅ Open anterior fontanelle:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Systolic murmur:
Incorrect: If a murmur is appreciated in a patient who presents after a brief, resolved, unexplained event (BRUE), hospital observation and further evaluation to rule-out a cardiac cause of the event is required 
❌ Ecchymosis on the face:
Incorrect: Signs of unexplained trauma such as bruising in atypical locations (e.g., scalp, face, ears) should raise concern for non-accidental trauma and abuse. These findings warrant hospital observation and further evaluation. 
❌ Repetitive predictable movements:
Incorrect: Repetitive predictable or stereotyped movements raise concern for seizure activity or other neurological disorder. These findings warrant hospital observation and further evaluation. 
❌ Cough:
Incorrect: At the time of the evaluation of a patient with a brief, resolved, unexplained event (BRUE), patients with upper respiratory symptoms should have further evaluation such as testing for pertussis and respiratory syncytial virus. This should be performed before discharging home.

questions.text: A 2.5-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of an episode of limpness and cyanosis. The father states that the patient was sitting in his arms when he suddenly lost muscle tone and became blue. He states the episode lasted about 30 seconds and the patient immediately returned to his baseline. The patient was born at 30 weeks' gestation. The patient’s parent has a history of a congenital heart defect, and the father has a seizure disorder. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 94/55mmHg, pulse is 138/min, respiratory rate is 35/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is well-appearing. The anterior fontanelle is open and flat, mucus membranes are moist, cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits, and no rashes or ecchymosis are noted. Which of the following historical features indicates the need for further workups?

choices.text: Maternal history of congenital heart disease

questions.solution:
This patient presents with clinical findings consistent with a brief, resolved, unexplained event (BRUE) including cyanosis and decreased muscle tone lasting less than one minute with return to baseline after the event. Patients with high-risk features should have close monitoring and further inpatient evaluation. In the setting of a BRUE, prematurity is a high-risk factor that warrants further evaluation. Therefore, this patient who was born at 30 weeks of gestation needs inpatient observation and further evaluation.

Based on historical features and exam findings, infants who meet the criteria for BRUE are classified into high and low-risk categories. Patients considered high-risk should be admitted for observation, supportive care, and further evaluation. Potential underlying causes of a BRUE-like event include infectious processes, inborn errors of metabolism, cardiovascular anomalies, gastroesophageal reflux/laryngospasm, epilepsy, and child abuse. When a clear precipitating event is not apparent on history or physical examination, a work-up should include pulse oximetry monitoring, electrocardiogram, hematocrit, blood glucose, bicarbonate or venous blood gas, lactic acid, respiratory virus testing panel, and testing for pertussis. It is also important to review newborn screening test results.

In contrast, patients with low-risk features are typically discharged without observation or further evaluation. A brief in-hospital observation, electrocardiogram, and testing for pertussis or other respiratory viruses can be considered but are not required. These patients can be safely discharged following parental education and ensuring close follow-up.
 
 

Option Analysis

✅ Birth at 30 weeks of gestation:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Maternal history of congenital heart disease:
Incorrect: A maternal history of a congenital heart defect does not classify a patient who has experienced a high-risk brief, resolved, unexplained event (BRUE) as high-risk and requiring further workup. 
❌ Paternal history of seizure disorder :
Incorrect: A paternal history of seizure disorder does not classify a patient who has experienced a high-risk brief, resolved, unexplained event (BRUE) as high-risk and requiring further workup. 
❌ Age of 2.5 months:
Incorrect: Infants greater than 2 months old at the time of a high-risk brief, resolved, unexplained event (BRUE) are considered low-risk and do not warrant further evaluation if no other high-risk features are present. 
❌ Episode lasting 30 seconds :
Incorrect: Episodes that last less than one minute are considered low-risk and do not indicate the need for further workup to evaluate for an underlying etiology.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought by his parents to the pediatrician’s office for evaluation of 5 days of fever, rhinorrhea, and a cough. He has also developed a red rash in the perineal area, and bilateral eye redness. Weight is 68th percentile, length is 54th percentile, and head circumference is 44th percentile. Temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 142/min, respirations are 32/min, blood pressure is 88/42 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, there is bilateral conjunctivital erythema without discharge. The lips are red and cracked, and the tongue is erythematous (see below). There is erythema and desquamation in the perineal region. There is a single 2cm mobile left anterior cervical lymph node. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Which of the following physical examination findings is most likely to be seen given the likely underlying condition?

choices.text: Erythema of the palms and soles
Single vesicular lesion on the finger

questions.solution:
This patient presents with 5 days of fever, bilateral non-exudative conjunctivitis, cracked red lips, strawberry tongue, a desquamating rash in the perineal area, and a single enlarged cervical lymph node. These findings are consistent with Kawasaki disease. Extremity changes which may consist of edema of the hands and feet and erythema of the palms and soles are included in the clinical criteria for Kawasaki disease.

A diagnosis of Kawasaki disease can be made if the patient has ≥5 days of fever along with 4 out of 5 of the following findings: bilateral conjunctival injection, oral mucous membrane changes, >1.5 cm cervical lymphadenopathy, polymorphous rash, and peripheral extremity changes. Changes to the extremities typically appear last and include edema of the dorsum of the hands and feet and diffuse erythema of the palms and soles. Patients may also have arthritis and cardiovascular findings.

In the setting of peripheral lymphadenopathy, patients often present for evaluation of a lump or mass. The location of the lump can help identify it as a lymph node, as lymph nodes are frequently palpated along the cervical chain, hairline, axilla, and inguinal canal. History in patients with lymphadenopathy may include fever, fatigue, and poor appetite.

Peripheral lymphadenopathy can be caused by malignancy, autoimmune conditions, and infections. Signs and symptoms suggestive of malignancy include nontender, firm, immobile lymph nodes; palpable supraclavicular nodes; and persistently enlarged nodes. Signs and symptoms of autoimmune conditions include joint pain, fever, rash, and nontender mobile lymph nodes.

Peripheral lymphadenopathy secondary to infection, typically presents acutely (<4 weeks) with tender and mobile Lymph nodes. A single tender lymph node is concerning for a primary lymph node infection such as lymphadenitis or cat-scratch disease. Regional lymphadenopathy is concerning for localized infection such as otitis media, cellulitis, or strep pharyngitis. Generalized lymphadenopathy is often observed in systemic infections such as HIV, Ebstein-Barr virus, cytomegalovirus, toxoplasmosis, and adenoviral infections.   

Option Analysis

✅ Erythema of the palms and soles:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Exudative pharyngitis:
Incorrect: Exudative pharyngitis is associated with strep pharyngitis and infectious mononucleosis. This patient has clinical findings consistent with Kawasaki disease. Oropharyngeal findings associated with Kawasaki disease include erythematous cracked lips, strawberry tongue, and erythema of the pharynx but without exudate. 
❌ Splenomegaly:
Incorrect: Splenomegaly is associated with various illnesses including Ebstein Barr virus (infectious mononucleosis) and malignancy. Splenomegaly is not associated with Kawasaki disease. 
❌ White lesions on the buccal mucosa:
Incorrect: White lesions on the buccal mucosa known as Koplik spots, are associated with measles, and not Kawasaki disease. 
❌ Single vesicular lesion on the finger :
Incorrect: Patients with cat scratch disease can have lymphadenopathy and typically have a lesion at the inoculation site often on the hands. However, this patient has a constellation of findings consistent with Kawasaki disease and is more likely to have erythema of the palms and soles.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the clinic due to concerns regarding the lack of facial hair and pubic hair. There is no history of seizures, headaches, or exposure to radiation. Family history and birth history are unremarkable. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mm Hg. On physical examination, the patient has no facial hair, no pubic hair, and small testes. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are normal. Luteinizing hormones, follicle stimulating hormones and testosterone levels are low. Genetic testing is positive for ANOS1 gene mutation. Which of the following additional findings would be expected?

choices.text: Elevated TSH and low free T4

questions.solution:
This 15-year-old boy who presents with delayed puberty is found to have hypogonadotropic hypogonadism and a positive ANOS1 gene mutation confirming the diagnosis of Kallman syndrome. Anosmia (i.e., impaired, or absent sense of smell) is a characteristic clinical feature of Kallman syndrome.

Kallman syndrome is an inherited disorder with a genetic mutation of anosmin-1 (ANOS1) formerly called the (KAL1) gene. Patients with Kallman syndrome can have a combination of delayed puberty, anosmia, and midline defects, such as a cleft lip or palate and gonadotropins deficiency. Patients may also have color blindness, atrial septal defects, and renal structural anomalies. Some patients present with bimanual synkinesia, also known as mirror movement, where voluntary movement of one hand results in involuntary movement of the other hand.

Physical examination may show lack of hair and small testes. Patients will have low levels of luteinizing hormone, follicle-stimulating hormone, and testosterone, indicating congenital hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Left-hand X-ray should be obtained and may reveal delayed bone age. A scratch-and-sniff smell test should be ordered to test for anosmia when Kallman syndrome is suspected. Genetic testing can confirm the diagnosis with presence of ANOS1 (KAL1) gene mutation.

Option Analysis

✅ Anosmia  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Gynecomastia  :
Incorrect: Gynecomastia may be found in male patients with hyperprolactinemia who have delayed puberty. This patient’s findings of delayed puberty and prepubertal levels on bloodwork are consistent with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. This patient is positive for the ANOS1 gene mutation consistent with the anosmic form of Isolated gonadotropin-releasing hormone deficiency (i.e., Kallman syndrome). Anosmia would be expected. 
❌ Visual field defects :
Incorrect: Visual field defects and headaches are typically noted in patients with central nervous system tumors compressing the pituitary gland or the hypothalamus which can lead to acquired hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. This patient with delayed puberty and ANOS1 gene mutation has Kallman syndrome and therefore anosmia would be expected. 
❌ Excessive exercising:
Incorrect: Functional hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is when there is impairment of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis (HPG-A) functioning, resulting in decreased testosterone and delayed puberty. Excessive exercise can cause this. However, this patient has the genetic mutation associated with Kallman syndrome, which is the cause of delayed puberty, and amsonia would be expected. 
❌ Elevated TSH and low free T4:
Incorrect: Severe primary hypothyroidism can cause these lab results and delayed puberty. However, this patient has the genetic mutation associated with Kallman syndrome, which is the cause of delayed puberty, and amsonia would be expected.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents, along with her parents, to the emergency department for evaluation of one-day of fever, cough, increased work of breathing, and lethargy. Parents report the patient was recently ill with a “virus” last week. They state the patient was being watched by her elderly grandmother today and was difficult to arouse when they arrived to pick her up. The patient has a history of asthma, controlled with Albuterol as needed, and is otherwise healthy. Vaccinations are up-to-date. Weight is 67th percentile and height is 56th percentile. Temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), blood pressure is 77/40mmHg, pulse is 142/min, respiratory rate is 26/min, and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. The patient is ill-appearing, with a pale complexion, and moans in response to voice. She has dry mucous membranes and increased breathing work. Rales are appreciated over the right lung base. The patient is attached to the monitor and receives supplemental oxygen. In the first 5 minutes, multiple attempts are made at obtaining intravenous access without success. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Place a central venous catheter in the left internal jugular vein

questions.solution:
This patient presents with features of pediatric sepsis, including symptoms of systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS), toxic appearance, and the presence of a localized infection (e.g., pneumonia). Acute management of pediatric sepsis involves airway, breathing, and circulation stabilization. These patients are often significantly volume depleted, making intravenous access difficult. In this setting, rapid access is often best achieved via intraosseous line placement. This allows for rapid resuscitation with crystalloid, antibiotic, and vasopressor infusion, if needed. Delays in fluid administration have been associated with complications and mortality.

Sepsis refers to a dysregulated immune response to infection and is frequently associated with organ dysfunction, shock, and death. The infection can be bacterial, viral, or fungal, and may originate from any tissue, initiating a complex interplay between infectious virulence factors and host defense mechanisms. The main goals of management are to identify and treat the infection while maintaining hemodynamic stability to prevent or minimize organ damage. Pediatric patients with sepsis often have vague symptoms, like irritability and poor feeding, and on physical exam, they may have altered mental status and appear toxic or lethargic. They are often febrile or hypothermic and exhibit tachycardia, bradycardia, or hypotension. Occasionally, there is tachypnea and respiratory distress. 

Most patients with pediatric sepsis are unstable and require airway, breathing, and circulation stabilization via modalities such as respiratory support (i.e., intubation) and intravenous access. While many of these patients eventually require central venous access for hemodynamic support, this should not delay immediate intravenous access. These patients also require continuous vital sign monitoring, crystalloids, broad spectrum antibiotic therapy, and source control. Once stabilized, patients should undergo a focused history and physical exam and have blood work obtained to assess for associated metabolic complications and evidence of end-organ ischemia.   

Option Analysis

✅ Place an intraosseous line in the left tibia:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Administer oral acetaminophen:
Incorrect: While this patient can be given antipyretic therapy as a resuscitative measure, the most crucial priority step is establishing intravenous access for fluid resuscitation. This patient has multiple findings suggesting hemodynamic instability requiring prompt fluid administration. 
❌ Place a central venous catheter in the left internal jugular vein:
Incorrect: While this patient will require a central venous catheter for fluid, antibiotic, and vasopressor administration, the patient first requires immediate stabilization via intravenous access and IV fluid resuscitation. Placing a central venous catheter can be time-consuming and may result in further hemodynamic instability with potential morbidity. This patient requires more immediate access, which is best achieved via intraosseous line placement.  
❌ Administer intramuscular antibiotics:
Incorrect: Although this patient is septic due to a likely respiratory infection that will require antibiotics, the first step in management is stabilization of the patient with intravenous access and IV fluids. Intraosseous access is recommended if attempts at an intravenous line are unsuccessful. The goal is to stabilize the patient, obtain labs, and start intravenous antibiotics within one hour of presentation to the emergency department. 
❌ Administer oral rehydration therapy:
Incorrect: This patient is critically ill with multiple vital sign derangements requiring immediate stabilization. Oral rehydration therapy is inappropriate. This patient requires intraosseous access for fluids and medication.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents with her parents to the emergency department for evaluation of fever and lethargy. Parents state the patient has had a headache over the past three days, and today she said she was too tired to get out of bed. She has had decreased oral intake. The patient has no significant past medical history; but, parents report that vaccinations are not up-to-date. Patient is febrile, blood pressure is 107/64 mmHg, pulse is 115/min, respiratory rate is 26/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. The patient is ill-appearing and complains of a headache and neck stiffness. She is tachypneic with rapid, shallow breathing. However, the lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. A purpuric rash is appreciated over the trunk. Intravenous fluids and empiric antibiotics are started based on the most likely diagnosis. Which of the following additional findings would be an indication of septic shock?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with features of pediatric sepsis, including systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS), toxic appearance, and findings consistent with a localized infection. This patient has meningitis and meningococcemia as suggested by the fever, neck stiffness, purpuric rash, and under immunized status. Delayed capillary refill is the most concerning finding since it is a sign of poor perfusion and septic shock. Septic shock can lead to organ failure and increased mortality. 

Sepsis refers to a dysregulated immune response to infection and is frequently associated with organ dysfunction, shock, and death.
