questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician’s office for a sports clearance evaluation prior to football tryouts. The boy has no symptoms. The parent reports that the family history is significant for a grandparent who died unexpectedly at age 38 from a “thickened heart” that was seen on autopsy. On physical examination, temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), heart rate is 66/min, blood pressure is 111/63 mmHg, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient is well-appearing and in no acute distress. Cardiac examination reveals a regular heart rate. Which of the following murmurs would indicate the patient has the same condition as his grandfather?

choices.text: Systolic ejection murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border, that is louder with Valsalva
Holosystolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border
Early diastolic, high-pitched, blowing murmur heard best at the left sternal border
Continuous murmur heard below the clavicles that disappears when supine
Blowing systolic ejection murmur heard best at the left upper sternal border that radiates to the back

questions.solution:
This patient’s family history of a grandfather who had sudden cardiac death (SCD) at an early age from a “thickened heart” is concerning for hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). Since this condition can be inherited, the patient may also have HCM. Findings on exam of a systolic ejection murmur, heard best at the left lower sternal border, that is louder with Valsalva. Would raise concerns for HCM.        

Once a murmur is identified in a pediatric patient, a focused history and physical examination should be performed. Patients and parents should be asked about chest pain, fatigue, dyspnea on exertion, palpitations, or syncope. Newborns with a murmur should be assessed for difficulty feeding and cyanosis. Family history is also important to ask about since some heart defects are inherited.        

On physical examination, vitals should be obtained. In addition to cardiac auscultation, bilateral pulses should be palpated. Once innocent murmurs are ruled out, pathologic murmurs can be differentiated based on various characteristics. The first step is to assess the timing of the murmur and whether it occurs during systole, diastole, or is continuous.         

Systolic murmurs are further differentiated by whether they are systolic ejection murmurs (e.g., aortic stenosis and HCM), holosystolic murmurs (e.g., ventricular septal defect and mitral regurgitation), or murmurs occurring in late systole (e.g., mitral valve prolapse). Diastolic murmurs are further differentiated by whether they occur in early diastole (e.g., aortic regurgitation and pulmonic regurgitation) or mid-to-late diastole (e.g., mitral stenosis and tricuspid stenosis). If a continuous murmur is heard, a patent ductus arteriosus should be suspected.        

Once the timing of the murmur is identified, other characteristics such as where the murmur is best heard, radiation, quality of the murmur, and the effect of positional changes (e.g., supine vs. prone) can add information to help determine the type of murmur.   

Option Analysis

✅ Systolic ejection murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border, that is louder with Valsalva:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Holosystolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border:
Incorrect: A holosystolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border is consistent with a ventricular septal defect (VSD). This patient’s grandfather likely had hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), and the associated murmur is a systolic ejection murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border that is louder with Valsalva. 
❌ Early diastolic, high-pitched, blowing murmur heard best at the left sternal border:
Incorrect: An early diastolic, high-pitched, blowing murmur heard best at the left sternal border is consistent with aortic regurgitation (AR). This patient’s grandfather likely had hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), and the associated murmur is a systolic ejection murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border that is louder with Valsalva. 
❌ Continuous murmur heard below the clavicles that disappears when supine:
Incorrect: A continuous murmur heard below the clavicles that disappears when the patient is supine is consistent with a venous hum. This patient’s grandfather likely died of sudden cardiac death from hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). The associated murmur is a systolic ejection murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border that is louder with Valsalva. 
❌ Blowing systolic ejection murmur heard best at the left upper sternal border that radiates to the back:
Incorrect: A blowing systolic ejection murmur heard best at the left upper sternal border that radiates to the back is consistent with peripheral pulmonary stenosis (PPS). This patient’s grandfather likely died of sudden cardiac death from hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). The associated murmur is a systolic ejection murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border that is louder with valsalva.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old girl presents to the pediatrician for a well-child visit. Past medical history is significant for celiac disease. She tries to follow a gluten-free diet but occasionally ingests gluten-containing foods. She reports intermittent abdominal pain and diarrhea but does not have systemic symptoms. There is no significant family history. Body mass index (BMI) is in the 45th percentile. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 120/82 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is well-appearing. Cardiopulmonary exam is normal, and capillary refill is < 2 seconds. The abdomen is soft, nontender, nondistended, with normoactive bowel sounds. Results of lab work are shown below. In addition to an albumin level, what lab test should be ordered next? 

 Laboratory value     Result    
 Complete blood count    
 Hemoglobin     12.7 g/dL   
 Hematocrit     38.1%   
 Leukocyte count     8,200/mm3   
 Platelet count     215,000/mm3   
 Serum chemistry         
 Sodium      137 mEq/L    
 Potassium      3.5 mEq/L    
 Chloride      98 mEq/L    
 Bicarbonate     21 mEq/L    
 Blood urea nitrogen      16 mg/dL    
 Creatinine     1.1 mg/dL    
 Glucose     98 mg/dL    
 Calcium     7.8 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient has poorly controlled celiac disease and blood work reveals hypocalcemia. Celiac disease and chronic diarrhea can impair absorption of magnesium, resulting in hypomagnesemia and subsequent hypocalcemia. The next step in evaluating the etiology of hypocalcemia in this patient is to order albumin and magnesium levels.       

When lab work indicates hypocalcemia, the first step is to check serum albumin and magnesium levels. If the albumin is normal and the magnesium is low, then hypocalcemia is due to magnesium deficiency. A corrected serum calcium level should be calculated if the albumin is low, and the magnesium is normal. A normal corrected serum calcium would indicate pseudohypocalcemia. However, a low corrected serum calcium confirms true hypocalcemia, and further evaluation should be performed.       

Hypocalcemia within the first four days of life is consistent with early-onset neonatal hypocalcemia, whereas newborns over four days with hypocalcemia should be evaluated for DiGeorge syndrome. For older children presenting with hypocalcemia, recommended lab workup includes a basic metabolic panel, serum phosphate, parathyroid hormone (PTH), calcidiol (25-OH vitamin D), calcitriol (1,25(OH)2 vitamin D), and urine calcium: creatinine ratio. An elevated urine calcium: creatinine ratio is suggestive of autosomal dominant hypocalcemia type I. PTH will be low in primary hypoparathyroidism and elevated in secondary hypoparathyroidism. Checking vitamin D and renal function will help differentiate renal failure, vitamin D-dependent rickets type I, vitamin D deficiency, and pseudohypoparathyroidism.   

Option Analysis

✅ Magnesium:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Parathyroid hormone (PTH):
Incorrect: This patient has hypocalcemia. The first step in the evaluation of hypocalcemia is to check albumin and magnesium levels to exclude magnesium deficiency and pseudohypocalcemia. Once these are ruled out, a PTH level should be obtained to assess for primary hypoparathyroidism and secondary hyperparathyroidism. 
❌ Calcidiol (25-OH vitamin D):
Incorrect: This patient has hypocalcemia. The first step in the evaluation of hypocalcemia is to check albumin and magnesium levels to exclude magnesium deficiency and pseudohypocalcemia. Once these are ruled out, PTH, calcidiol and calcitriol levels and urine calcium: creatinine ratio should be obtained to help diagnose the underlying cause of hypocalcemia. 
❌ Calcitriol (1,25(OH)2 vitamin D):
Incorrect: This patient has hypocalcemia. The first step in the evaluation of hypocalcemia is to check albumin and magnesium levels to exclude magnesium deficiency and pseudohypocalcemia. Once these are ruled out, PTH, calcidiol and calcitriol levels and urine calcium: creatinine ratio should be obtained to help diagnose the underlying cause of hypocalcemia. 
❌ Urine calcium: creatinine ratio:
Incorrect: This patient has hypocalcemia. The first step in the evaluation of hypocalcemia is to check albumin and magnesium levels to exclude magnesium deficiency and pseudohypocalcemia. Once these are ruled out, a urine calcium: creatinine ratio should be obtained, which will be elevated in autosomal dominant hypocalcemia type 1.

questions.text: A 7-day-old boy has been in the neonatal intensive care unit since delivery due to transitional increased work of breathing and feeding difficulties. Prenatally, the patient was diagnosed with tetralogy of Fallot. The pregnancy and delivery were otherwise uncomplicated. The patient was born at 40 weeks of gestation, weight is in the 8th percentile, length is in the 6th percentile, and head circumference is in the 11th percentile. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 145/min, respirations are 38/min, blood pressure is 68/48 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the infant appears jittery. The anterior fontanelle is open and flat, ears are low-set and posteriorly rotated, eyes are widely spaced, and there is a cleft palate. There is a 3/6 systolic ejection murmur heard best at the left upper sternal border. Pulses are 2+. Laboratory work is notable for a calcium level of 6.2 mg/dL. Which of the following tests will confirm the underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has been diagnosed with tetralogy of Fallot and a cleft palate. In addition, the patient is jittery, has feeding difficulties, and has low-set posteriorly rotated ears and widely spaced eyes on physical examination. Lab work is pertinent for hypocalcemia. These findings are consistent with DiGeorge syndrome, which is caused by a 22q11.2 deletion. The diagnosis can be confirmed using fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) testing.       

Diagnosis of various causes of hypocalcemia requires obtaining a thorough history, physical examination, lab work, and occasionally genetic testing. Once hypocalcemia is identified, an albumin level and calculation of corrected calcium level will differentiate pseudohypocalcemia from true hypocalcemia. Early-onset neonatal hypocalcemia is diagnosed clinically when a patient has hypocalcemia at < 4 days of age and calcium levels improve with supplementation.        

In autosomal dominant hypocalcemia type I, the urine calcium: creatinine ratio is elevated. This is confirmed with genetic testing and identification of a gain-of-function mutation of the calcium-sending receptor (CaSR). Vitamin D-dependent rickets type I and pseudohypoparathyroidism are also diagnosed by genetic testing by evaluating for a CYP mutation and GNAS mutation, respectively.    

Option Analysis

✅ Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) for 22q11.2:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Karyotype:
Incorrect: This patient’s physical examination and laboratory findings (specifically hypocalcemia) are consistent with DiGeorge syndrome, which can be diagnosed with a FISH test for the 22q11.2 deletion. A karyotype evaluates abnormalities in chromosomal structure or number, such as those seen with trisomy 21 or Klinefelter syndrome. 
❌ Genetic mutation for CHD7:
Incorrect: This patient’s physical examination and laboratory findings (specifically hypocalcemia) are consistent with DiGeorge syndrome, which can be diagnosed with a FISH test for the 22q11.2 deletion. CHARGE (coloboma, heart defects, atresia of choanae, retardation of growth, genital underdevelopment, ear abnormalities) syndrome is associated with a mutation of the CHD7 gene. While these two conditions can have similar clinical features, this patient’s examination is more consistent with DiGeorge syndrome.  
❌ Parathyroid hormone (PTH) and vitamin D :
Incorrect: This patient’s physical examination and laboratory findings (specifically hypocalcemia) are consistent with DiGeorge syndrome, which can be diagnosed with a FISH test for the 22q11.2 deletion. While a PTH level would likely indicate hypoparathyroidism in this patient, this is related to the patient’s DiGeorge syndrome. 
❌ Urine calcium: creatinine ratio:
Incorrect: This patient’s physical examination and laboratory findings (specifically hypocalcemia) are consistent with DiGeorge syndrome which can be diagnosed with a FISH test for the 22q11.2 deletion. A urine calcium: creatinine ratio will be elevated in autosomal dominant hypocalcemia type I, which is not associated with the physical examination findings noted for this patient.

questions.text: A 1-month-old female infant is evaluated in the clinic during a 1-month-old well check. The infant is breastfed, but the parents note that she tires easily and sweats while feeding. She feeds 8-10 times a day, five minutes on each side, and latches well. There is no history of choking, coughing with feeding, diarrhea, or vomiting. Parents report frequent spit-ups that are nonbloody, nonbilious, not projectile and do not cause the infant discomfort. There is appropriate urine output and 6-8 diapers with stool every day. There is an older sibling at home who attends daycare and is frequently sick. The infant was born at full term with no complications during pregnancy or delivery. At birth, weight, length, and head circumference were at the 30th percentile. Temperature is 37° C (98.6° F), pulse is 180/min, respirations are 45/min, blood pressure is 82/45 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Weight and height are at less than the 5<sup>th</sup> percentile. Head circumference is at the 25<sup>th</sup> percentile. Physical examination reveals a calm infant in mild respiratory distress. No dysmorphic features are noted. There is tachypnea and faint diffuse crackles are appreciated on lung examination. Cardiac examination reveals a grade 2/6 holosystolic murmur heard best at the left sternal border. No hepatosplenomegaly is appreciated. The patient is sent to the Emergency Department. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This 1-month-old infant presents with growth faltering as diagnosed by a weight-for-age more than 2 standard deviations below the mean for age and biological sex. History is pertinent for tiring and sweating with feeding. On physical examination, there is tachycardia, tachypnea, crackles, and a holosystolic murmur. This patient’s growth faltering is most likely secondary to congenital heart disease, specifically a ventricular septal defect causing mild heart failure. Obtaining an echocardiogram is the best next step in the evaluation.

Growth faltering refers to the inability to gain or maintain adequate weight. It can result from underlying conditions associated with increased metabolic requirements like congenital heart disease, malabsorption, or inadequate caloric intake. When a pediatric patient presents with growth faltering, obtaining measurements of weight and height or length and plotting results on a standardized growth chart is the first step. If the patient’s weight-for-age or BMI is more than 2 standard deviations below the mean for age and biological sex or if the weight-for-age has crossed 2 major percentile lines, growth faltering is diagnosed.

A focused history and physical exam should assess for Chronic health conditions such as congenital heart diseases which can lead to growth faltering due to increased energy expenditure. Patients with Congenital heart diseases can present with increased work of breathing, sweating, or cyanosis with feeding. Physical exam may reveal findings such as a heart murmur and signs of congestive heart failure (e.g., hepatomegaly, tachypnea, and tachycardia). If findings are suggestive of congenital heart disease, an echocardiogram should be performed to confirm the diagnosis.

Option Analysis

✅ Echocardiogram  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Chest radiograph :
Incorrect: This patient has tachypnea and crackles on pulmonary examination, but these findings are secondary to heart failure. Although a chest radiograph can assess for cardiomegaly and pulmonary congestion, an echocardiogram is the best next step in the evaluation of this patient’s growth faltering. It will provide information about the underlying heart defect and degree of heart failure. 
❌ Abdominal ultrasound  :
Incorrect: This patient is spitting up frequently but there are no red flags. She is a “happy spitter,” and no abdominal imaging is necessary. The tiring and sweating with feeding, tachypnea, crackles on pulmonary examination, and the presence of a holosystolic murmur make mild heart failure secondary to a ventricular septal defect the most likely diagnosis. This is best evaluated with an echocardiogram. 
❌ Stool studies :
Incorrect: This patient is having 6-8 stools a day which is normal for a 1-month-old. No further evaluation of the stools is necessary. The tiring and sweating with feeding, tachypnea, crackles on pulmonary examination, and holosystolic murmur make mild heart failure secondary to a ventricular septal defect the most likely diagnosis. This is best evaluated with an echocardiogram. 
❌ Evaluation of the caloric value of breastmilk :
Incorrect: Although the number of calories in breast milk varies per person there are ways to measure this value. However, this patient has mild heart failure, as evidenced by tiring and sweating with feeding, tachypnea, crackles on pulmonary examination, and the presence of a holosystolic murmur.  An echocardiogram is the best next step in management.

questions.text:
A 5-day-old female neonate is brought to the clinic for worsening jaundice. She was delivered at 37 weeks' gestation following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. Birth weight was 3400 grams. The infant initially had difficulty latching but subsequently appeared to nurse adequately, and she was discharged home after two days of life. The mother reports she has not been nursing well and has become increasingly sleepy with less frequent wet diapers and stools. There have been three wet diapers in the last 24 hours. She has not had vomiting, diarrhea, bloody stools, or seizures. Temperature is 37° C (98.6° F), pulse is 171/min, respirations are 32/min, blood pressure is 74/46 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Current weight is 3000 grams. Examination reveals scleral icterus, jaundice to the umbilicus, and dry mucous membranes. The anterior fontanelle is open and mildly sunken. There are no dysmorphic features. Cardiac exam is significant for tachycardic and a flow murmur. Respiratory and abdominal exams are normal. Labs are shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?   

 Laboratory value     Results     
 Total bilirubin     15 mg/dL    
 Conjugated bilirubin      1 mg/dL    
 Aspartate aminotransferase (AST)     50 U/L    
 Alanine aminotransferase (ALT)     25 U/L      
 Reticulocytes      0.7%    
 Direct antiglobulin test (DAT)     Negative

choices.text: Increase feeding frequency and supplement with formula after each feed

questions.solution:
This newborn presents with scleral icterus and jaundice at five days of life. Breastfeeding has been challenging, and the infant has dry mucus membranes, decreased urine output, and mildly sunken fontanelle consistent with mild dehydration. Labs confirm unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that is well below light level (~20mg/dL) for phototherapy. This infant’s hyperbilirubinemia is most likely due to breastfeeding (failure) jaundice which is due to suboptimal fluid and caloric intake during the first seven days of life. Increasing the feeding frequency and supplementing feeds with either expressed breast milk or formula. This is the recommended treatment.       

Jaundice is a yellowish discoloration of the skin and sclerae caused by an abnormality of bilirubin metabolism or excretion. Bilirubin can be unconjugated or conjugated.    Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia is often caused by breastfeeding jaundice, breastmilk jaundice, hemoglobinopathies, RBC membranopathies, and RBC enzyme defects. Breastfeeding jaundice is seen in breastfed infants during the first week of life due to inadequate breast milk intake, decreased stooling, and dehydration. The decreased breast milk intake causes decreased stooling, which leads to increased enterohepatic circulation of bilirubin. Physical exam reveals significant weight loss, jaundice, and dry mucous membranes.  

Option Analysis

✅ Increase feeding frequency and supplement with formula after each feed :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Switch to formula :
Incorrect: Stopping breastfeeding is not necessary as there are no clear contraindications such as galactosemia, maternal infection with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), or active maternal tuberculosis. The breast-feeding frequency should be increased and supplementation with expressed mild or formula should be provided.  
❌ Refer to pediatric gastroenterology :
Incorrect: patients with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and findings on abdominal ultrasound consistent with cholestasis, should be referred to pediatric gastroenterology. This infant has unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia secondary to breastfeeding jaundice which requires increasing feeding frequency and supplementation with expressed milk or formula. 
❌ Provide phototherapy  :
Incorrect: This infant is 5 days old with a total bilirubin of 15 which is well below the phototherapy threshold. This infant has unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia secondary to breastfeeding jaundice which requires increased feeding frequency and supplementation with expressed breast milk or formula. 
❌ Order a peripheral smear :
Incorrect: A peripheral smear is used to assess red blood cell morphology. It can identify various hemoglobinopathies and red blood cell membranopathies. This infant’s clinical picture is consistent with breastfeeding jaundice which requires increasing the feeding frequency and supplementation with expressed breast milk or formula.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy with a past medical history of asthma presents to the emergency department for evaluation of shortness of breath. He was playing at a party and started wheezing. The family recently moved to town and has not refilled his asthma medication. The patient has not had fever, congestion, or rhinorrhea. He has no surgical history, and family history is positive for asthma. Temperature is 37° C (98.6° F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 45/min, blood pressure is 92/53 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 80% on room air. Subcostal retractions are noted with diffuse expiratory wheezing. Heart sounds are normal. Chest X-ray shows hyperinflation. Which of the following diagnostic studies should be obtained next?
questions.solution:
This child presents with signs of acute respiratory distress secondary to acute asthma exacerbation. Obtaining an arterial blood gas analysis is the most appropriate next step to assess the severity of respiratory compromise and degree of compensation which can guide further management.

Respiratory failure can be classified as hypoxemic respiratory failure, (e.g. lung failure), and hypercapnic respiratory failure, (respiratory pump failure). In a patient with suspected respiratory failure, an arterial blood gas analysis (ABG) is the initial diagnostic test of choice to assess acid-base balance, oxygenation, and carbon dioxide retention.

If the ABG reveals an arterial partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) < 60 mmHg, the patient has hypoxemic respiratory failure. This often results from a mismatch in alveolar ventilation and perfusion (V/Q mismatch) such as in patients with asthma, interstitial edema or fibrosis, atelectasis, and pneumonia. If the ABG reveals an arterial partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) > 50 mmHg, this indicates hypercapnic respiratory failure. This condition is characterized by inadequate ventilation and carbon dioxide retention. Hypoxemic and hypercapnic respiratory failure often occur together as many disease processes induce physiologic changes that impair both oxygenation and ventilation. In these cases, the ABG will demonstrate both decreased PaO2 and increased PaCO2.

Option Analysis

✅ Arterial blood gas:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Blood culture:
Incorrect: Blood cultures are used to diagnose sepsis. This patient’s presentation is consistent with respiratory distress secondary to an acute asthma exacerbation rather than an infectious process.
❌ Bronchoscopy :
Incorrect: Bronchoscopy is commonly utilized in cases of persistent stridor or wheezing. It is not typically used in unstable patients with asthma exacerbations. This patient’s presentation is consistent with respiratory distress secondary to an acute asthma exacerbation, and an arterial blood gas should be performed initially.
❌ Pulmonary function test:
Incorrect: Pulmonary function testing helps to determine the characteristics of an underlying respiratory disease. This test is not performed when a patient is unstable. This patient’s presentation is consistent with respiratory distress secondary to acute asthma exacerbation, and an arterial blood gas should be performed.
❌ Sweat chloride test:
Incorrect: Sweat chloride testing is commonly used to confirm the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis. This patient’s presentation is consistent with respiratory distress secondary to acute asthma exacerbation.

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant boy presents with one week of fever, rhinorrhea, and cough. Parents report decreased feeding over the last week with intermittent shortness of breath. The infant was born at full term without complications during pregnancy or delivery. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 190/min, respirations are 65/min, blood pressure is 102/55 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 83% on room air. Intercostal and subcostal retractions are noted on physical exams. Chest auscultation reveals bilateral coarse breath sounds. Heart sounds are normal. The patient is placed on low flow supplemental oxygen via nasal cannula and oxygen saturation increases to 88% on 2 liters with persistent increased work of breathing. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This infant presents with respiratory failure likely due to acute bronchiolitis. He continues to have increased work of breathing despite treatment with low flow oxygen via nasal cannula. High-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy is the recommended next step in management.

Patients with mild hypoxemic respiratory failure may improve with supplemental oxygen administration alone, which is minimally invasive and well tolerated. Depending on the amount of support needed, various methods of delivery are available, including low- or high-flow nasal cannula or a non-rebreather mask. A high flow nasal cannula can provide gas flow rates up to 60 liters per minute and FiO2 from 21% to 100%. Limitations of a nasal cannula include the risk of ineffective sealing leading to leaking of air and loss of the positive airway pressure effect.

Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) provides a constant level of positive airway pressure, which increases functional residual capacity, prevents small airway collapse, and improves alveolar aeration. CPAP is most useful for treating hypoxemic respiratory failure. Biphasic positive airway pressure (BiPAP) provides positive airway pressure during exhalation and additional positive pressure during inspiration, which decreases the work of breathing. BiPAP can be used in both hypoxemic and hypercapnic respiratory failure. If the patient’s respiratory failure persists despite these interventions, endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation are indicated. Other indications for mechanical ventilation include an inability to protect the airway, altered mental status, severe hemodynamic instability, midfacial anomalies, and facial trauma.

Option Analysis

❌ Bronchoscopy  :
Incorrect: Bronchoscopy can be used to diagnose causes of stridor and respiratory distress; however, this patient has findings consistent with bronchiolitis with continued increased work of breathing despite low flow oxygen via nasal canula. He should be switched to a high flow nasal canula.
❌ Chest tube:
Incorrect: Chest tube placement can provide relief for patients with hemothorax, pneumothorax, and pleural effusions. This patient has findings consistent with bronchiolitis with continued increased work of breathing despite low flow oxygen via nasal canula. He should be switched to a high flow nasal canula.
✅ High flow nasal cannula :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Intravenous antibiotics:
Incorrect: Intravenous antibiotics are appropriate to treat bacterial pneumonia. However, this patient has findings consistent with bronchiolitis, which is typically viral and may require treatment with supplemental oxygen.
❌ Echocardiogram  :
Incorrect: Echocardiogram can be used to diagnose cardiac causes of respiratory distress. This patient has findings consistent with bronchiolitis with continued increased work of breathing despite low flow oxygen via nasal canula. He should be switched to a high flow nasal canula.

questions.text:
A 21-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents for evaluation of fever and cough for one week. Parents report the fever has not resolved, and the cough has worsened over the course of one week. Temperature is 39.2°C (102.6°F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 44/min, blood pressure is 85/39 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. On physical exam, the patient is responsive to verbal and tactile stimulation. There are no signs of respiratory distress. Capillary refill is less than two seconds. No cervical lymphadenopathy is present. The patient's skin is warm and flushed and mucous membranes are moist. The neck is supple with a full range of motion without signs of meningismus or nuchal rigidity. On pulmonary examination, there are rales and rhonchi over the right lower and middle lobes. Peripheral pulses are bounding. Heart sounds are normal without murmurs or gallops. Abdominal exam is unremarkable. Lab results are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation? 

 Laboratory value      Results      
 White blood cells       22,000 /μL     
 Neutrophils       88%     
 Lymphocytes       12%     
 Hemoglobin       12.4 g/dL     
 Platelets       90,000/μL     
 CRP      160 mg/mL     
 Lactate       3.5 Mmol/L
questions.solution:
This infant presents with fever and cough and findings consistent with pneumonia and warm shock. He has septic shock most likely secondary to bacterial infection.         

There are four main categories of shock: distributive, hypovolemic, cardiogenic, and obstructive. Distributive shock includes septic, anaphylactic, and neurogenic shock and results from peripheral vasodilation and increased but inadequate cardiac output. Distributive shock is typically considered a warm shock.       

Sepsis results from a suspected or proven infectious etiology, and clinical deterioration leads to septic shock, which may result in multi-organ dysfunction and mortality. Clinical signs of septic shock include unstable temperatures (hyperthermia or hypothermia), tachycardia, tachypnea, hypotension, and signs of infection (e.g. abnormal lung findings consistent with pneumonia in this patient). When septic shock is suspected, complete blood count (CBC), lactate, and inflammatory markers (i.e., C-reactive protein (CRP), erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), and procalcitonin level) should be ordered. Blood and urine cultures should be drawn, and cerebrospinal fluid cultures should possibly be obtained via lumbar puncture. Lab results typically reveal elevated white blood cell count and low platelets in combination with an elevated lactate and increased inflammatory markers. Cultures might reveal a causative pathogen.        

The other types of distributive shock are anaphylactic shock and neurogenic shock. Patients with anaphylactic shock present after exposure to an allergen with itching, rash, and shortness of breath, and physical examination may reveal urticaria, angioedema, wheezing, or stridor. With neurogenic shock, patients often have a history of trauma with a brain or spinal cord injury or recent administration of spinal or epidural anesthesia. Physical exam reveals bradycardia, paralysis, or paresis.   

Option Analysis

❌ Cardiogenic shock  :
Incorrect: Patients with cardiogenic shock present with signs of cold shock, including cold and clammy skin, delayed capillary refill, diminished peripheral pulses, and a narrow pulse pressure. The findings in this patient are more consistent with warm shock due to septic shock.  
❌ Hypovolemic shock  :
Incorrect: Patients with hypovolemic shock typically have a history of volume loss and present with signs of cold shock. This patient has signs of warm shock, making hypovolemic shock an unlikely diagnosis. His signs of warm shock as well as fever, cough, and abnormal pulmonary findings make septic shock from pneumonia likely. 
❌ Neurogenic shock  :
Incorrect: Patients presenting with neurogenic shock often have had brain or spinal cord injury. Physical exam would reveal bradycardia, paralysis, or paresis. This patient, without signs of neurologic dysfunction and with signs of warm shock as well as fever, cough, and abnormal pulmonary findings, most likely has septic shock from underlying pneumonia. 
❌ Anaphylactic shock  :
Incorrect: Patients with anaphylactic shock often have a history of exposure to an allergen, followed by itching, rash, and shortness of breath. Physical examination often shows urticaria, angioedema, or wheezing. This patient has signs of warm shock as well as fever, cough, and abnormal pulmonary findings, which make septic shock from pneumonia likely. 
✅ Septic shock :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 4-day-old newborn is in the neonatal intensive care unit for persistent hypoglycemia. Pregnancy and delivery were unremarkable. There was no maternal history of gestational diabetes. The infant was born at full term. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 173/min, respiration is 37/min, blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Height and weight are at the 25<sup>th</sup> percentile. On physical exam, a cleft palate is noted. Genital exam reveals microphallus. Abdomen is soft and nontender without organomegaly. The cardiopulmonary exam is unremarkable. The blood glucose level is 35 mg/dL, and serum bicarbonate is 22 mEq/L. Which of the following additional laboratory findings would be expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has a cleft palate, microphallus, and hypoglycemia without metabolic acidosis. These findings are consistent with congenital hypopituitarism. A low cortisol level is expected in patients with congenital hypopituitarism, among other hormonal deficiencies.

Congenital hypopituitarism results in a deficiency of one or more pituitary hormones that may include adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH), and growth hormone (GH). Congenital hypopituitarism should be suspected in neonates presenting with hypoglycemia and midline defects, such as cleft lip and palate, conjugated jaundice or prolonged unconjugated jaundice, poor growth, and microphallus.

To help differentiate the etiology of hypoglycemia in the absence of metabolic acidosis, features of hypopituitarism should be assessed. If present, as in this patient, hormonal levels such as insulin-like growth factor -1 (IGF-1) and cortisol levels should be checked. Low levels of IGF-1 and cortisol are suggestive of congenital hypopituitarism. Provocative tests of both GH and ACTH secretion may be necessary to confirm the respective hormone deficiencies. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain is necessary to evaluate for a pituitary defect. Inadequate hormone response to stimulation along with MRI findings demonstrating a pituitary defect, such as an absent septum pellucidum, confirms congenital hypopituitarism.

Option Analysis

❌ High serum insulin:
Incorrect: High serum insulin levels in a 4-day-old suggest hyperinsulinism, which can be associated with a history of maternal diabetes or congenital hyperinsulinism. This patient’s hypoglycemia, midline defect, and microphallus are consistent with congenital hypopituitarism, which is associated with low cortisol, among other hormonal deficiencies.
❌ High adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH):
Incorrect: High ACTH can cause Cushing syndrome which presents with hypertension, hyperglycemia, and a moon-shaped face, which are not seen in this patient. This patient’s hypoglycemia, midline defect, and microphallus are consistent with congenital hypopituitarism, which would result in low ACTH (and subsequently low cortisol), among other hormonal deficiencies.
✅ Low cortisol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Low free fatty acids:
Incorrect: Laboratory findings of low free fatty acids with hypoglycemia and the absence of metabolic acidosis suggest hyperinsulinism; however, this patient's physical features and laboratory results are more consistent with congenital hypopituitarism, which is associated with low cortisol, among other hormonal deficiencies.
❌ High free thyroxine :
Incorrect: High free thyroxine is found in hyperthyroidism. This patient’s hypoglycemia, midline defect, and microphallus are consistent with congenital hypopituitarism which is associated with hypothyroidism, and this patient would likely have a low free thyroxine in addition to low cortisol and other hormonal deficiencies.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought by his parent to the pediatrician for evaluation of poor school performance and disruptive behavior over the past year. His parent reports that he frequently fidgets, interrupts others, and blurts out answers during class. He has difficulty completing homework and chores, often leaving tasks unfinished. His classmates have teased him about these behaviors. He does not have any recent emotional or physical stressors, and he is otherwise healthy. The patient has no specific complaints and simply says he “wants to play video games.” Vital signs are within normal limits, and the physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following historical findings is most strongly associated with this patient’s likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Biological father with history of alcohol-use disorder
Brother with a history of depression
Mother with a history of smoking cigarettes

questions.solution:
This 8-year-old patient presents with a one-year history of hyperactivity/impulsivity and inattention, which strongly supports a diagnosis of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). A known risk factor for developing this condition is a history of prematurity.

ADHD is a common neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by a history of excessive levels of inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity. As a result, children with ADHD often experience impaired social, emotional, and academic functioning, and many exhibit poor impulse control. The patient’s history may reveal several risk factors including prematurity, low birth weight, adverse childhood experiences, a family history of ADHD, or syndromes such as fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS) or fragile X syndrome. Physical examination is typically unremarkable.

Option Analysis

✅ History of prematurity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Biological father with history of alcohol-use disorder:
Incorrect: Alcohol use disorder in a patient’s biological father is not an independent risk factor for developing attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). While fetal alcohol syndrome has been associated with ADHD, this patient has no phenotypic features of this condition.
❌ Brother with a history of depression:
Incorrect: A sibling with depression does not independently predict the risk of developing attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). While psychosocial stressors might increase the risk of developing ADHD, this vignette does not indicate that such stressors are present for this patient.
❌ Mother with a history of smoking cigarettes:
Incorrect: Prenatal tobacco exposure has been associated with the development of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). However, it remains uncertain whether this association is causal or primarily mediated by environmental or genetic confounders. In cases of smoking that occur outside of pregnancy, the association is even less robust.
❌ History of recurrent streptococcal pharyngitis:
Incorrect: Streptococcal pharyngitis can increase the risk of developing pediatric autoimmune neuropsychiatric disorders associated with streptococcal infections (PANDAS), a condition characterized by obsessive-compulsive or tic disorder traits. It is not a risk factor for the development of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is evaluated for difficulty walking and frequent falls. She has no fever, cough, difficulty breathing, neck rigidity, convulsions, blurring of vision, or sensory deficits. Her past medical history is significant for delayed motor milestones and recurrent pneumonia. The patient’s temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Ophthalmologic examination reveals abnormal eye movements and tortuous, dilated blood vessels on the bulbar conjunctivae. Physical examination shows hypotonia in all four limbs and tremors in both hands. Deep tendon reflexes are absent, with preserved superficial reflexes. She has a wide-based gait. Which of the following would most likely help confirm the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Oculocutaneous telangiectasia. Image courtesy of " target="_blank">Wikimedia Commons. 

This 6-year-old girl presents with ataxia, oculocutaneous telangiectasia, and oculomotor apraxia; she most likely has ataxia telangiectasia. Genetic testing can help confirm the diagnosis.       

Ataxia telangiectasia is an autosomal recessive neurocutaneous disorder caused by mutations in the ataxia-telangiectasia mutated (ATM) gene on chromosome 11q22-23. Patients often experience recurrent sinopulmonary infections (e.g. pneumonia) and malignancies, such as acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL) and lymphoma. Many patients present with developmental delay and progressive ataxia, which eventually leads to loss of ambulatory function.       

Patients with neurocutaneous syndromes should first be evaluated based on skin lesion morphology. Ataxia telangiectasia is diagnosed in a patient when there is oculocutaneous telangiectasias and telangiectasias of the nasal bridge and ears. Other classic skin lesions in neurocutaneous syndromes include the café-au-lait spots (hyperpigmented macules) seen in neurofibromatosis, the ash-leaf spots (hypopigmented lesions) seen in tuberous sclerosis complex, and the port-wine stain seen in Sturge-Weber syndrome.        

If truncal ataxia and oculomotor apraxia (the inability to coordinate head and eye movements while shifting gaze rapidly) are found, ataxia telangiectasia is likely. Labs may demonstrate decreased lymphocyte and immunoglobulin levels and elevated alpha-fetoprotein levels, while brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) shows cerebellar atrophy. These results are highly suggestive of ataxia telangiectasia, and the diagnosis can be confirmed with genetic testing detecting mutations in the ATM gene.    

Option Analysis

❌ Abdominal computed tomography (CT) scan  :
Incorrect: An abdominal CT scan is useful in determining associated tumors (such as pheochromocytoma, pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors, and renal cysts or carcinomas) seen in Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome. This patient’s findings of oculocutaneous telangiectasias and oculomotor apraxia are more consistent with ataxia telangiectasia, and an abdominal CT scan would not confirm this diagnosis.  
❌ Echocardiogram  :
Incorrect: Echocardiography is useful for evaluation of cardiac rhabdomyomas, which are seen in patients with tuberous sclerosis complex. This patient's presentation is more consistent with ataxia telangiectasia, so an echocardiogram would not be helpful. 
✅ Genetic testing  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Renal ultrasound  :
Incorrect: A renal ultrasound is useful for evaluating renal cysts or carcinomas seen in patients with tuberous sclerosis complex and Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome, respectively. This patient's findings are more consistent with ataxia telangiectasia, and a renal ultrasound will not confirm the diagnosis. 
❌ Wood’s lamp exam of the skin  :
Incorrect: A Wood’s lamp exam is useful for evaluating ash-leaf spots seen in tuberous sclerosis complex. This patient's findings are more consistent with ataxia telangiectasia, making this test unnecessary.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the clinic with a three-day history of limping. Her parents report increased irritability and fatigue. She has no history of recent trauma but experienced an episode of pharyngitis one week ago that resolved without treatment. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg, heart rate is 98 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The right thigh is swollen and warm to the touch. A radiograph reveals a small area of localized soft tissue swelling at the metaphysis of the right femur. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) shows bone marrow edema. Blood cultures are pending, and laboratory tests reveal an elevated white blood cell count, C-reactive protein (CRP), and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). Which of the following would be expected on physical examination?

choices.text: Pain relief with passive movement of the limb
Diffuse lower extremity weakness and hyporeflexia
Well-demarcated, erythematous rash over the affected limb

questions.solution:
This 4-year-old girl presents with limping, irritability, and localized swelling and warmth of the right thigh. She is febrile and has elevated inflammatory markers. Radiography shows localized soft tissue swelling at the metaphysis of the right femur, and MRI reveals bone marrow edema. These findings are consistent with acute hematogenous osteomyelitis. The most supportive physical examination finding for this diagnosis is localized bony tenderness, rather than joint or soft tissue tenderness.        

In pediatric patients, osteomyelitis typically presents with fever, irritability, and a history of recent infection or trauma, although a clear preceding event may not always be identified. Affected children often exhibit limping, refusal to bear weight, or decreased use of the affected limb (pseudoparalysis), which may be the presenting symptom in nonverbal or younger patients. The physical examination commonly reveals localized swelling, warmth, tenderness, and sometimes erythema over the affected bone, with pain that persists even at rest. Osteomyelitis may also involve adjacent joints (septic arthritis) or present as a multifocal infection, necessitating a high index of suspicion for early diagnosis.   

Option Analysis

❌ Pain relief with passive movement of the limb:
Incorrect: This patient’s physical examination, laboratory findings, and imaging are consistent with osteomyelitis, which causes severe pain that worsens with both passive and active movement of the affected limb. 
✅ Localized bony tenderness:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Appreciable joint effusion:
Incorrect: An appreciable joint effusion is more characteristic of septic arthritis, although in cases of hip involvement, the effusion might not be as apparent on physical exam. Septic arthritis of the hip often presents with severe pain with passive motion and when the hip is held in a flexed, externally rotated position. This patient’s imaging findings of bone marrow edema are more consistent with osteomyelitis, where localized bony tenderness is expected. 
❌ Diffuse lower extremity weakness and hyporeflexia:
Incorrect: Diffuse lower extremity weakness and hyporeflexia suggest a neurologic disorder, such as transverse myelitis or Guillain-Barré syndrome, which would not typically cause localized tenderness or warmth. This patient’s findings are consistent with osteomyelitis, and localized bony tenderness would be expected on examination. 
❌ Well-demarcated, erythematous rash over the affected limb :
Incorrect: A well-demarcated, erythematous rash over the affected limb is more characteristic of cellulitis, a soft tissue infection. This patient’s findings are more consistent with osteomyelitis, and localized bony tenderness would be expected on examination.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with fever and worsening right leg pain for the past five days. Her parent reports that she fell off her bicycle one week ago, scraping her right leg, but they did not seek medical attention at the time. Since then, she has been increasingly irritable, refusing to bear weight, and experiencing persistent leg pain even at rest. The patient’s temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), blood pressure is 105/65 mmHg, heart rate is 135 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The right lower leg is swollen, warm, and tender to palpation, with limited range of motion due to pain. A scab is present over the right shin. Laboratory results are shown below. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the right leg reveals bone marrow edema and a subperiosteal abscess measuring 3.5 cm in diameter. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 

 Laboratory Test     Result    
 White blood cell count     19,200/mm³   
 Hemoglobin     12.0 g/dL   
 Platelets     450,000/mm³   
 C-reactive protein (CRP)     14.8 mg/dL   
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)     72 mm/hr

choices.text: Urgent surgical consultation for debridement and initiation of intravenous antibiotics
Needle aspiration of the abscess and delay antibiotics until culture results return
Empiric intravenous antibiotics with repeat MRI in 5–7 days to assess response
Empiric oral antibiotics for a 4–6-week course

questions.solution:
This 7-year-old girl with fever, worsening leg pain, refusal to bear weight, and a history of recent minor trauma presents with findings highly concerning for osteomyelitis with a subperiosteal abscess. An abscess larger than 2 cm requires urgent surgical drainage and intravenous (IV) antibiotics to prevent complications such as bone necrosis, chronic osteomyelitis, or sepsis.       

Treatment of pediatric osteomyelitis typically begins with empiric IV antibiotics targeting Staphylococcus aureus—the most common pathogen at this age—and other gram-positive organisms. Coverage is adjusted based on local methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) resistance patterns and culture results. If there is no abscess or the abscess is ≤ 2 cm, IV antibiotics alone are typically sufficient, with transition to oral antibiotics once clinical and laboratory improvement is observed. However, if MRI reveals an abscess > 2 cm or if there are red flags (e.g. no improvement after 48–72 hours of antimicrobial therapy), urgent surgical consultation for drainage or debridement is required to prevent progression to chronic osteomyelitis. In stable patients, initiation of empiric antibiotics will occasionally be delayed up to 24–48 hours until surgical intervention is performed and cultures are obtained. Serial measurements of inflammatory markers and clinical monitoring help guide treatment duration, and once improvement is noted, a prolonged course of oral antibiotics (typically 3–6 weeks) is necessary to ensure complete resolution.   



Option Analysis

❌ Empiric intravenous antibiotics with transition to oral antibiotics after 7 days :
Incorrect: Empiric intravenous antibiotics alone are appropriate for smaller abscesses (≤ 2 cm) or uncomplicated osteomyelitis but are insufficient for an abscess > 2 cm, which requires surgical drainage. Additionally, the transition to oral antibiotics is based on the patient’s clinical improvement rather than a fixed timeline. This patient requires surgical consultation for debridement in addition to initiation of empiric parenteral antibiotics.
✅ Urgent surgical consultation for debridement and initiation of intravenous antibiotics:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Needle aspiration of the abscess and delay antibiotics until culture results return:
Incorrect: Delaying antibiotics while awaiting culture results in osteomyelitis with a significant abscess can lead to systemic spread or chronic infection. Although cultures should be obtained as part of the workup for osteomyelitis, empiric intravenous antibiotics should begin immediately.  
❌ Empiric intravenous antibiotics with repeat MRI in 5–7 days to assess response:
Incorrect: Although intravenous antibiotics are necessary in this case, surgical drainage is also required for the 3.5 cm abscess because an untreated abscess that is > 2 cm may progress and cause bone necrosis or chronic osteomyelitis. 
❌ Empiric oral antibiotics for a 4–6-week course:
Incorrect: Oral antibiotics are not appropriate for the initial management of osteomyelitis. This condition requires intravenous antibiotics initially, with a transition to oral therapy only after clinical and laboratory improvement. Additionally, an abscess > 2 cm also necessitates surgical intervention.

questions.text: A baby boy is born at 41 weeks of gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery. Delivery was complicated by prolonged labor requiring forceps. Apgars were 6 and 9. On initial evaluation, the infant is 4150 grams. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 162/min, respirations are 40/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. The infant is crying vigorously, and the eyes remain shut. The anterior fontanelle is open and flat. There is a palpable concave depression over the right parietal region. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. Which of the following should be ordered next to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the head

questions.solution:
This newborn was born post-dates and is large for gestational age. The delivery was complicated by prolonged labor and the use of forceps. There is a depressed concave area over the right parietal region consistent with a depressed skull fracture. Neonates with depressed skull fractures often have associated intracranial hemorrhage; as such, they should be evaluated with computed tomography (CT) of the head.         

Newborn deliveries can result in head, nerve, skeletal, and soft tissue injuries; many of these injuries can be diagnosed clinically and do not require further evaluation. A cephalohematoma is a benign bleed under the scalp that typically resolves on its own. No imaging is needed. If there is concern for skull fracture or hemorrhage, a CT of the head is recommended. Occasionally, a head ultrasound is obtained to evaluate for intraventricular hemorrhage.        

Skeletal injuries, such as clavicle or long bone fractures, can be diagnosed with radiographs. Diagnosis of nerve palsies and soft tissue injuries can often be made clinically as long as there is no concern for underlying fracture.   

Option Analysis

✅ Computed tomography (CT) of the head:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Skull radiographs:
Incorrect: While radiographs evaluate bone, computed tomography (CT) of the head is the preferred imaging modality to evaluate a skull fracture since there can be an associated intracranial hemorrhage.  
❌ Cranial ultrasound:
Incorrect: Cranial ultrasound is often used to screen for intraventricular hemorrhage in premature infants. This patient has evidence of a depressed skull fracture for which computed tomography (CT) of the head is recommended. 
❌ No further imaging is required:
Incorrect: This patient has physical examination findings consistent with a depressed skull fracture. Because of the association with intracranial hemorrhage, a head CT should be performed. 
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the head:
Incorrect: MRI is best for soft tissue injuries. Computed tomography (CT) of the head is the preferred option to evaluate for a skull fracture and associated intracranial hemorrhage.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl presents to a clinic for evaluation of abdominal pain and intermittent bloody diarrhea for the past 3 months. The pain is described as generalized, severe, and crampy. The pain is not diurnal or related to food consumption. She reports sores in her mouth and unexpected weight loss over the past few months. The patient has not had a fever, rash, or mucoid stool. Menstrual cycles are regular, and she is not sexually active. Past medical, surgical, and family history are non-contributory. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, blood pressure is 117/76 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On exam, she has ulcers over the buccal mucosa and tender nodules over her legs as shown in the image below. The abdomen is tender about the umbilicus and over the left lower quadrant, and there is no distention or rigidity. Cardiopulmonary exam is within normal limits. Which of the following laboratory tests should be ordered as part of this patient’s workup? 



Reproduced from Wikimedia . Licensed under CC BY-SA 3.0
questions.solution:
This patient presents with chronic abdominal pain, bloody stools, and weight loss with physical exam findings of oral ulcers and erythema nodosum; this presentation is consistent with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), likely Crohn disease. A fecal calprotectin level and colonoscopy with biopsies should be ordered.       

Patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) report diffuse, crampy, periumbilical pain and fecal urgency. These symptoms are often associated with bloody stools, weight loss, or suboptimal weight gain. Some patients demonstrate extraintestinal manifestations like arthritis, episcleritis and uveitis, and skin nodules or ulcers. There may also be a family history of inflammatory bowel disease. Physical exam usually demonstrates abdominal tenderness, skin findings such as erythema nodosum (painful nodules over the tibia), and pyoderma gangrenousum (ulcerative lesions on the lower extremities).        

Patients with chronic abdominal pain, bloody stools, and weight loss should be evaluated for IBD. IBD is diagnosed in a patient with an elevated fecal calprotectin. To help differentiate the etiology of the IBD, a colonoscopy with biopsies should be performed. There are two types of IBD: ulcerative colitis (UC) and Crohn disease. UC shows a continuous pattern of edematous, erythematous, friable mucosa and erosions or ulcerations in the colon; biopsy reveals mucosal and submucosal inflammation with erosions, ulcerations, and crypt abscesses. In contrast, Crohn disease demonstrates cobblestoning, a discontinuous pattern of skip lesions, and linear serpiginous ulcerations. Crohn disease can involve the entire gastrointestinal tract, with rectal sparing. A biopsy will show transmural inflammation and granulomas.  

Option Analysis

❌ Esophageal pH monitoring :
Incorrect: Esophageal pH monitoring is a diagnostic test for gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), which presents with heartburn, anorexia, and epigastric/chest pain. The findings in this patient are more consistent with inflammatory bowel disease, and fecal calprotectin is a better test to confirm that diagnosis.  
✅ Fecal calprotectin :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) :
Incorrect: GGT is the test of choice for diagnosis of biliary disease, which presents with jaundice and abdominal pain. The findings in this patient are more consistent with inflammatory bowel disease. Fecal calprotectin is a better test to confirm the diagnosis. 
❌ Hydrogen breath test  :
Incorrect: The hydrogen breath test is useful for the diagnosis of lactase deficiency, which presents with abdominal pain, flatulence, and diarrhea related to consuming lactose-containing foods. The findings in this patient are more consistent with inflammatory bowel disease; fecal calprotectin is a better test to confirm that diagnosis.  
❌ Total IgA :
Incorrect: Total IgA is a diagnostic test for celiac disease, which presents with abdominal pain, diarrhea, and steatorrhea secondary to gluten sensitivity. The findings in this patient are more consistent with inflammatory bowel disease, and fecal calprotectin is a better test to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy was admitted to the intensive care unit for brain contusions and edema after being involved in a motor vehicle accident. Mental status has been within normal limits and stable; however, on day 2 of hospitalization, the patient has a new headache and feels weak. He vomited three times in the past hour and seems confused. He does not recognize his parents. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 115/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Urine output is 3 mL/kg/hr. On physical examination, the patient is not oriented to person, place, or time. Mucous membranes are moist, and capillary refill is 2 seconds. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are normal. Strength is 2/5 in all extremities. The patient suddenly develops generalized tonic-clonic seizures. Seizures are controlled with medications, and laboratory work is sent with the results shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

 Laboratory value Result
 Hemoglobin 12.5 g/dL
 Leukocyte count 7300/mm3
 Platelets 275,000/mm3
 Sodium 94 mEq/L
 Potassium 3.2 mEq/L
 Chloride 101 mEq/L
 Bicarbonate 22 mEq/L
 Blood urea nitrogen 15 mg/dL
 Creatinine 0.5 mg/dL
 Glucose 99 mg/dL

choices.text: Intravenous fluids given at a slow rate
Measurement of serum and urine osmolality
Observation and measurement of sodium level in 1 hour

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of head trauma presents with the acute onset of headache, confusion, vomiting, generalized weakness and polyuria and has seizures secondary to euvolemic hyponatremia. Patients with severe symptoms secondary to hyponatremia (e.g. seizures), regardless of the etiology, should be given a bolus of hypertonic saline to correct the serum sodium and prevent seizures.

Patients with euvolemic hyponatremia may have conditions affecting the central nervous system, such as meningitis, brain tumors or trauma, or recent brain surgery. The history of head trauma and polyuria in this case increases the possibility of cerebral salt wasting. Symptoms of hyponatremia include nausea, confusion, weakness, and headache. Severe symptoms include vomiting, lethargy, seizures, or cardio-respiratory distress. In patients with euvolemic hyponatremia, as in this patient, physical examination usually reveals a normal heart rate with no orthostatic drop in blood pressure, moist mucous membranes, normal skin turgor, and no signs of hypervolemia, such as ascites or edema.

In the setting of severe symptoms secondary to hyponatremia, an ABCDE assessment should be performed. If the patient is unstable, the first step is to stabilize the airway, breathing, and circulation. Unstable patients with hyponatremia often have a sodium level <125 mEq/L, which can result in cerebral edema, seizures, and respiratory arrest. If these findings are present, emergent administration of hypertonic saline is necessary to correct the serum sodium and prevent seizures. Once the patient is stabilized, they should be placed on continuous vital sign monitoring and supplement with oxygen as needed. Monitoring urine output is essential.   

Option Analysis

❌ Intravenous fluids given at a slow rate:
Incorrect: This patient has euvolemic hyponatremia. He does not have signs of dehydration as evidenced by normal vital signs, moist mucous membranes, and normal capillary refill. This patient is unstable and presents with generalized seizures and hyponatremia, and therefore, a bolus of hypertonic saline should be given to control the seizures and correct the sodium level.
✅ Bolus of hypertonic saline:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Intubation and mechanical ventilation:
Incorrect: This patient has euvolemic hyponatremia and seizures that are being controlled with medications. He has no signs of respiratory distress, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air, so intubation and mechanical ventilation are not the most appropriate next steps in this case.
❌ Measurement of serum and urine osmolality:
Incorrect: This patient has severe hyponatremia and seizures. Serum and urine osmolality should indeed be obtained to determine the etiology but not before stabilizing the patient and giving a bolus of hypertonic saline.
❌ Observation and measurement of sodium level in 1 hour:
Incorrect: This patient has hyponatremia with severe manifestations, including vomiting, confusion, and seizures. Observation and rechecking sodium levels is inappropriate in this patient; emergent administration of bolus of hypertonic saline is needed.

questions.text: A newborn girl is evaluated on day one of life following a vacuum-assisted vaginal delivery at 37 weeks' gestation. The mother has a history of a seizure disorder that is well-controlled with antiepileptic medications. Pregnancy was complicated by maternal group B Streptococcus colonization, and the mother received two doses of penicillin prior to delivery. The newborn’s temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), heart rate is 105/min, blood pressure is 74/40 mmHg, respiratory rate is 38/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. The patient appears lethargic and does not appropriately interact with the examiner. A significant cephalohematoma is noted, and the anterior fontanelle is open and slightly bulging. Ecchymoses are present on the infant’s extremities. During the examination, the patient begins to seize. Which of the following post-delivery care measures could have prevented this patient’s seizure?
questions.solution:
This newborn is evaluated following a vacuum-assisted vaginal delivery. There is a maternal history of a seizure disorder that is well-controlled with antiepileptic medications, which can affect vitamin K metabolism. The patient exhibits signs of easy bleeding, including a significant cephalohematoma and ecchymoses. These findings are consistent with hemorrhagic disease of the newborn, and the patient's seizure is likely secondary to an intracranial hemorrhage. Vitamin K is typically administered to all newborns shortly after birth to mitigate the risk of developing this condition.        

After a thorough history and physical examination, the focus should shift toward supporting newborn feeding, administering immunizations and preventive medications, performing routine screenings, providing anticipatory guidance, and offering optional care such as circumcision. Newborns should receive a series of preventive treatments, including vitamin K to prevent hemorrhagic disease of the newborn, topical erythromycin ointment to prevent chlamydial and gonococcal ophthalmia neonatorum, and a hepatitis B vaccine. Routine screenings in the newborn nursery include a newborn metabolic screen, hearing screen, congenital cardiac heart disease screen, and bilirubin screen. Blood glucose levels and infectious screening labs may also be obtained based on the infant’s risk factors.   

Option Analysis

✅ Vitamin K:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Corticosteroids:
Incorrect: Corticosteroids are used in premature infants to reduce the risk of bronchopulmonary dysplasia. This patient has findings more consistent with hemorrhagic disease of the newborn, which could have been prevented with vitamin K administration.  
❌ Ampicillin:
Incorrect: Intravenous ampicillin is administered to newborns for group B Streptococcus infections. Since the mother received adequate intrapartum prophylaxis, post-delivery administration is not indicated. This patient has hemorrhagic disease of the newborn, which is due to vitamin K deficiency.  
❌ Erythromycin ointment:
Incorrect: Erythromycin ointment is administered to prevent ophthalmia neonatorum caused by chlamydia or gonorrhea. This patient’s seizure is likely a result of an intracranial hemorrhage from hemorrhagic disease of the newborn. Vitamin K is typically given immediately after delivery to prevent this complication. 
❌ Bilirubin measurement:
Incorrect: Kernicterus is a complication of severe hyperbilirubinemia and typically presents with jaundice, hypotonia, poor feeding, or seizures. In this case, the presence of a cephalohematoma, bulging fontanelle, and maternal use of antiepileptic medications suggest that hemorrhagic disease of the newborn is the more likely cause of this patient’s seizure. Vitamin K is given after birth to prevent postnatal bleeding, including intracranial hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician’s office by a parent for evaluation of an eye concern. The parent noticed that the child looks “crossed-eyed,” with the patient's left eye deviating inward compared to the right eye. The patient is otherwise healthy and takes no daily medication. Vital signs are within normal limits. Visual acuity and red reflexes are normal bilaterally. Corneal light reflection and a cover-uncover test show no ocular misalignment. Which of the following additional findings is most likely on physical examination?

choices.text: Blood within the vitreous body on fundoscopy

questions.solution:
This 3-year-old child presents with findings concerning for potential amblyopia. Normal corneal light reflection and a negative cover-uncover test indicate intact ocular alignment, making pseudostrabismus the likely diagnosis. This condition refers to the false perception of ocular malalignment caused by anatomical features. A flat, broad nasal bridge, prominent epicanthal folds, and a narrow interpupillary distance can create the illusion of true strabismus.        

Amblyopia, sometimes called “lazy eye,” is reduced visual acuity in one or both eyes that impairs normal visual cortex development. Early identification is essential to support proper ophthalmologic development. Common causes include strabismus (misalignment of the eyes), visual deprivation, and refractive error.        

Evaluation for amblyopia and strabismus begins with a history and physical examination, including visual acuity testing and red reflex testing. Most patients will have reduced visual acuity, but many remain asymptomatic with the condition detected by clear deviation of an eye on physical examination. When symptoms do occur, they may include blurry vision, vision loss, squinting, head tilt, or (in infants) a lack of eye contact.        

If no obvious ocular deviation is noted on history or examination, consider refractive or deprivation amblyopia and perform a complete eye examination with fundoscopy. If ocular deviation is suspected, the corneal light reflection and cover-uncover tests can distinguish true strabismus from pseudostrabismus by assessing ocular alignment.   

Option Analysis

❌ Ptosis:
Incorrect: Ptosis, or upper eyelid droop, may accompany extraocular muscle weakness in cranial nerve III palsy, which would produce a “down and out” eye position and a positive cover test – neither of which are present in this vignette. 
✅ Flat, broad nasal bridge:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Blood within the vitreous body on fundoscopy:
Incorrect: Vitreous hemorrhage produces an abnormal red reflex (often dark or diminished) and usually impairs visual acuity. However, this patient has a normal red reflex and intact vision in the affected eye. 
❌ Papilledema:
Incorrect: Papilledema results from elevated intracranial pressure. When it is accompanied by an inwardly deviated eye, cranial nerve VI palsy should be suspected. However, this condition would produce persistent ocular misalignment on examination on cover-uncover testing, which is not present in this vignette. 
❌ Periorbital pain:
Incorrect: Normal visual acuity, a symmetric corneal light reflex, and a negative cover-uncover test indicate pseudostrabismus. Pain is not typical of pseudostrabismus but is more consistent with conditions such as periorbital cellulitis or trauma – neither of which is supported by the history or examination findings.

questions.text: A 2-day-old newborn, delivered at 37 weeks' gestation via an uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal delivery, is noted to have atypical genitalia. The mother reports a personal history of a right ovarian mass discovered during pregnancy. Pregnancy was otherwise uncomplicated. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 135/min, respirations are 33/min, blood pressure is 69/44 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The newborn's length is 49 cm (32nd percentile) and weight is 3,200 g (47th percentile). Physical exam reveals clitoromegaly and a single urogenital opening. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. Laboratory results show normal serum 17-hydroxyprogesterone and electrolyte levels. Chromosomal analysis later reveals a 46,XX karyotype. Which of the following findings on history is most strongly associated with this condition?

choices.text: Family history of short stature in females

questions.solution:
This newborn has atypical genitalia in the context of a 46,XY karyotype, with normal electrolyte and 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels. Given the maternal history of a right ovarian mass, these findings are potentially related to a maternal androgen-producing tumor. These tumors, which can be adrenal, abdominal, or pelvic in origin, often present with elevated testosterone levels and maternal virilization.    

Infants with atypical genitalia can present with cryptorchidism, hypospadias, micropenis, bifid scrotum in karyotypic males, and clitoromegaly, posterior labial fusion, a single genitourinary opening, or inguinal hernia in karyotypic females. Placental aromatase deficiency and maternal androgen-secreting tumors, such as luteomas, Krukenberg, and Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors of the ovaries, can produce maternal virilization. Signs of maternal virilization include hirsutism, acne, frontal balding, clitoromegaly, and deepening of the voice. Excess androgens passed through the placenta can result in virilization of karyotypic female (46,XX) infants, presenting as ambiguous genitalia.    

The diagnosis of androgen excess disorders in infants includes history and physical examination to assess for virilization and signs of atypical genitalia. The initial laboratory evaluation includes obtaining a karyotype and measuring 17-hydroxyprogesterone (17-OHP). If 17-OHP is normal, and maternal virilization is present, placental transmission of excess androgens should be considered as a potential cause of atypical genitalia. The next step is maternal testing for testosterone, dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEAS), and androstenedione. If these levels are elevated, and ultrasound imaging of the pelvis, abdomen, and adrenal glands reveals a mass, a maternal androgen-producing tumor can be diagnosed.   

Option Analysis

❌ Family history of infertility :
Incorrect: Family history of infertility is found in various causes of ambiguous genitalia, such as partial androgen insensitivity syndrome. This condition presents with atypical genitalia, a 46,XY karyotype, and normal or elevated sex hormones (e.g., luteinizing hormone, follicle-stimulating hormone, testosterone). This patient's findings are likely secondary to a maternal androgen-producing tumor associated with maternal virilization.
❌ History of consanguinity  :
Incorrect: A history of consanguinity raises suspicion for autosomal recessive disorders such as congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), which presents with atypical genitalia and elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone (17-OHP) levels. This patient has normal 17-OHP and normal electrolyte levels, making CAH unlikely. This patient's findings are likely secondary to a maternal androgen-producing tumor associated with maternal virilization. 
✅ Maternal virilization :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Prenatal exposure to lithium  :
Incorrect: Prenatal exposure to lithium is associated with congenital heart diseases, but it is not known to cause atypical genitalia. This patient's findings are more likely secondary to a maternal androgen-producing tumor associated with maternal virilization. 
❌ Family history of short stature in females :
Incorrect: Short stature in a female with characteristic features may suggest Turner syndrome, but this condition is diagnosed by a 45,X karyotype and is not linked to family history or atypical genitalia. In this case, the findings are more likely due to a maternal androgen-producing tumor causing virilization.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for frequent joint dislocations over the summer break. The patient has not had frequent fractures, joint pain, vision problems, headaches, or fever. Family history reveals that the paternal grandfather had extremely flexible joints. There is no significant past medical or surgical history, and the child does not take any medication. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 21/min, blood pressure is 115/76 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Height and weight are at the 35th percentile for age. On physical exam, multiple bruises and scars are seen over both lower legs and knees. Cardiopulmonary exam is unremarkable. Which of the following additional physical exam findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Increased arm span to height ratio

questions.solution:
Hypermobile joints and skin hyperelasticity in Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.
Reproduced from Wikipedia and Wikipedia . Licensed under CC by 2.5 and CC BY-SA 4.0  
This 10-year-old child's history and presentation are most consistent with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS), as evidenced by frequent joint dislocations, a family history of hypermobile joints, and physical exam findings of normal height, bruising, and scarring of the skin. Hyperextensible skin is an additional feature expected in patients with EDS.
