Children with connective tissue disorders often present with chronic joint pain, recurrent joint dislocations, fractures, fragile skin, and/or poor wound healing. Many will also have ophthalmologic manifestations, such as severe myopia. A family history may reveal a first- or second-degree relative with a connective tissue disorder.

Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) is a spectrum of heritable conditions caused by collagen defects. Classic EDS and hypermobility EDS are the most common types. Children with EDS typically experience chronic joint pain, frequent joint dislocations, or subluxations, and may have delayed motor milestones, such as walking. They may also have fragile skin that bruises and tears easily, with poor healing. Characteristic physical exam findings include hypermobile joints; thin, velvety, hyperextensible skin; wide atrophic scars; and striae. Hypotonia can be noted. A heart murmur and mid-systolic click can be auscultated if the patient has mitral valve prolapse.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Arachnodactyly:
Incorrect: Arachnodactyly is typically seen in patients with Marfan syndrome, commonly associated with tall stature, long extremities, and ectopia lentis. The findings in this patient are more consistent with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which is associated with hyperextensible skin.
❌ Blue sclera:
Incorrect: Blue sclera is usually seen in patients with osteogenesis imperfecta, in addition to frequent low-impact fractures and short stature. The findings in this patient are more consistent with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which is associated with hyperextensible skin.
✅ Hyperextensible skin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Light skin and hair:
Incorrect: Light skin and hair may be seen in patients with phenylketonuria, in addition to eczema and a musty odor from the skin and urine. The findings in this patient are more consistent with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which is associated with hyperextensible skin.
❌ Increased arm span to height ratio:
Incorrect: Increased arm span to height ratio is seen in patients with Marfan syndrome, commonly associated with arachnodactyly, tall stature, and ectopia lentis. The findings in this patient are more consistent with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which is associated with hyperextensible skin.

questions.text: An 18-month-old boy is brought to the clinic for delayed development. The caregivers report the child has not started walking, is unable to climb on or off furniture, and does not follow one-step directions. There is no history of characteristic odors, meningitis, or stroke. The caregivers report a past medical history of pulmonary embolism. The infant was born at home, and the family moved to the United States when he was 6 months of age. All immunizations are up to date. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 25/min, blood pressure is 90/46 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Height is at the 95<sup>th</sup> percentile for age, and weight is at the 45<sup>th</sup> percentile. On examination, the infant appears fair-skinned and blue-eyed, with no abnormal facial features. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. Laboratory studies show elevated urine homocysteine levels. Which of the following genetic mutations is most likely in this patient?

choices.text: Fragile X messenger ribonucleoprotein 1 (FMR1) gene mutation

questions.solution:
The findings described in this 18-month-old infant are most consistent with homocystinuria. The infant presents with global developmental delay, a history of a thrombotic event, fair skin, marfanoid habitus, and elevated urine homocysteine levels. Homocystinuria is caused by a cystathionine beta-synthase (CBS) genetic mutation.

In connective tissue disorders, growth patterns can help narrow the differential diagnosis. Disorders associated with excessive long bone growth, such as Marfan syndrome and homocystinuria, may present with taller stature. However, this difference in height may not be apparent in infancy and often becomes more noticeable as the child grows.

Homocystinuria is an autosomal recessive inborn error of metabolism caused by cystathionine beta-synthase (CBS) enzyme deficiency. This results in elevated homocysteine levels which interfere with collagen and fibrillin formation, leading to connective tissue dysfunction. Children with homocystinuria often experience developmental delays and progressive intellectual impairment. They may also present with downward lens subluxation, marfanoid body habitus, and hypercoagulability, which can result in pulmonary embolism or stroke. Examination findings include a tall, thin frame, long limbs, chest wall deformities, and scoliosis.

Laboratory testing typically reveals elevated plasma levels of methionine and homocysteine, with low levels of cysteine. Elevated levels of urinary homocysteine are diagnostic. Genetic testing will demonstrate a mutation in the CBS gene, confirming the diagnosis.

Option Analysis

❌ Fragile X messenger ribonucleoprotein 1 (FMR1) gene mutation:
Incorrect: Fragile X syndrome is caused by a mutation in the FMR1 gene and typically presents with tall stature, developmental delays, and characteristic facial features such as large ears and an elongated face. This patient's findings are more consistent with homocystinuria, caused by a mutation in the cystathionine beta-synthase (CBS) gene.
❌ Collagen-1 gene mutation:
Incorrect: Osteogenesis imperfecta is caused by a mutation in the collagen-1 gene and typically presents with frequent fractures and blue sclerae. This patient's findings are more consistent with homocystinuria, caused by a mutation in the cystathionine beta-synthase (CBS) gene.
❌ Collagen-5 gene mutation:
Incorrect: Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is caused by a mutation in the collagen-5 gene and typically presents with joint hypermobility and hyperextensible skin. This patient's findings are more consistent with homocystinuria, caused by a mutation in the cystathionine beta-synthase (CBS) gene.
✅ Cystathionine beta-synthase (CBS) gene mutation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Fibrilin-1 gene mutation:
Incorrect: Marfan syndrome is caused by mutations in the fibrillin-1 gene and typically presents with chronic joint pain, arachnodactyly, mitral valve prolapse, and aortic root dilation. This patient's findings are more consistent with homocystinuria, caused by a mutation in the cystathionine beta-synthase (CBS) gene.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is transported by emergency medical services to the emergency department for sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to the lower back. The patient has not experienced recent illnesses, cough, dyspnea, orthopnea, fever, night sweats, or chest trauma. There is no significant past medical or surgical history, and the patient takes no medication. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 15/min, blood pressure is 135/86 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination reveals tall stature and arachnodactyly. No lymphadenopathy or edema is noted. Cardiac examination reveals a mid-systolic click. Pulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. Chest X-ray shows a widened mediastinum. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This adolescent boy presents with severe chest pain radiating to the back, along with physical examination findings of tachycardia, hypertension, a marfanoid body habitus, and arachnodactyly. Chest X-ray shows a widened mediastinum. These findings are most consistent with aortic dissection secondary to Marfan syndrome.

Marfan syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations of the fibrillin-1 (FBN1) gene. Patients often experience chronic joint pain, and some may develop ectopia lentis (dislocation of the optic lens), which can cause ocular pain, myopia, and diplopia. Physical examination typically reveals a tall, thin frame with an increased arm span-to-height ratio. Other common findings include arachnodactyly, pectus carinatum, pectus excavatum, and scoliosis. A heart murmur with a mid-systolic click is consistent with mitral valve prolapse, a condition frequently seen in patients with Marfan syndrome.
   
Marfanoid body habitus. Reproduced from: Wikipedia. Licensed under CC BY 2.0 
Marfan syndrome leads to weakness of the aortic wall, leading to progressive aortic root dilatation and increased risk of aortic dissection. The classic presentation involves sudden, severe pain in the anterior chest that radiates to the back. However, patients may also present with stroke-like symptoms, limb weakness, or paresthesias. Electrocardiogram (ECG) findings are often nonspecific, and chest X-ray may reveal a widened mediastinum and an abnormal aortic contour. Computed tomography angiography (CTA) is the diagnostic tool of choice for aortic dissection, although transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) can be used in hemodynamically unstable patients or when CTA is unavailable.

Option Analysis

✅ Aortic dissection:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Heart failure:
Incorrect: Patients with heart failure typically present with dyspnea, orthopnea, and edema. Chest X-rays more commonly show signs of pulmonary edema, rather than a widened mediastinum. The physical exam findings in this case, including tall stature, arachnodactyly, and mitral valve prolapse, should raise suspicion for Marfan syndrome, which is a significant risk factor for aortic dissection.
❌ Hodgkin lymphoma:
Incorrect: Patients with Hodgkin lymphoma usually present with lymphadenopathy, fever, and night sweats. Chest X-ray may show a widened mediastinum. However, the physical exam findings in this case, including tall stature, arachnodactyly, and mitral valve prolapse, should raise suspicion for Marfan syndrome, which is a significant risk factor for aortic dissection.
❌ Mediastinal teratoma:
Incorrect: Mediastinal teratomas are rare benign germ cell tumors that present with cough, dyspnea, dysphagia, and chest discomfort. Chest X-ray may show a widened mediastinum. However, the physical exam findings in this case, including tall stature, arachnodactyly, and mitral valve prolapse, should raise suspicion for Marfan syndrome, which is a significant risk factor for aortic dissection.
❌ Thymoma:
Incorrect: Patients with a thymoma present with chest pain, cough, stridor, and dysphagia, and chest X-ray may show a widened mediastinum. However, the physical exam findings in this case, including tall stature, arachnodactyly, and mitral valve prolapse, should raise suspicion for Marfan syndrome, which is a significant risk factor for aortic dissection.

questions.text: A newborn boy delivered at 36 weeks’ gestation is evaluated in the nursery. The infant is small for gestational age. Prenatal care was inconsistent, but there is no history of drug use or teratogen exposure. The parent recalls having a “cold” early in the pregnancy and is unsure if she received her childhood vaccinations. Delivery was uneventful, and Apgar scores were 6 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 42/min, blood pressure is 72/38 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, multiple violaceous macules are noted on the skin. No dysmorphic features are present. Cardiac auscultation reveals a continuous, machine-like murmur. Ophthalmologic evaluation shows a bilateral blue-grey pupillary reflex with lens opacities. Which of the following is the most probable cause of the ophthalmological findings in this patient?
questions.solution:
This newborn’s low birth weight, bilateral cataracts (blue-grey pupillary reflex with lens opacities), patent ductus arteriosus, and “blueberry-muffin” rash are most likely due to congenital rubella syndrome.

Congenital rubella syndrome results from maternal infection with rubella virus in the first trimester of pregnancy. It typically presents with congenital heart defects (commonly patent ductus arteriosus), sensorineural hearing loss, a petechial or "blueberry muffin" rash from dermal extramedullary hematopoiesis, and cataracts.  

In patients presenting with leukocoria, an ophthalmologic examination provides essential information to guide the diagnosis. If no intraocular mass is detected, the next step is to evaluate for lens opacities, which indicate cataracts. A thorough history can then help identify the underlying cause. Etiologies to consider include prematurity, metabolic disorders, genetic conditions, and congenital infections. In older children, trauma or chronic corticosteroid use may be factors. Persistent fetal vasculature is another potential cause; it is usually unilateral, associated with microphthalmia, and occurs in otherwise healthy infants.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Coloboma:
Incorrect: Coloboma often appears as a keyhole-shaped defect of the iris (though it can also involve the retina, choroid, or optic disc) and is associated with several genetic conditions, such as trisomy 13, trisomy 18, and CHARGE syndrome. This patient has no dysmorphic features suggestive of those conditions, and the ophthalmologic findings noted are more consistent with cataracts. When combined with low birth weight, a “blueberry-muffin” rash, and patent ductus arteriosus, congenital rubella syndrome is the most likely diagnosis.
✅ Congenital rubella syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Retinoblastoma:
Incorrect: Patients with retinoblastoma present with strabismus, leukocoria, and an intraocular mass on fundoscopic exam. The lens opacities described in the vignette are more consistent with cataracts. When combined with low birth weight, a “blueberry-muffin” rash, and patent ductus arteriosus, congenital rubella syndrome is the most likely diagnosis.
❌ Retinopathy of prematurity:
Incorrect: Retinopathy of prematurity occurs in premature infants (typically born before 32 weeks’ gestation), especially when risk factors are present (e.g., prolonged mechanical ventilation, hyperoxygenation), and is characterized by retinal neovascularization on fundoscopic examination. The lens opacities described in the vignette are more consistent with cataracts. When combined with low birth weight, a “blueberry-muffin” rash, and patent ductus arteriosus, congenital rubella syndrome is the most likely diagnosis.
❌ Vitreous hemorrhage:
Incorrect: Vitreous hemorrhage is commonly associated with trauma, thrombocytopenia, or coagulopathy and is characterized by blood in the vitreous humor. In contrast, the blue-grey pupillary reflex and lens opacities described in the vignette are more consistent with cataracts. When combined with low birth weight, a “blueberry-muffin” rash, and patent ductus arteriosus, congenital rubella syndrome is the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old girl presents with a 3-month history of intermittent epigastric pain that worsens between meals and at night. The pain is partially relieved by eating and occasionally accompanied by nausea. The patient reports no vomiting or diarrhea but recently noticed dark, tarry stools. The family emigrated from Vietnam two years ago, and the father has a history of peptic ulcer disease (PUD). Vitals are within normal limits. On examination, the child appears pale, with mild tenderness in the epigastric region without guarding or rebound. Laboratory results are shown below. An esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) reveals an ulcer in the gastric antrum, and biopsies are taken. Which of the following is most likely to be seen on histology after biopsy of the gastric mucosa?

 Laboratory Test     Result    
 Hemoglobin     9.5 g/dL    
 Hematocrit     28%    
 Stool guaiac test     Positive

choices.text: Fungal hyphae with surrounding neutrophilic infiltration
Non-caseating granulomas with multinucleated giant cells

questions.solution:
This patient’s chronic epigastric pain, melena, anemia, positive stool guaiac test, and EGD finding of a gastric antral ulcer are consistent with peptic ulcer disease (PUD). The history of emigration from an endemic country and a family history of PUD are significant risk factors for Helicobacter pylori infection, a common cause of PUD in children. Histological examination of gastric biopsy specimens may reveal curved, gram-negative rods located in the mucosal layer overlying the gastric epithelium.

A diagnostic workup for a pediatric patient with suspected PUD, gastritis, or duodenitis may not be required, but those with alarm features should undergo testing. Laboratory evaluation may include a complete blood count to identify microcytic anemia and stool guaiac testing for occult blood.

Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) with biopsy is the gold standard to confirm the diagnosis. Mucosal erythema, erosions, and subepithelial hemorrhage in the stomach or duodenum are characteristic of gastritis or duodenitis, respectively. Mucosal ulceration is indicative of PUD. Histology may show inflammatory cells in gastritis and duodenitis or identify damage extending into the muscularis mucosa in the case of ulcers.

Histopathology may also reveal H. pylori organisms in some cases, but tissue culture is considered the gold standard for diagnosis. Other options include rapid urease testing, polymerase chain reaction, or fluorescent in situ hybridization.

Option Analysis

❌ Fungal hyphae with surrounding neutrophilic infiltration:
Incorrect: Fungal hyphae with surrounding neutrophilic infiltration are typically seen with fungal infections, such as Candida esophagitis, which is not associated with PUD. Esophageal candidiasis is commonly found in immunocompromised patients. This patient’s constellation of symptoms, diagnostic findings, and risk factors for Helicobacter pylori are consistent with PUD. Curved, gram-negative rods in the gastric mucosa are the most likely finding
✅ Curved, gram-negative rods:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Non-caseating granulomas with multinucleated giant cells:
Incorrect: Non-caseating granulomas with multinucleated giant cells are seen in granulomatous diseases like Crohn disease or sarcoidosis, which often present with chronic abdominal pain and diarrhea or systemic symptoms. This patient’s constellation of symptoms, diagnostic findings, and risk factors for Helicobacter pylori are consistent with PUD. Curved, gram-negative rods in the gastric mucosa are the most likely finding.
❌ Intranuclear inclusions with surrounding inflammation:
Incorrect: Intranuclear inclusions with surrounding inflammation are characteristic of viral infections, such as cytomegalovirus (CMV) or herpes simplex virus (HSV), especially in immunocompromised individuals. This patient’s constellation of symptoms, diagnostic findings, and risk factors for Helicobacter pylori are consistent with PUD. Curved, gram-negative rods in the gastric mucosa are the most likely finding.
❌ Basophilic stippling:
Incorrect: Basophilic stippling is not associated with PUD or Helicobacter pylori. It is more commonly seen in certain toxin exposures or metabolic conditions, such as lead poisoning. Instead, curved, gram-negative rods in the gastric mucosa are the most likely finding in this case.

questions.text:
A 5-day-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of lethargy, poor feeding, increased work of breathing, and vomiting. The infant was born at full term via vaginal delivery. Pregnancy and delivery were uneventful, and prenatal labs were negative. After discharge, the infant was doing well; however, since yesterday, there has been progressive lethargy and difficulty with feeding. There has been non-bloody, non-bilious, non-projectile vomiting after feeds. The infant has had three wet diapers and one stool in the last 24 hours. Weight is down 12% from birth. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 65/min, blood pressure is 82/50 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. On physical exam, the infant is lethargic, with moderate retractions and equal air entry bilaterally. The anterior fontanelle is open and flat. No nasal congestion is present. The abdomen is soft and nondistended with hepatomegaly. A complete blood count, inflammatory markers, glucose level, and chest x-ray are unremarkable. Respiratory viral panel is negative. Arterial blood gas is shown below. The anion gap is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate study to obtain next?

 Laboratory value     Result   
 Blood gas         
 pH     7.55    
 PaCO2     22 mmHg    
 HCO3     19 mEq/L
questions.solution:
This newborn presents with lethargy, poor feeding, vomiting, and increased work of breathing. On exam, the infant is lethargic with tachypnea and moderate retractions. Arterial blood gas reveals respiratory alkalosis, which raises concern for a urea cycle disorder. The next appropriate step is to obtain a serum ammonia level.

When a pediatric patient presents with signs suggestive of an inborn error of metabolism, a focused history and physical examination should be performed, and key laboratory studies should be obtained. These include an arterial blood gas (ABG), complete blood count (CBC), comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP), serum ammonia level, and urinalysis. An ABG showing elevated pH and decreased partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO₂) indicates respiratory alkalosis, which, in this context, is concerning for a urea cycle disorder. Marked hyperammonemia further supports this diagnosis.

Urea cycle disorders are characterized by impaired conversion of ammonia to urea, resulting in hyperammonemia. Elevated ammonia levels stimulate respiratory drive, leading to respiratory alkalosis. If untreated, hyperammonemia can cause encephalopathy, seizures, and coma. The most common urea cycle disorder is ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency. Plasma amino acid analysis can help confirm the diagnosis, with findings that typically include elevated glutamine and alanine levels, and decreased citrulline and arginine levels.

Option Analysis

❌ Air contrast enema:
Incorrect: An air contrast enema is useful for the management of intussusception, which typically presents with vomiting, intermittent abdominal pain, and currant jelly stools in children three months to three years old. This newborn presents with lethargy, hepatomegaly, and respiratory distress with respiratory alkalosis suggestive of a urea cycle disorder. The next best step is to check the ammonia level.
❌ Pyloric ultrasonography:
Incorrect: Pyloric ultrasonography can help confirm pyloric stenosis in patients presenting with projectile vomiting, poor weight gain, and a palpable, olive-shaped mass on abdominal examination. This newborn presents with lethargy, hepatomegaly, and respiratory distress with respiratory alkalosis suggestive of a urea cycle disorder. An ammonia level should be checked next.
✅ Serum ammonia level:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Serum uric acid level:
Incorrect: Serum uric acid is useful in the evaluation of patients with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome and glycogen storage disease type 1 (GSD I). Lesch-Nyhan syndrome may present with hypotonia, gout, and kidney stones, while GSD I typically presents with hypoglycemia and hepatomegaly, but it is not associated with the respiratory alkalosis seen in this case. This newborn’s presentation is most consistent with a urea cycle disorder. An ammonia level is more diagnostic and should be ordered next.
❌ Urine drug screen:
Incorrect: A urine drug screen may help evaluate suspected neonatal abstinence syndrome, which can present with tremors, irritability, feeding difficulty, and vomiting. However, this infant’s respiratory alkalosis and progressive lethargy are more consistent with an inborn error of metabolism, making serum ammonia the more appropriate next test.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the emergency department after a fall off a bicycle. The patient struck a pothole and landed directly on his left shoulder. Pain is reported over the anterior left shoulder, radiating up the neck and down the left arm. Parents at bedside report the patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any daily medications. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), heart rate is 106/min, blood pressure is 110/65 mmHg, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient appears uncomfortable but in no acute distress. Examination of the left shoulder reveals point tenderness at the acromioclavicular (AC) joint. The patient can flex and extend the elbow with minimal pain. Radial pulse is 2+, capillary refill is less than 2 seconds, and sensation is intact. Which of the following is the best next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the left shoulder
Computed tomography (CT) of the left shoulder

questions.solution:
This pediatric patient presents after a fall directly onto the shoulder, with physical examination revealing point tenderness at the acromioclavicular (AC) joint. The differential diagnosis includes clavicle fracture, AC separation, rotator cuff injury, and proximal humerus fracture. The best next step in diagnosis is to obtain a plain radiograph of the left shoulder.         

In children with musculoskeletal injuries, a careful history and physical examination are often sufficient to formulate and prioritize a differential diagnosis. It is helpful to categorize injuries based on the mechanism (e.g., direct trauma, no clear trauma, overuse) to narrow the differential diagnosis. In patients with acute trauma and a clear mechanism of injury, focal bony tenderness may indicate an underlying fracture, while tenderness localized to a joint may suggest a sprain or joint separation. The physical examination should also assess for deformity, swelling, and ecchymosis.       

In these cases, plain radiographs of the affected bone and nearby joints are typically obtained to evaluate for fracture or dislocation. If these are negative, but clinical suspicion remains high, computed tomography (CT) may be used to identify occult fractures, while magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can evaluate for soft tissue injury. If there is concern for non-accidental trauma, a skeletal survey should be performed in patients under 60 months of age or those with limited communication abilities. Overuse injuries are often diagnosed clinically, with physical examination maneuvers aiding in identification. For example, a positive squeeze test of the calcaneus may support a diagnosis of Sever disease (calcaneal apophysitis).       

P.S. Physicians are mandatory reporters in cases of suspected child abuse and neglect in every U.S. state and territory. Visit www.childhelphotline.org for help, resources, and reporting information. You can also visit www.childwelfare.gov/state-child-abuse-and-neglect-reporting-numbers for U.S. state-specific reporting numbers.   

Option Analysis

✅ Radiograph of the left shoulder:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the left shoulder:
Incorrect: MRI is generally reserved for soft tissue injuries such as rotator cuff or labral tears. This patient’s presentation is consistent with acromioclavicular (AC) separation, which can be diagnosed with plain radiographs. 
❌ Computed tomography (CT) of the left shoulder:
Incorrect: CT of the left shoulder is not indicated unless there is concern for complex or occult fractures missed on plain radiographs. Acromioclavicular (AC) separation can be diagnosed with plain radiographs. 
❌ Arthrocentesis of the left shoulder:
Incorrect: Arthrocentesis is used in the evaluation of joint effusions in conditions such as septic or crystal-induced arthritis. It is not indicated in the setting of acute trauma without signs of joint effusion or infection. 
❌ Radiograph of the left humerus:
Incorrect: This patient can flex and extend at the elbow, with point tenderness at the acromioclavicular (AC) joint, consistent with AC separation. A radiograph of the left humerus may be obtained as a precaution given the location of injury, but a radiograph of the left shoulder will diagnose this patient’s AC separation.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician's office for evaluation of rapid weight gain and excessive appetite. A caregiver reports that the child had difficulty feeding at birth due to poor sucking. Developmental milestones, particularly motor skills, have been delayed compared to siblings. Pregnancy was uncomplicated. Immunizations are up to date. Family history is non-contributory. Temperature is 37° C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Weight is at the 97th percentile for age. Physical examination reveals almond-shaped eyes, a thin upper lip, and micropenis. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. Which of the following studies should be obtained to confirm the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Characteristic facial features, truncal obesity, and small hands and feet associated with Prader-Willi syndrome. Reproduced from; Wikipedia      Licensed under: CC BY 2.0  

This child has Prader-Willi syndrome. The clinical history of feeding difficulties as a neonate, developmental motor delays, insatiable appetite, and characteristic facial features support this diagnosis. Genetic testing should be obtained for confirmation.       

The differential diagnosis for hypotonia can be broadly categorized into central and peripheral nervous system etiologies. In pediatric patients with developmental delays or seizures, central causes such as inborn errors of metabolism, hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy, and structural brain or spinal cord abnormalities should be considered. Evaluation should include a careful physical examination for syndromic features, followed by brain imaging, metabolic studies, EEG, and genetic testing when appropriate.       
Infants with Prader-Willi syndrome typically present with hypotonia and poor feeding. As they grow, affected children typically develop hyperphagia that can lead to obesity, along with hypogonadism, developmental delays, and behavioral issues, including obsessive-compulsive traits. Distinctive physical findings may include almond-shaped eyes, a thin upper lip, small hands and feet, micropenis and cryptorchidism in males, or clitoral and labial hypoplasia in females. The diagnosis is confirmed with genetic testing, most commonly identifying a deletion in chromosome 15q11–q13.   

Option Analysis

❌ Creatinine kinase (CK) levels:
Incorrect: CK is typically elevated in muscular dystrophies and other primary myopathies. This patient presents with a history of early feeding problems and delayed motor skills, current hyperphagia, and characteristic facial features, which suggests Prader-Willi syndrome. Genetic testing should be obtained to confirm the diagnosis.  
❌ Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis  :
Incorrect: Elevated protein and a normal white blood cell count on CSF analysis supports a diagnosis of Gulian-Barré syndrome, which presents with hypotonia and ascending paralysis, often after a viral infection. However, this patient presents with a history of early feeding problems and delayed motor skills, current hyperphagia, and characteristic facial features, which suggests Prader-Willi syndrome. Genetic testing should be obtained to confirm the diagnosis. 
✅ Genetic testing  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Metabolic screening :
Incorrect: Metabolic screening may be useful in identifying inborn errors of metabolism, which can present with hypotonia and developmental delay. However, the presence of dysmorphic features and hyperphagia makes Prader-Willi syndrome more likely. Genetic testing should be obtained to confirm the diagnosis. 
❌ Muscle biopsy  :
Incorrect: Muscle biopsy is useful in the diagnosis of muscular diseases. However, this patient presents with a history of early feeding problems and delayed motor skills, current hyperphagia, and characteristic facial features, which suggests Prader-Willi syndrome. Genetic testing should be obtained to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A newborn boy delivered at term is evaluated in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) at 2 days of life due to feeding difficulties and choking episodes. Pregnancy and delivery were uneventful. The mother takes pyridostigmine for a chronic disorder but was asymptomatic throughout pregnancy. The infant has poor sucking during breastfeeding. Weight is 2900 g. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 45/min, blood pressure is 70/38 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On examination, the newborn demonstrates a weak cry, bilateral ptosis, and generalized hypotonia with preserved reflexes. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. Complete blood count (CBC), C-reactive protein, and creatinine kinase (CK) are within normal limits. Electromyography (EMG) and nerve conduction studies (NCS) demonstrate a decremental response of the compound muscle action potential with repetitive nerve stimulation. Which of the following findings is expected in the laboratory evaluation of this patient?
questions.solution:
This newborn with a maternal history of likely myasthenia gravis (treated with pyridostigmine), feeding difficulties, poor sucking, ptosis, and generalized hypotonia has transient neonatal myasthenia gravis (MG). Diagnosis is supported by detection of anti-acetylcholine receptor (anti-AChR) antibodies.       

Neonatal hypotonia may result from systemic illness or dysfunction of the central or peripheral nervous system. An alert infant who responds appropriately to the surroundings but with profound weakness raises concern for a peripheral nervous system etiology. Normal CK levels argue against primary myopathy. In this context, EMG/NCS demonstrating a decremental response to low-frequency repetitive stimulation suggests a neuromuscular junction (NMJ) disorder.        

Fluctuating weakness, a maternal history of MG, and seropositivity for anti-AChR antibodies support a diagnosis of transient neonatal myasthenia gravis (MG). In contrast, congenital MG results from mutations such as those in the CHRNE gene. A positive response to an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor would be expected. Botulism, another NMJ disorder, presents with descending paralysis and is associated with Clostridium botulinum exposure (e.g. honey ingestion), often confirmed by stool culture or direct toxin assay.   

Option Analysis

❌ Positive direct toxin assay  :
Incorrect: Infantile botulism is confirmed with a positive toxin assay, typically following ingestion of Clostridium botulinum spores (e.g. in honey). However, this neonate is only 2 days old with no exposure history. The presentation and maternal history are more consistent with neonatal myasthenia gravis, which can be confirmed with anti-AChR antibodies. 
❌ Positive anti-nuclear antibodies (ANA) :
Incorrect: A positive ANA may be seen in neonatal lupus, which typically presents with heart block and cutaneous lesions. This presentation and maternal history are more consistent with neonatal myasthenia gravis, which can be confirmed with anti-AChR antibodies. 
✅ Positive anti-acetylcholine receptor (anti-AChR) antibodies :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Elevated thyroid stimulating hormone levels  :
Incorrect: Congenital hypothyroidism may cause hypotonia and feeding difficulties but often presents with additional signs (e.g., macroglossia, umbilical hernia, prolonged jaundice). The maternal history, clinical picture, and EMG/NCS findings in this case point to neonatal myasthenia gravis. 
❌ Positive blood culture  :
Incorrect: Neonatal sepsis can present with hypotonia and poor feeding, but this patient is afebrile and has normal inflammatory markers and blood counts. The maternal history, clinical picture, and EMG/NCS findings in this case point to neonatal myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department (ED) by a parent for evaluation of altered mental status. The parent reports they found the patient in a bedroom 20 minutes before presentation to the ED, breathing but difficult to arouse. There is a past medical history of asthma controlled with as-needed albuterol. The parent notes the patient has been having a difficult year and is failing several classes. Temperature is 97.2 °F (36.2 °C), blood pressure is 105/60 mmHg, pulse is 65/min, respiratory rate is 12/min, oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is slumped slightly in bed and incoherent. Miosis is noted bilaterally. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Glasgow coma scale is 10. Bedside glucose is obtained and is 64 mg/dL. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This adolescent patient presents with new onset altered mental status. Vital signs reveal mild hypotension, bradycardia, bradypnea, and borderline hypoglycemia. Physical examination shows miosis. These findings are consistent with opioid intoxication, and administration of naloxone is the appropriate next step in management.       

 In any patient with altered mental status, an initial assessment should follow the Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, and Exposure (ABCDE) framework, with stabilization as needed. The Glasgow coma scale (GCS), which ranges from 3 (deep coma) to 15 (normal), is commonly used to assess level of consciousness. While a GCS of 8 or lower is often used as a threshold for intubation in trauma patients, intubation may be considered at higher scores if airway protection is a concern.       

Once a patient is stabilized, the next steps typically include obtaining intravenous access, checking bedside glucose level, and administering naloxone if opioid intoxication is suspected. Continuous vital sign monitoring and supplemental oxygen may also be necessary.       

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741, or visit www.iasp.info/suicidalthoughts/  for international resources. You are not alone.       

Option Analysis

✅ Naloxone:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Intubation and mechanical ventilation:
Incorrect: Although the patient has a depressed mental status, there are no current signs of respiratory failure or loss of airway protection. A trial of naloxone should be administered first. If there is an inadequate response to naloxone or the patient’s respiratory status becomes compromised, supplemental oxygen or endotracheal intubation may be necessary. 
❌ Urine toxicology:
Incorrect: While toxicology screening may be helpful in the clinical course, it should not delay the administration of naloxone in a patient with suspected opioid toxicity. Toxicology results rarely alter acute management. 
❌ Ceftriaxone:
Incorrect: Ceftriaxone may be appropriate for suspected bacterial infections, such as meningitis. However, the clinical features here are more consistent with opioid intoxication, and there is no evidence of infection on examination or in the vital signs. 
❌ Intravenous glucose:
Incorrect: Although the glucose level is mildly low, it is unlikely to be the sole cause of this degree of altered mental status in a nondiabetic adolescent. If the glucose level is >60 mg/dL, it is recommended to first treat a suspected opioid intoxication with naloxone.

questions.text: A 7-month-old boy is brought to the clinic due to frequent regurgitation after feedings. The caregiver reports frequent crying during and after feeding, occasional back arching, and reduced feeding volumes over the past two weeks. The infant has recently refused bottle-feeding and has had intermittent non-bloody, nonbilious vomiting. An upper respiratory tract infection occurred three weeks ago. There has not been fever, lethargy, bilious vomiting, hematemesis, or diarrhea. Weight is at the 25<sup>th</sup> percentile for age, down from the 45<sup>th</sup> percentile two months prior. Vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, the infant appears alert and active with no abnormal findings. Which of the following findings from the history and physical examination should prompt further evaluation?

choices.text: Crying and back arching during feedings

questions.solution:
This infant presents with frequent regurgitation, crying, back arching, and occasional vomiting, which are suggestive of gastroesophageal reflux disease. However, the decline in growth percentile indicating poor weight gain is an alarm sign that requires further evaluation.  

Gastroesophageal reflux (GER) is the backward flow of stomach contents into the esophagus. When this causes significant symptoms or complications such as esophagitis or Barrett esophagus, it is termed gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). In infants, GERD commonly presents with regurgitation, feeding refusal, irritability, and back arching during feeds. In older children and adolescents, symptoms may include heartburn, epigastric pain, nausea, or vomiting, along with anorexia or specific food aversions.

Clinicians should evaluate for warning signs that may suggest a diagnosis other than GERD. In infants, concerning features include onset of symptoms before 1 week or after 6 months of age, poor weight gain, fever, or lethargy. Neurologic signs such as seizures, abnormal head size, or a bulging fontanelle may indicate intracranial pathology. Other red flags include abdominal distention, hepatosplenomegaly, bilious or bloody vomiting, chronic diarrhea, and rectal bleeding. If any of these findings are present, further workup is warranted to assess for conditions such as intestinal obstruction, infection, or intracranial mass.

Option Analysis

❌ Crying and back arching during feedings:
Incorrect: These are common symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux in infants and do not warrant further workup in the absence of warning signs.
✅ Change in growth percentile:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Recent upper respiratory tract infection:
Incorrect: A resolved upper respiratory infection is unlikely to be related to the current feeding issues and does not require further evaluation.
❌ Bottle refusal for two weeks:
Incorrect: Temporary feeding aversion is a common symptom of gastroesophageal reflux   and should be managed with conservative measures unless accompanied by warning signs, such as suboptimal weight gain.
❌ Non-bloody, nonbilious vomiting:
Incorrect: Non-bloody, nonbilious vomiting is a hallmark of gastroesophageal reflux in infants and is not concerning without warning signs. Bloody or bilious vomiting are alarm features that should prompt further evaluation.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy is brought to clinic due to frequent regurgitation and irritability during and after feedings for one month. The infant arches his back during feedings, cries excessively, and often refuses to finish formula bottles. Feeding occurs every 4 hours, with approximately 4 ounces consumed per feed. There is no bilious or bloody vomiting. The parents report no fever, diarrhea, lethargy, or respiratory symptoms. Weight is at the 45<sup>th</sup> percentile for age, and growth parameters are consistent with previous visits. Vital signs are within normal limits. The infant appears alert and well-hydrated. The abdomen is soft and non-tender, with no hepatosplenomegaly or palpable masses. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: Elimination of cow’s milk protein from the diet

questions.solution:
This infant’s symptoms of frequent regurgitation, irritability, and back arching during feeding are consistent with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). In the absence of alarm signs such as poor weight gain, bilious vomiting, hematemesis, or systemic symptoms, GERD is typically managed conservatively with thickened feedings using rice cereal or a commercial thickener, along with smaller, more frequent feedings. Counseling on avoiding tobacco exposure is also recommended.

If symptoms persist, elimination of cow’s milk protein from the diet can be considered. Formula-fed infants may transition to extensively hydrolyzed or amino acid-based formulas. For breast-fed infants, the breastfeeding parent can remove cow’s milk from their diet. If symptoms improve, this approach should be continued.

If symptoms continue despite these measures, referral to a pediatric gastroenterologist is appropriate for further evaluation. A proton pump inhibitor (PPI) may be considered if specialist evaluation is delayed, but only for severe symptoms and for a limited duration of 4 to 8 weeks.

Option Analysis

❌ Proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy:
Incorrect: PPIs are not first-line treatment in infants with uncomplicated reflux due to limited benefit and potential risks. They may be considered if there are persistent, severe symptoms or evidence of acid-related complications.
✅ Thickened and smaller, frequent feedings:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Elimination of cow’s milk protein from the diet:
Incorrect: This is a second-line measure in the management of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), considered if conservative strategies fail or if there are signs of cow’s milk protein allergy (e.g., blood in stool, eczema, family history of atopy).
❌ Pediatric gastroenterologist referral:
Incorrect: Referral is not indicated unless symptoms are severe, refractory, or associated with alarm features such as failure to thrive, hematemesis, or bilious vomiting.
❌ Esophageal pH monitoring:
Incorrect: This test is reserved for infants with atypical symptoms or those not responding to diet modifications.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents to the clinic along with a parent for evaluation of gross hematuria for 3 weeks. Medical history is notable for visual impairment and an incidental finding of microscopic hematuria on previous urinalysis. There is no history of vomiting, diarrhea, or skin rash. Temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. Edema is noted in bilateral lower extremities. Ophthalmologic examination reveals anterior lenticonus. Renal biopsy shows a “basket-weave” appearance of the glomerular basement membrane on electron microscopy (EM). Which of the following is most likely to be found on further questioning?
questions.solution:
This adolescent has Alport syndrome. This hereditary disorder commonly presents with hematuria, hypertension, edema, and ocular abnormalities such as anterior lenticonus. Visual impairment may be noted early, and sensorineural hearing loss often develops during childhood or adolescence. Renal biopsy typically reveals glomerular basement membrane (GBM) splitting and a “basket-weave” appearance on electron microscopy. A family history of deafness or renal failure is frequently present.        

Nephritic syndrome typically presents with gross hematuria that may appear frankly bloody, cola-colored, or tea-colored, along with decreased urine output. Physical examination often reveals elevated blood pressure and edema. Urinalysis shows hematuria with or without proteinuria, and microscopy reveals red blood cells and red blood cell casts. A preceding upper respiratory infection may suggest post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis or IgA nephropathy, depending on timing and clinical context.       

In the absence of an infection history, additional clinical features can help narrow the differential diagnosis. Alport syndrome is associated with sensorineural hearing loss, ocular abnormalities involving the cornea, lens, and retina, and a family history of renal failure and/or deafness. Pulmonary symptoms such as cough, sinus congestion, or hemoptysis may suggest pulmonary-renal syndrome, including anti-GBM disease or ANCA-associated vasculitis. A history of chronic systemic illness, such as hepatitis B or systemic lupus erythematosus, may also indicate an alternative etiology.   

Option Analysis

❌ Recent streptococcal pharyngitis infection :
Incorrect: Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis typically presents 1 to 3 weeks after pharyngitis with acute onset of hematuria, edema, and hypertension. However, it is not associated with chronic microscopic hematuria, ocular abnormalities such as anterior lenticonus, or the “basket-weave” appearance of the glomerular basement membrane on EM, which are more characteristic of Alport syndrome. 
❌ Malar rash  :
Incorrect: A malar rash is characteristic of systemic lupus erythematosus, which may cause lupus nephritis. However, lupus nephritis typically also presents with systemic symptoms such as fatigue, joint pain, and photosensitivity. This patient lacks those features, and the presence of visual impairment and a “basket-weave” appearance of the glomerular basement membrane on EM are characteristic of Alport syndrome. 
✅ Family history for deafness :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hemoptysis:
Incorrect: Hemoptysis is seen in pulmonary-renal syndromes such as anti-GBM disease or ANCA-associated vasculitis. They do not typically cause anterior lenticonus or a “basket-weave” appearance of the glomerular basement membrane on EM. 
❌ Hepatitis B infection :
Incorrect: Hepatitis B virus can be associated with membranous nephropathy or membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, particularly in children. However, these conditions do not typically present with ocular findings such as anterior lenticonus or a “basket-weave” appearance of the glomerular basement membrane on electron microscopy. This patient’s combination of renal, ocular, and biopsy findings is characteristic of Alport syndrome.

questions.text:
A 1-month-old infant presents with delayed cord separation. Pregnancy and delivery were uneventful. Past medical history is significant for two episodes of otitis media. The patient has no rash, vomiting, or diarrhea. Temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 190/min, respirations are 33/min, blood pressure is 75/40 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, the umbilical cord appears attached with an erythematous and tense umbilical stump. A complete blood cell count (CBC) is shown below. Immunoglobulin levels are normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?  

 Laboratory value     Result    
           Complete blood count (CBC)         
 Hemoglobin     16 g/dL    
 Hematocrit     45 %    
 Leukocyte count     59,100 /mm3    
 Platelet count     400,000/mm3    
 Neutrophils     78%    
 Eosinophils     0%    
 Basophils     0%    
 Lymphocytes     20%    
 Monocytes     2%
questions.solution:
This child's history of recurrent infections, delayed umbilical cord separation, and physical exam findings of omphalitis without purulence are characteristic of leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD). The laboratory studies showing marked neutrophilic leukocytosis with normal immunoglobulin levels further support the diagnosis. LAD results from impaired neutrophil adhesion and migration due to defective integrins, particularly CD18, which can be evaluated by flow cytometry.       

In patients with suspected primary immunodeficiency and no distinguishing syndromic features, the type of infection and causative organisms can help narrow the differential diagnosis and guide the diagnostic process.        

LAD typically presents polymicrobial skin and mucosal infections, delayed cord separation, ulcers without pus, and gingivitis. Labs may show marked neutrophilic leukocytosis and normal immunoglobulin levels. Flow cytometry demonstrates decreased expression of CD18 or CD11 on neutrophils.        

In contrast, chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) involves recurrent infections with catalase-positive organisms. Immunoglobulin levels are usually normal, and the CBC may show mild leukocytosis. Diagnosis is confirmed by the dihydrorhodamine (DHR) flow cytometry test for oxidative burst.        

Complement deficiencies often result in invasive infections with encapsulated bacteria, especially Neisseria meningitidis, with normal CBC and immunoglobulin levels. Diagnosis is made using CH50 and AH50 assays.         

B-cell or antibody deficiencies present with recurrent sinopulmonary or gastrointestinal infections, lymphopenia on CBC, and characteristic immunoglobulin level patterns. Diagnosis includes quantitative immunoglobulin testing, flow cytometry, and genetic analysis as indicated.   

Option Analysis

❌ Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation :
Incorrect: Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is the treatment of choice for leukocyte adhesion deficiency. However, flow cytometry is required to confirm the diagnosis prior to referral.  
❌ Genetic testing :
Incorrect: Genetic testing can be useful for the diagnosis of primary immunodeficiencies such as ataxia telangiectasia, Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, and hyper IgM syndrome. This patient's presentation is most consistent with leukocyte adhesion deficiency, and flow cytometry is required to confirm the diagnosis. 
✅ Flow cytometry :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Immunology referral :
Incorrect: While referral to an immunologist is appropriate for long-term management of suspected immunodeficiency, diagnostic confirmation with flow cytometry is the priority. 
❌ Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) serology  :
Incorrect: Perinatal HIV infection typically presents with opportunistic infections, failure to thrive, or chronic symptoms such as diarrhea. Delayed cord separation and marked neutrophilia are not characteristic of HIV but suggest leukocyte adhesion deficiency.

questions.text: A 6-week-old girl is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of poor feeding and high-pitched crying. A caregiver reports the infant has been feeding very slowly, and if the feeding rate is increased, the infant develops a high-pitched inspiratory cough. These symptoms have been present for approximately three weeks. The infant was born full term and has not had any illnesses since birth. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals normal tone and reflexes with occasional stridor. When placed supine on the exam table, the stridor noticeably worsens. Which of the following is most likely to be found on further testing?
questions.solution:
This 6-week-old infant presents with slow feeding and a high-pitched cry. These features are characteristic of laryngomalacia, which results from collapse of the supraglottic structures due to soft, immature laryngeal cartilage. Stridor typically occurs during inspiration and is often worsened by feeding, agitation, or the supine position. Laryngoscopy confirms the diagnosis by visualizing dynamic supraglottic collapse.         

When evaluating an infant with poor feeding, history and physical examination are essential in guiding the differential diagnosis. Physical findings may reveal craniofacial abnormalities such as cleft lip, cleft palate, or micrognathia, all of which are clinically apparent. Ankyloglossia may present with difficulty latching and is identified by a tight lingual or upper lip frenulum.         

In some cases, the physical examination may not reveal obvious abnormalities. Frothing or bubbling from the nose and mouth raises concern for esophageal atresia. Choanal atresia is often associated with cyanosis that improves with crying, whereas laryngomalacia typically presents with inspiratory stridor that worsens with crying, feeding, or changes in position. These conditions require confirmatory testing. Esophageal atresia is evaluated with plain radiography and often confirmed with endoscopy or bronchoscopy. Choanal atresia is best diagnosed with computed tomography (CT) imaging. Laryngomalacia is confirmed with flexible laryngoscopy.        

Gastroesophageal reflux disease can also present with poor feeding and is often accompanied by fussiness, regurgitation, and back arching during feeds. Diagnosis is clinical and based on response to conservative treatment.   

Option Analysis

❌ Airless scaphoid abdomen:
Incorrect: An airless scaphoid abdomen on X-ray may be seen with esophageal atresia. However, esophageal atresia typically presents in the first few days of life with excessive oral secretions, choking, and difficulty passing a nasogastric tube. This infant’s subacute, progressive symptoms are not consistent with that diagnosis.        
❌ Retained fluid in nasal cavity :
Incorrect: Choanal atresia can present with retained secretions in the nasal cavity and respiratory distress, particularly in bilateral cases. However, it usually manifests in the immediate neonatal period with cyanosis that improves with crying. This infant’s stable oxygenation and progressive stridor make choanal atresia unlikely. 
❌ Bilateral bony atresia :
Incorrect: Bilateral choanal atresia presents with cyclic cyanosis that improves with crying and respiratory distress during feeding. This infant has normal oxygenation and no signs of cyanosis, making this diagnosis unlikely. 
✅ Collapse of supraglottic structures :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Thickened pylorus:
Incorrect: Pyloric stenosis presents with projectile, non-bilious vomiting. This infant has feeding difficulty without vomiting, making pyloric stenosis an unlikely cause.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the clinic for gynecomastia that has been present for three months. There is no history of medication use, oil use, recent infection, or travel. Parents report learning difficulties at school. Birth and family history are non-contributory. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 65/min, respirations are 15/min, blood pressure is 119/68 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. Weight is at the 45<sup>th</sup> percentile and height is at the 99<sup>th</sup> percentile for age. Physical examination reveals bilateral gynecomastia, pubic hair at Tanner stage 2, and small firm testes bilaterally. Which of the following is expected on karyotype analysis?
questions.solution:
This adolescent patient exhibits features consistent with Klinefelter syndrome, including gynecomastia, developmental delay, tall stature, small firm testicles, and lack of secondary sexual characteristics. A chromosome analysis showing 47,XXY would confirm the diagnosis.

Chromosomal microarray analysis (CMA) and fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) should be ordered for patients with concerns for aneuploidy or microdeletion. Conditions characterized by aneuploidy include trisomy 13, 18, and 21, which present in the neonatal period, as well as Turner or Klinefelter syndromes, which present in childhood or adolescence.

Symptoms of Klinefelter syndrome become evident at puberty. If a pediatric patient is phenotypically male and has tall stature, Klinefelter syndrome should be considered. This contrasts with Turner syndrome, where patients are phenotypically female with short stature. Klinefelter syndrome is also associated with delayed puberty, learning disabilities, language and processing deficits, and psychiatric conditions such as ADHD or depression. On physical exam, long limbs, a lack of secondary sexual characteristics, gynecomastia, and small firm testes are often observed. Gonadotropins (FSH and LH) are usually elevated, while testosterone levels are low. A definitive diagnosis is made through karyotype analysis or chromosomal microarray testing. A finding of 47,XXY confirms the diagnosis.

Option Analysis

❌ 47,XX,+21:
Incorrect: The karyotype 47,XX,+21 is consistent with Down syndrome. This condition presents with hypotonia, brachycephaly, a single palmar crease, wide-spaced toes, and upward-slanting palpebral fissures. However, the clinical presentation in this case is more consistent with Klinefelter syndrome, which is associated with a 47,XXY karyotype.
❌ 45,XO:
Incorrect: The karyotype 45,XO is consistent with Turner syndrome, which occurs in phenotypical females and presents with lymphedema, a short, webbed neck, widely-spaced nipples, and congenital heart defects. The clinical presentation in this case is more consistent with Klinefelter syndrome, which is associated with a 47,XXY karyotype.
✅ 47,XXY:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ 47,XX,+18:
Incorrect: The karyotype 47,XX,+18 is consistent with Edwards syndrome, which typically presents within the first two years of life with poor growth, cardiac anomalies, microcephaly, cleft lip and/or palate, micrognathia, low-set or malformed ears, clenched fists, and rocker-bottom feet. However, the clinical presentation in this case is more consistent with Klinefelter syndrome, which is associated with a 47,XXY karyotype.
❌ 47,XX,+13:
Incorrect: The karyotype 47,XX,+13 is consistent with Patau syndrome, which typically presents within the first two years of life with poor growth, microcephaly, microphthalmia, cleft lip and palate, clinodactyly, and polydactyly. However, the clinical presentation in this case is more consistent with Klinefelter syndrome, which is associated with a 47,XXY karyotype.

questions.text: A previously healthy 9-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by a parent for disorientation. According to the parent, the child woke up in the morning and did not recognize family members. The symptoms are associated with right-sided upper and lower extremity weakness over the past few days, which had been attributed to tiredness after a sports event. There has been no vomiting, headache, seizures, or fever. Family and developmental histories are non-contributory. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, blood pressure is 115/68 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is disoriented to time, place, and person. Neurological exam reveals 3/5 strength with hyporeflexia in the right upper and lower extremities. Strength and tone are normal on the left side. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. Blood glucose, electrolytes, and complete blood count are within normal limits. While additional laboratory studies are pending, the patient has a generalized tonic-clonic seizure and oxygen saturation drops to 80%. There is poor respiratory effort, and oxygenation does not improve with nasal cannula. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging(MRI) of the brain

questions.solution:
The 9-year-old patient’s presentation with disorientation, hemiparesis, and seizures strongly suggests an underlying brain tumor. Following the acute seizure episode, the patient develops acute respiratory distress, necessitating immediate intubation and mechanical ventilation.         

Hemispheric masses, such as glioblastoma multiforme or primitive neuroectodermal tumors, commonly present with seizures. Additional findings may include focal weakness, sensory changes, and alterations in cognitive function including behavior, personality, and speech. Older children may report headaches, while infants might demonstrate early handedness. Physical examination findings can include altered levels of consciousness, motor weakness or paralysis, asymmetric reflexes, and vision or hearing loss.       

In the setting of a seizure due to a suspected brain tumor, an ABCDE assessment should be performed. If the patient is unstable, the immediate priority is to stabilize the airway, breathing, and circulation. For patients with respiratory distress, emergent intubation and mechanical ventilation may be required. Intravenous (IV) access should be obtained, and the patient should be placed on continuous vital sign monitoring. IV fluids and supplemental oxygen can be administered as needed. Subsequent treatment should focus on seizure management and identifying the cause. Ongoing assessment of respiratory and neurologic status remains essential.    

Option Analysis

❌ Valproic acid :
Incorrect: Valproic acid is used for long-term seizure management, not for acute seizure termination. In addition, in the setting of respiratory compromise, the priority is immediate airway protection with intubation and mechanical ventilation. 
❌ Intravenous antibiotics :
Incorrect: Administration of empiric antibiotics is indicated in suspected meningitis, which typically presents with disorientation, headache, fever, and meningeal signs. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with a structural or neurologic process. Additionally, the immediate need is airway stabilization due to respiratory compromise. 
✅ Intubation and mechanical ventilation  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Lumbar puncture and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis :
Incorrect: While lumbar puncture is essential in the evaluation of suspected meningitis, neuroimaging should be performed first in patients presenting with focal neurologic deficits or altered mental status. Additionally, in this case of respiratory failure, airway protection takes precedence. 
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging(MRI) of the brain :
Incorrect: Neuroimaging is important to evaluate for the structural or neurologic causes of this patient’s presentation but should be deferred until the airway is secured. In the setting of acute respiratory failure, immediate intubation and mechanical ventilation are required.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for evaluation of a neck mass that has been gradually enlarging over the past three weeks. The parents report that the mass appeared without any known trauma or illness and has grown steadily. The child has no pain or tenderness at the site, but he has developed intermittent night sweats over the past few days. There is no history of fever, recent infection, or animal exposure. Immunizations are up-to-date, and there is no history of radiation exposure. Vitals are within normal limits. The child is breathing comfortably, without signs of airway compromise. A firm, non-tender, immobile mass measuring approximately 4 cm is palpated along the left lateral neck, just superior to the clavicle. The borders are irregular, and the mass does not transilluminate. There is no erythema or warmth over the mass, and there are no enlarged lymph nodes appreciated in the axilla or groin. Oropharyngeal exam is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Computed tomography (CT) of the head and neck with IV contrast
Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and free T4 levels

questions.solution:
This 9-year-old child presents with a firm, immobile, irregular lateral neck mass accompanied by a systemic "B symptom" (night sweats), raising strong suspicion for a malignancy, particularly lymphoma. In a stable patient with concerning features, the appropriate next step is cross-sectional imaging. CT with IV contrast is preferred for evaluating the anatomy, extent, and vascular involvement of deep neck structures and lymph nodes. Imaging helps guide biopsy planning and further staging.

The diagnostic workup for a child with a head or neck mass begins with a focused history and physical examination to assess the location, consistency, rate of growth, and associated symptoms. Imaging, typically ultrasound or CT with contrast, is used to evaluate the structure, vascularity, and extent of the mass.

Neoplasms often present as firm, immobile, irregular masses that grow rapidly and may be associated with systemic B symptoms such as weight loss, fever, or night sweats, particularly in the case of lymphoma. Diagnosis is confirmed with biopsy.

In contrast, developmental anomalies are typically soft, mobile, and slow growing with smooth borders. When not associated with overlying skin discoloration, diagnoses such as dermoid cysts, thyroglossal duct cysts, and branchial cleft cysts are considered. These can often be evaluated and supported by imaging showing a well-defined cyst.

Option Analysis

❌ Fine-needle aspiration of the mass:
Incorrect: Fine-needle aspiration is often inadequate for diagnosing lymphoma in children, as it may not provide sufficient tissue for histopathology and immunophenotyping. In addition, imaging should be obtained first to guide biopsy site selection and assess the extent of disease.
✅ Computed tomography (CT) of the head and neck with IV contrast:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and free T4 levels:
Incorrect: Thyroid studies are appropriate for evaluating midline neck masses that raise concern for thyroid pathology. This lateral supraclavicular mass associated with night sweats is not consistent with thyroid disease.
❌ 10-day course of oral antibiotics:
Incorrect: There are no clinical signs of bacterial infection in this case, such as warmth, tenderness, or erythema. Empiric antibiotics would delay the diagnosis of a potentially serious condition.
❌ Reassurance and observation for 4 weeks:
Incorrect: A firm, immobile, enlarging supraclavicular mass with systemic symptoms requires prompt evaluation. Delaying diagnostic workup is inappropriate given the high-risk features in this case.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for evaluation of a painless swelling on the right side of the neck that has recently become more noticeable. A parent reports that the mass has been present intermittently for several years and enlarges during colds or upper respiratory infections. There is no fever, weight loss, night sweats, or recent trauma, and the child is otherwise healthy and up to date on immunizations. The family has a pet cat at home. On examination, the child is afebrile and in no distress. A 3 cm soft, non-tender, fluctuant mass is noted anterior to the right sternocleidomastoid muscle. The overlying skin appears normal without erythema or warmth. The mass does not move with swallowing or tongue protrusion. Oropharyngeal and lymphatic examinations are unremarkable. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the neck reveals a well-defined, low-attenuation cystic structure lateral to the carotid sheath and anterior to the sternocleidomastoid muscle. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
This 8-year-old boy presents with classic features of a branchial cleft cyst, a developmental anomaly caused by incomplete obliteration of the branchial apparatus during embryogenesis.

Branchial cleft cysts typically appear anterior to the sternocleidomastoid muscle, are soft and fluctuant, and often enlarge during upper respiratory infections due to associated inflammation. In this case, imaging reveals a well-defined cystic structure consistent with the diagnosis. The absence of systemic symptoms and the chronic, intermittent nature of the swelling help distinguish it from infectious or neoplastic causes.

In evaluating a pediatric head or neck mass, the differential diagnosis generally includes malignancy, infection, and developmental anomalies. Key features such as growth rate, location, consistency, and associated symptoms help guide the assessment. Firm, immobile masses with systemic signs such as fever or weight loss raise concern for malignancy, whereas tender, erythematous lesions are more consistent with infection. Soft, mobile, midline or lateral lesions that vary with illness suggest a developmental anomaly. Additional history, including recent infections, environmental exposures, and radiation history, along with a thorough physical examination, further refines the differential. Imaging studies such as ultrasound, CT, or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) are often useful for diagnosis, with laboratory testing or biopsy considered when clinically indicated.   

Option Analysis

❌ Infectious process:
Incorrect: Infection is unlikely in this case because there are no signs of inflammation such as fever, tenderness, or skin changes. Lymphadenitis typically presents as an acutely tender, erythematous, and warm mass rather than a chronic, fluctuant one.
✅ Developmental anomaly:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Neoplastic process:
Incorrect: Malignancies typically present as firm, fixed, irregular masses that grow progressively and may be associated with systemic symptoms such as weight loss or night sweats. These features are not present in this case.
❌ Congenital vascular malformation:
Incorrect: Vascular malformations usually appear as compressible, sometimes pulsatile masses that may have a bruit or overlying skin discoloration. These findings are not present on examination.
❌ Autoimmune lymphoproliferative disorder (ALPS):
Incorrect: ALPS is a rare genetic disorder that usually involves generalized lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and other systemic features. The isolated, asymptomatic mass seen here is not consistent with this diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 4-hour-old newborn delivered at 38 weeks’ gestation is being evaluated in the nursery for irritability and jitteriness. The mother had poorly controlled gestational diabetes during pregnancy. There is no history of maternal fever, rash, or drug use. Delivery was uneventful, with rupture of membranes for 6 hours. Apgar scores were 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Birth weight is 4,200 grams, and the newborn is breastfed. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 37/min, blood pressure is 72/40 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical examination, no dysmorphic features are noted, and no rash is seen. Cardiopulmonary exam is unremarkable. A sacral dimple is seen on the back. Bedside glucose is 28 mg/dL. The neonate is breastfed three times, and repeated glucose measurements are 27, 25, and 26 mg/dL. Additional laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? 

 Serum chemistries         
 Hemoglobin     24 g/dL    
 Hematocrit     75%    
 Leukocyte count     10,100/mm3    
 Platelet count     300,000/mm3    
 Serum glucose     30 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This newborn of a mother with diabetes is macrosomic (birth weight >4,000 grams) and presents with signs of hypoglycemia, including jitteriness and irritability, along with physical exam findings of caudal regression. Despite frequent feedings, the patient remains hypoglycemic, making intravenous (IV) dextrose infusion the most appropriate next step in management.        

Gestational diabetes increases the risk of neonatal and long-term complications. Poor maternal glycemic control leads to hyperinsulinism and neonatal hypoglycemia. Infants of diabetic mothers (IDMs) are often macrosomic, predisposing them to birth injuries. They may also have congenital anomalies, such as cardiac defects, neural tube defects, and neonatal small left colon syndrome. Postnatally, IDMs can present with hypoglycemic symptoms (e.g., jitteriness, irritability), respiratory distress, caudal regression signs, polycythemia, and hypocalcemia.    

In the case of neonatal hypoglycemia due to hyperinsulinism, an ABCDE assessment should be performed. If the patient is unstable, airway, breathing, and circulation should be stabilized first. After stabilization, continuous vital sign monitoring and oxygen as needed should follow. In newborns with hypoglycemia that does not improve with feeding or supplementation, IV dextrose infusion should be started to maintain adequate blood glucose levels. Monitoring glucose levels is essential. IV glucagon can be considered if the dextrose infusion fails to maintain glucose levels. If hypoglycemia persists, further investigation is needed to evaluate for a possible endocrine pathology or inborn error of metabolism.    

Option Analysis

❌ Intubation and mechanical ventilation  :
Incorrect: Intubation and mechanical ventilation are essential in unstable patients with respiratory distress or failure. This patient is not experiencing tachypnea or increased work of breathing, and oxygen saturation is normal. Instead, the priority is addressing the patient's hypoglycemia. 
❌ Intravenous (IV) glucagon infusion :
Incorrect: IV glucagon is typically used when dextrose infusion is insufficient to maintain adequate blood glucose levels. This patient has not yet received a dextrose infusion, so glucagon is not the most appropriate next step.
✅ Intravenous (IV) dextrose infusion :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intravenous (IV) normal saline bolus :
Incorrect: While a normal saline bolus may be needed in cases of hypotension or shock, this patient has a stable blood pressure. Instead, the priority is addressing the neonate’s hypoglycemia. 
❌ Intravenous (IV) antibiotics  :
Incorrect: IV antibiotics are typically started when there is concern for neonatal sepsis, which usually presents with risk factors for infection, temperature instability, or respiratory distress. This patient’s symptoms are more likely due to hypoglycemia, making intravenous dextrose the priority.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old girl is brought to a primary care clinic by parents due to 15 days of watery diarrhea. The diarrhea is frequent, mucoid, and occasionally blood streaked. The child has had abdominal cramping, fatigue, and poor appetite. She has not had a fever or vomiting. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), heart rate is 110/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and blood pressure is 98/62 mm Hg. The child appears fatigued but alert. Dry mucous membranes and a capillary refill time of 2 seconds are noted. The abdomen is soft with mild diffuse tenderness but no guarding or rebound tenderness. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is most likely to be present on further questioning? 

 Lab Test     Value    
 White blood cell (WBC) count     12,000/mm³    
 Hemoglobin     12.0 g/dL    
 Platelets     320,000/mm³    
 Serum sodium     134 mEq/L    
 Serum potassium     3.4 mEq/L    
 Serum bicarbonate     20 mEq/L    
 Stool culture     Positive for enteroaggregative E. coli

choices.text: Recent travel to a developing country
Family history of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)

questions.solution:
This child presents with 15 days of subacute watery diarrhea which contains mucus and occasionally blood. Stool culture confirms an infection with enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC), a recognized cause of traveler's diarrhea, often associated with recent travel to developing countries where food and water contamination is common.        

The history and physical examination may provide valuable clues in identifying the causative organism in infectious gastroenteritis, which can then be confirmed with stool studies. To qualify as "subacute," diarrhea must persist for more than 14 days and may be accompanied by fever, malaise, anorexia, vomiting, and abdominal cramps.       
A focused history should assess the characteristics of the diarrhea (e.g., watery, bloody, mucous, greasy) as well as potential exposures, such as sick contacts, recent travel (e.g., EAEC is linked to travel to developing countries, while tropical areas are associated with Cyclospora, Cryptosporidium, and Entamoeba infections), antibiotic use, or ingestion of contaminated food and water. The physical exam should evaluate the severity of dehydration (e.g., tachycardia, dry mucous membranes, delayed capillary refill) and check for abdominal tenderness, which may suggest inflammation or infection.   

Option Analysis

❌ Recent consumption of reheated rice:
Incorrect: Reheated rice is typically associated with Bacillus cereus, which causes acute, self-limited gastroenteritis with symptoms of vomiting or diarrhea occurring within hours of ingestion. It is unrelated to enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC) and would be unlikely to be the cause of this patient’s 2-week duration of symptoms.
