Pneumoperitoneum or a paracentesis showing enteric contents are absolute indications for surgical intervention. If the patient appears unstable and has extensive pneumatosis, surgery should also be considered. This patient appears stable and has a small amount of pneumatosis; therefore, medical management is more appropriate.  
❌ Emergent interventional radiology consultation for peritoneal drain placement:
Incorrect: In patients who have necrotizing enterocolitis and are unstable with evidence of hollow viscus perforation, a primary peritoneal drain placement can be performed at the bedside. A peritoneal drain serves as a temporary measure, as up to 75% of patients end up requiring definitive surgery. It is not necessary for this patient who has no evidence of perforation.

questions.text: A three-year-old girl presents to her primary care provider for re-evaluation of a chronic cough. Since infancy, the girl has had numerous respiratory infections. She also has been experiencing large foul-smelling stools, and poor weight gain since infancy. She is currently 3<sup>rd</sup> percentile for weight and 15<sup>th</sup> percentile for height. Temperature is 37.3°C (99°F), pulse is 115/min, respiratory rate is 28/min, blood pressure is 100/55, and oxygen saturation is 97%. On physical exam, the patient is thin-appearing. She appears comfortable and has no increased work of breathing. Diffuse rhonchi are heard throughout the lungs bilaterally. Which of the following additional physical findings would be expected on examination?

choices.text: Heart sounds on right side of chest

questions.solution:
This patient’s history of chronic cough, poor weight gain, recurrent upper respiratory infections, and large foul smelling stools since infancy is consistent with cystic fibrosis. Nasal polyps are often seen in patients with cystic fibrosis secondary to chronic rhinosinusitis.

When evaluating children who present with signs and symptoms of lower airway obstruction, it is important to assess the onset of pulmonary symptoms, specifically determining if symptoms have been present since birth and, if not, determining if they have acute onset, subacute onset, or gradual chronic onset. Causes of lower respiratory obstruction that have acute onset include anaphylaxis and bronchiolitis. Chronic diseases that present in childhood with lower airway obstruction and gradual onset of symptoms include cystic fibrosis, primary ciliary dyskinesia, tracheobronchomalacia, and asthma. These may be further differentiated by their triggers. For example, position changes, specifically the supine position, triggers stridor and monophonic wheezing associated with tracheobronchomalacia; and environmental changes, such as cold air and pollen, can trigger wheezing associated with asthma.

On physical exam, patients with suspected lower airway obstruction should be assessed for signs of increased work of breathing and impending respiratory distress. Respiratory rate and oxygen saturation should be monitored, and patients should be assessed for wheezing, crackles, and rhonchi on lung auscultation.

Patients with cystic fibrosis typically have a history of chronic cough and symptoms consistent with recurrent respiratory infections, including rhinosinusitis and pneumonia. They may have poor weight gain/failure to thrive due to pancreatic insufficiency, preventing the digestion of food. As a result, on physical examination, they often have nasal polyps from recurrent sinopulmonary infections; wheezing, crackles, or rhonchi on lung exam; digital clubbing if hypoxia is present; and abdominal distension.  

Option Analysis

✅ Nasal polyps:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Facial swelling:
Incorrect: Facial swelling and acute dyspnea associated with exposure to known allergens is associated with lower airway obstruction in the setting of anaphylaxis. This patient’s cough and gastrointestinal symptoms are more chronic, making them more consistent with cystic fibrosis.  
❌ Jaundice:
Incorrect: Liver disease is seen in alpha 1 antitrypsin deficiency, which is an inherited disease that can cause bronchiectasis and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. This patient who, along with upper respiratory infections and diffuse rhonchi, also has signs and symptoms of pancreatic insufficiency; they more likely have cystic fibrosis.  
❌ Middle ear effusions:
Incorrect: Recurrent otitis media is seen with primary ciliary dyskinesia, which can also present with recurrent sinopulmonary infections and chronic cough. This patient, who also has signs and symptoms of pancreatic insufficiency, is more likely to have cystic fibrosis.  
❌ Heart sounds on right side of chest:
Incorrect: Heart sounds can be appreciated on the right side of the chest with situs inversus, which is associated with primary ciliary dyskinesia. This patient, who has signs and symptoms of pancreatic insufficiency in addition to respiratory symptoms, is more likely to have cystic fibrosis.

questions.text:
A 1-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician for a well-child visit. He was born full-term and has no significant medical history. He is breastfed and eats a well-rounded diet. Parents report that they give him a daily multivitamin with iron. During the week, he is watched by his grandparents at their house, which was built in 1972, which they are currently renovating. He is 68th percentile for length and 80th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 150/min, respirations are 28/min, blood pressure is 92/58 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98%. On physical examination, the patient is happy and interactive with conjunctival pallor. There is mild tachycardia with a soft 1/6 systolic murmur heard best at the left sternal border. Lung examination is normal. Routine blood work is obtained and shown below. Which of the following additional tests is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

 Laboratory value  Result 
 CBC 
 Hemoglobin  10 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  29.4% 
 Leukocyte count  13,400/mm3 
 Platelet count  220,000/mm3 
 Red Blood Cell (RBC)  4.46 million/mm3 
 Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)  66 fL 
 Peripheral smear  Basophilic stippling of RBCs 
 Reticulocyte Count  0.8% 
 Iron studies
 Iron  20 mcg/dL 
 Ferritin  5 ng/mL 
 Total iron binding capacity (TIBC)  450 mcg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a history of exposure to a home built before 1978 that is undergoing a renovation and physical exam findings of tachycardia, flow murmur, and fatigue. Laboratory evaluation shows microcytic anemia, iron deficiency, and basophilic stippling of RBCs (see below) on peripheral smear. History, physical exam, and laboratory findings are consistent with anemia secondary to lead poisoning, which can be confirmed by checking a lead level.   



Once a patient diagnosed with anemia is deemed stable, the first step in evaluation is to obtain a reticulocyte count. A reticulocyte count above the reference range suggests anemia secondary to red blood cell destruction, whereas a reticulocyte count below the reference range suggests anemia secondary to underproduction. Anemias secondary to underproduction can be classified into three categories based on the mean corpuscular volume (MCV): microcytic, normocytic, and macrocytic anemia.   

A diagnosis of microcytic anemia with a low reticulocyte count warrants testing of iron studies. If iron deficiency is confirmed, a lead level and peripheral smear should be obtained to differentiate iron deficiency anemia from anemia due to lead poisoning. Patients who drink large volumes of milk are at high risk for iron deficiency anemia because milk blocks iron absorption. Breast milk is also low in iron, so breastfed infants should start on iron supplementation at 4 months. People who live in homes built before 1978, especially if they are undergoing renovation, are at risk for lead poisoning and subsequent anemia. Lead poisoning causes anemia by preventing iron absorption and inhibiting heme synthesis.  

A diagnosis of normocytic anemia with low reticulocyte count is likely secondary to physiologic anemia of infancy, anemia of prematurity, transient erythroblastopenia of childhood, or infection. These can often be differentiated based on patient age or, in the case of infection, by a concomitant viral or bacterial infection.  

A diagnosis of macrocytic anemia with low reticulocyte count is likely secondary to B12 or folate deficiency, Diamond-Blackfan syndrome, or congenital hypothyroidism. A history of a vegan diet puts patients at risk for B12 and folate deficiency. Diamond-Blackfan and congenital hypothyroidism are two genetic disorders that have specific physical exam characteristics that may help determine the diagnosis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Lead level:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ B12/folate level:
Incorrect: B12/folate deficiency is typically seen in vegan individuals, and it causes macrocytic anemia. This patient has microcytic anemia.
❌ Thyroid Stimulating Hormone/free Thyroxine (TSH/free T4):
Incorrect: TSH/free T4 screens for thyroid diseases such as hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism. Congenital hypothyroidism is associated with macrocytic or normocytic anemia. This patient has microcytic anemia. Hyperthyroidism can cause microcytic anemia but this patient’s age, exposure to renovation, and basophilic stippling on peripheral smear, make anemia secondary to lead poisoning more likely.
❌ Hemoglobin electrophoresis:
Incorrect: Hemoglobin electrophoresis tests for thalassemias and other hemoglobin variants such as sickle cell disease. These can cause microcytic anemia but this patient’s exposure to renovation and basophilic stippling on peripheral smear makes anemia secondary to lead poisoning more likely.
❌ Bone marrow biopsy:
Incorrect: Bone marrow biopsy is performed when a patient has aplastic anemia or concern for bone marrow dysfunction. This patient does not have aplastic anemia and his exposure to renovation and basophilic stippling on peripheral smear makes anemia secondary to lead poisoning more likely.

questions.text: An 18-month-old boy is brought to the primary care office by his parents for a well-child visit. The patient’s parents have no specific concerns. He eats a variety of healthy foods regularly and rarely consumes high-sugar drinks. He has good sleeping habits. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, respiratory rate is 30/min, weight is in the 70th percentile, height is 64th percentile, and head circumference is in the 70th percentile. On physical examination, the child is alert and playful. Which of the following findings would indicate the need for further evaluation?

choices.text: Inability to carry a toy while walking
Caregivers are able to understand less than half of the child’s speech
Rigidity with routines and frequent temper tantrums
Genu varum orientation of the legs

questions.solution:
This 18-month-old child presenting for a well-child visit should be evaluated for developmental milestones, including gross motor development. By 18 months of age, children should be able to walk independently and carry a toy while walking. Lack of this ability should prompt further evaluation.  

The well-child visit for a toddler begins with a comprehensive history, including the birth history and discussion of any health changes since the last examination. Caregivers should be asked to provide details about the new skills their child has learned since the last clinic visit as well as whether they have any concerns about the child’s development. Important aspects to include in the history of an 18-month-old child include how the child is eating and sleeping; whether the child can walk independently and carry toys while walking; whether the child is beginning to use a cup and spoon; and aspects of play, such as the ability to engage in pretend play. It is recommended that toddlers receive screening for autism at 18 and 24 months using a validated screening questionnaire or checklist, such as the Modified Checklist for Autism in Toddlers, Revised (M-CHAT-R).   

The physical examination at a well-child visit for a toddler includes a general assessment of how the child interacts with the healthcare provider and the caregiver(s), including aspects such as making eye contact and turning to look at an adult when something new happens. A comprehensive physical examination should also be performed. The hepatitis A vaccine is often administered at the 18-month well-check as it is recommended to be given initially at age 12-23 months with a second dose at least six months after the first dose. Genu varum orientation of the legs is a normal finding in children up to age 18-24 months.  



Option Analysis

✅ Inability to carry a toy while walking:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Caregivers are able to understand less than half of the child’s speech:
Incorrect: It would be expected that by age 24 months, adults would be able to understand about half of the child’s speech. This child is only 18 months of age, and it is not concerning that caregivers are not able to understand most of his speech yet; a red flag would be if the child could not say approximately 10-20 words. 
❌ Rigidity with routines and frequent temper tantrums:
Incorrect: Rigidity with routines in children beyond the age of four can be concerning for autism; however, children aged 18-24 months are commonly rigid in routines and are prone to temper tantrums. Although parents may need counseling regarding how to best manage the behaviors, this would be considered expected behavior for this child. 
❌ Inability to jump:
Incorrect: Children are expected to be able to jump by 24-30 months of age. This child is only 18 months of age; it would be expected that the child be able to walk independently and do some running but not jumping. 
❌ Genu varum orientation of the legs:
Incorrect: Genu varum or “bowleg” orientation of the lower extremities is common in infants and toddlers and typically resolves around 18-24 months of age. See image in Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A three-day-old newborn girl is being evaluated for a rash that suddenly appeared on her trunk. Her parents brought her immediately to the emergency department where she was triaged. She was born at 37-weeks of gestation via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery without peripartum complications. Weight is 85th percentile, length is 80th percentile, and head circumference is 85th percentile. Rectal temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), heart rate is 185/min, and blood pressure is 70/47 mmHg. The patient is sleeping in the mother’s arms but is arousable and moves all four extremities equally. Physical examination reveals an erythematous rash with clear demarcation along the midline on the trunk as seen in the image below. The hands and feet are warm and pink. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?


 [URL: https://www.pediatriconcall.com/spot-diagnosis/color-change/186. Image taken from script.]
questions.solution:
This three-day-old newborn girl presents with sudden onset of an erythematous rash on the trunk with a clear demarcation along the midline consistent with Harlequin color change. This benign condition is characterized by unilateral transient color change.    

Patients with Harlequin color change have sudden onset of unilateral redness that typically resolves within 20 minutes. On physical examination when the infant is placed on their side, unilateral erythema is seen on the dependent side with a clear demarcation along the midline. Blanching can be observed on the nondependent side. While the color change may appear dramatic, this phenomenon is benign, self-limited, and does not require intervention.   

The cause of Harlequin color change is unknown, but it may be related to immaturity of autonomic regulation of cutaneous blood vessel tone. It is more commonly seen in preterm infants vs. term infants and typically appears before one week of age. It typically resolves on its own after 20 minutes.  



Option Analysis

✅ Harlequin color change :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Physiologic desquamation :
Incorrect: Physiologic desquamation most commonly occurs in post-term neonates, and patients present with skin peeling or desquamation of the hands and feet. Peeling may extend to the limbs or trunk. This patient has no evidence of desquamation on physical examination.
❌ Acrocyanosis :
Incorrect: Acrocyanosis is typically seen in newborns who are less than 2 days old. It refers to color changes of the distal extremities that resolve with warming. Physical examination typically reveals cool and blue skin over the involved distal extremities. The trunk remains warm and well-profused. This patient’s extremities are warm and pink.
❌ Cutis marmorata :
Incorrect: Patients with cutis marmorata exhibit widespread symmetrical mottling of the skin with cold exposure that improves with warming. It can occur any time during the first few months of life. It appears as a lacy or reticulated purple or pink rash on the trunk, arms, and legs.
❌ Congenital dermal melanocytosis :
Incorrect: Congenital dermal melanocytosis is a birthmark seen in newborns that appears similar to a bruise. It can appear as a bluish-gray spot on the back, extremities, or buttocks and may be mistaken for non-accidental trauma.

questions.text:
A five-day-old boy born at 39-weeks of gestation via uncomplicated vaginal delivery is brought by his parents to the primary care office for a facial rash. Weight is in the 90th percentile, length is in the 95th percentile, and head circumference is in the 90th percentile. Rectal temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), heart rate is 183/min, and blood pressure is 73/50 mmHg. The patient is awake and calm in the father’s arms and moves all extremities equally. Physical examination shows numerous 1-2 mm sized whitish-yellow colored smooth papules over the face, nose, and cheeks as seen in the image below. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s condition?



[URL: https://www.gponline.com/glance-sebaceous-gland-hyperplasia-vs-milia/paediatrics/article/1057176. Image taken from script]
questions.solution:
This five-day old boy presents with numerous tiny white-yellow papules that are 1-2 mm in size on the nose and cheeks. This rash is consistent with sebaceous hyperplasia, which is caused by androgenic stimulation of the sebaceous glands in newborns. The rash is a benign and transient condition that typically resolves on its own or with conservative management.    

Typically, rashes that appear in well-appearing afebrile newborns are benign. Diagnosis can typically be made clinically using history provided by a caregiver and the physical exam. However, if the diagnosis is unclear, cytologic examination (e.g. of fluid from a pustule) can be used to help make the diagnosis.    

Features to consider when making the diagnosis of a rash in a newborn is the time of onset of the rash, whether or not the rash is transient, and the distribution of the rash.  Rashes that typically appear before one week of age include physiologic desquamation, Harlequin color change, acrocyanosis, cutis marmorata, transient neonatal pustular melanosis (TNPM), erythema toxicum nonatorum (ETN), sebaceous gland hyperplasia, and milia.  

Newborn and infant rashes can be caused by hormonal shifts, immature circulation, and environmental exposures. Occasionally, rashes may be idiopathic. The table below lists common newborn rashes by age and their etiologies.



Option Analysis

✅ Androgenic stimulation of sebaceous glands:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Exposure to warm environment:
Incorrect: Patients with miliaria have a widespread, vesicular, erythematous rash following exposure to warm environments. The lesions seen in this newborn are papular and not vesicular (fluid filled) and are localized to the nose and cheeks, which is more consistent with sebaceous hyperplasia. 
❌ Exposure to cold environment:
Incorrect: Patients with cutis marmorata present with symmetric mottling of the skin, typically after cold exposure and have a lacy, reticulated purple or pink colored rash over the trunk, arms, and legs. This newborn’s rash appears as a whitish-yellow papular rash localized to the nose and cheeks that is more consistent with sebaceous gland hyperplasia. 
❌ Sebum overproduction:
Incorrect: Sebum overproduction can result in seborrheic dermatitis, or “cradle cap.” Patients with seborrheic dermatitis can present with a greasy, flaky rash involving the scalp, face, ears, or neck. This newborn’s rash appears as a whitish-yellow papular rash localized to the nose and cheeks that is more consistent with sebaceous gland hyperplasia. 
❌ Vasomotor immaturity:
Incorrect: Acrocyanosis may be seen in newborns due to vasomotor immaturity. Patients with acrocyanosis present with bluish discoloration in the hands and feet when exposed to the cold. This newborn’s rash appears as a whitish-yellow papular rash localized to the face, nose, and cheeks that is more consistent with sebaceous gland hyperplasia.

questions.text:
A three-day-old newborn girl is being evaluated for a rash. She was born at 40-weeks of gestation via uncomplicated vaginal delivery. Her mother says the rash first began two days after birth as multiple small red flat and raised lesions on the trunk. The rash appeared spontaneously and was not associated with exposure to temperature changes. Weight is in the 85th percentile, length is in the 85th percentile, and head circumference is in the 90th percentile. The patient is sleeping but is arousable and moves all four extremities equally. Rectal temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), heart rate is 183/min, and blood pressure is 73/50 mmHg. Physical examination shows numerous macules on erythematous bases with central pustules on the trunk as seen in the image below. No rash is seen over mucosal, palmar, or plantar surfaces. Cytologic examination of pustular fluid from one of the lesions reveals a predominance of eosinophils. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?


[URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4372928/. Image taken from script]
questions.solution:
This three-day old newborn presents with a rash made up of macules on erythematous bases with central pustules that is located on the trunk. Cytology shows a predominance of eosinophils. These findings are consistent with erythema toxicum neonatorum (ETN).    

ETN usually begins 2-3 days after birth as a rash made up of multiple erythematous macules and papules (1 to 3 mm in size) that quickly develop central pustules on an erythematous base. The lesions typically are distributed over the trunk and proximal extremities and spare the palms and soles. Lesions can mimic the appearance of flea bites.    

Cytologic examination of fluid from the pustules can help make the diagnosis and differentiate it from transient neonatal pustular melanosis (TNPM), which is a widespread pustular rash seen in the newborn period. In the case of ETN, cytology will show a predominance of eosinophils. Conversely, a predominance of neutrophils with occasional eosinophils will be seen on cytology with transient neonatal pustular melanosis (TNPM).    

Risk factors for ETN include higher birth weight, greater gestational age, and vaginal delivery. A correlation has been found between the length of labor and the incidence and duration of ETN. ENT is a benign condition that typically resolves spontaneously within 10 days.  

Option Analysis

✅ Erythema toxicum neonatorum (ETN) :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Transient neonatal pustular melanosis (TNPM):
Incorrect: Patients with transient neonatal pustular melanosis (TNPM) typically present at the time of birth with widespread vesiculopustular lesions on a non-erythematous base that may occur over the palms and soles. This newborn has a rash that consists of macules and pustules on erythematous bases on the trunk sparing the palms and soles that began two days after birth, which is more consistent with erythema toxicum neonatorum (ETN). 
❌  Miliaria :
Incorrect: Patients with miliaria present with a widespread rash made up of tiny scattered vesicles that may appear erythematous. The rash can appear after exposure to a warm environment. This patient’s rash appeared spontaneously and consists of macules and pustules on erythematous bases on the trunk sparing the palms and soles, which is more consistent with erythema toxicum neonatorum (ETN). 
❌ Milia:
Incorrect: Patients with milia typically present with firm, pearly yellow papules that are 1-3 mm in size on the face, nose, chin, or forehead made up of benign Keratin-containing cysts. This patient’s rash consists of macules and pustules on erythematous bases on the trunk sparing the palms and soles, which is more consistent with erythema toxicum neonatorum (ETN). 
❌ Seborrheic dermatitis :
Incorrect: Patients with seborrheic dermatitis, or “cradle cap,” present with a greasy, flaky rash involving the scalp, face, ears, or neck. Lesions appear as yellow, scaly patches on an erythematous base. This patient has a rash made up of macules and pustules on erythematous bases on the trunk sparing the palms and soles, which is more consistent with erythema toxicum neonatorum (ETN).

questions.text:
A newborn boy is delivered via vaginal delivery at 28 weeks gestation because of preterm labor. There is no maternal fever and GBS is negative. The newborn weighs 1500-g (3.3 lbs). Apgar scores are 2 and 6 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. He requires continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) immediately after delivery for respiratory distress. In the NICU, temperature is 36.8°C ( 98.2°F), pulse is 175 beats/min, and respiratory rate is 78/min with SpO2 70% on supplemental oxygen at FiO2 100%. On physical examination, the patient has subcostal retractions, grunting, and nasal flaring. Auscultation reveals decreased air entry in the bilateral lung fields throughout. Chest x-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
 
Reproduced from: Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This preterm infant presents shortly after birth with tachypnea, increased work of breathing, hypoxia, and a chest x-ray showing ground glass appearance of the lung fields, which is consistent with respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). This patient has failed a trial of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and has hypoxia at oxygen supplementation of FiO2 100%, therefore he should be intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation.

RDS is the most common cause of respiratory distress in the preterm newborn and incidence peaks at 72-96 hours after birth. Preterm infants are at risk for RDS due to underdeveloped lungs and surfactant deficiency. Term infants born to diabetic mothers are also at risk of RDS due to fetal hyperglycemia and hyperinsulinemia disrupting surfactant synthesis. Surfactant deficiency leads to alveolar collapse and atelectasis which results in impaired ventilation and gas exchange.

Physical exam of a newborn with RDS can reveal decreased air entry in the lungs, tachypnea (respiratory rate > 60/min), grunting, nasal flaring, subcostal or intercostal retractions, and crackles might be heard upon auscultation. Chest x-ray can show bilateral ground glass appearance with air bronchograms and hypoexpansion. A chest ultrasound will show compact B lines with an echographic white lung appearance.

The first step in the management of a newborn with respiratory distress is to perform an ABCDE assessment to determine if they are stable or unstable. In this unstable preterm infant in respiratory distress with hypoxia not responding to supplemental oxygen, the best next step is to ensure adequate breathing and oxygenation by intubation and starting mechanical ventilation. Surfactants should also be given in severe cases of respiratory distress syndrome to decrease the risk of pneumothorax and bronchopulmonary dysplasia.  

Option Analysis

❌ Blood cultures:
Incorrect: Blood cultures should be obtained if neonatal sepsis is suspected. Sepsis is typically associated with maternal fever and chorioamnionitis. This patient has signs of respiratory distress and needs to be stabilized before laboratory testing is obtained.  
❌ Echocardiogram:
Incorrect: Congenital heart defects or patent ductus arteriosus can lead to respiratory distress in the newborn. After stabilizing this patient in respiratory distress and impending respiratory failure, an echocardiogram can be obtained.  
✅ Intubation and mechanical ventilation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intravenous antibiotics:
Incorrect: Intravenous (IV) antibiotics should be started if the etiology suspected is infectious such as pneumonia or neonatal sepsis. For this unstable patient in respiratory distress, intubation with mechanical ventilation is the priority.  
❌ Observe and recheck in 1 hour:
Incorrect: This preterm newborn presents with tachypnea, increased work of breathing, and is not responding to supplemental oxygen and has a chest x-ray consistent with respiratory distress syndrome. Delayed intubation and mechanical ventilation will lead to respiratory failure.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parent for a cough that has been present for one day and increased work of breathing that has developed over the past few hours. He does not have any significant past medical history and vaccines are up-to-date. He is currently enrolled in daycare and recently developed rhinorrhea. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 107/min, blood pressure is 107/60 mmHg, respiratory rate is 32/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. The patient is awake and alert and is not complaining of pain. A barking cough is heard. He has stridor at rest with moderate subcostal retractions. There is no neck swelling. Oral examination reveals erythematous changes to the posterior pharynx and moist mucous membranes. Which of the following findings would most likely be seen on neck radiographs?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with several characteristic features of croup including a “seal-like” barking cough, stridor at rest, and subcostal retractions with a history (daycare) and symptoms (rhinorrhea and cough) of a viral upper respiratory infection. Croup can typically be diagnosed clinically, but x-rays may be performed to rule out other causes. The characteristic sign of croup on neck radiographs is the “steeple sign”, which indicates subglottic narrowing.

Both croup and epiglottitis can cause acute upper airway obstruction in children. Neck X-rays demonstrating the classic “thumb” sign, (reflective of the swollen epiglottis and surrounding structures) indicate epiglottitis. In cases of suspected epiglottitis, the diagnosis can be confirmed with direct visualization of a swollen epiglottis via laryngoscopy, but radiographs may be performed to rule out other conditions.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Subglottic narrowing:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Enlarged epiglottis:
Incorrect: On soft tissue lateral x-rays of the neck in patients with epiglottitis, an enlarged epiglottis protruding from the anterior wall of the hypopharynx (the "thumb sign") can be seen. Patients with airway obstruction from epiglottitis are usually ill-appearing with stridor, high fever, and tripod positioning. This patient has features that are more characteristic of croup.
❌ Increased prevertebral depth:
Incorrect: On lateral neck x-rays in patients with retropharyngeal abscesses, increased prevertebral depth can be seen. These patients typically are ill-appearing and present with a “hot potato voice,” trismus (lockjaw), neck swelling, drooling, and cervical lymphadenopathy. This patient has features that are more characteristic of croup.
❌ Foreign body:
Incorrect: A foreign body may be seen on x-ray in patients with airway obstruction from ingestion of a foreign body. Patients can present with stridor that may mimic croup. However, symptoms are typically acute onset (cough and choking) and the incident may be witnessed. Associated signs and symptoms of infection as seen in this (e.g. low-grade temperature nasal congestion) will be absent.
❌ Subcutaneous emphysema:
Incorrect: Subcutaneous emphysema may be seen on x-rays in patients with esophageal perforation or mediastinitis. Patients with esophageal perforation typically have acute neck or chest pain and patients with mediastinitis typically have neck pain and fever. This patient has features that are more characteristic of croup.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parent for evaluation of right eye pain and swelling for one week. The parent reports the patient has been vigorously rubbing his eye stating, “It hurts.” The week before he had nasal congestion and rhinorrhea. The patient has no significant medical history. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 106/62 mmHg, pulse is 102/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the pupils are equal and reactive bilaterally. There is soft tissue swelling, erythema, and tenderness about the right orbit. The patient has difficulty opening the eye. The left eye is within normal limits. There is nasal congestion. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. Which of the following would indicate this patient should be treated as an inpatient with intravenous antibiotics?

choices.text: Absence of pain with extraocular eye movements
Decreased activity level of the child

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs, symptoms, and findings, consistent with either preseptal periorbital cellulitis or orbital cellulitis. This patient should have had visual acuity testing during the physical examination. Patients with periorbital cellulitis often have normal visual acuity, while patients with orbital cellulitis have blurred vision or reduced visual acuity. Altered visual acuity indicates that the patient should be treated with intravenous antibiotics and urgent ophthalmology consultation.

Periorbital cellulitis is caused by bacterial infection around the orbit. Orbital cellulitis is caused by an infection within the orbit. The relation of the infection to the orbital septum and the presence or absence of increased intraorbital pressure can differentiate orbital from periorbital cellulitis. Orbital cellulitis occurs posterior to the orbital septum and is associated with increased intraorbital pressure, while periorbital cellulitis occurs in the soft tissues anterior to the orbital septum and is not associated with increased intraorbital pressure.

Signs of increased intraorbital pressure that can be seen with orbital cellulitis include blurred vision, decreased visual acuity testing, chemosis, proptosis, ophthalmoplegia, and abnormal corneal light reflex. Additionally, patients with orbital cellulitis can have systemic signs of infection like fever and leukocytosis while patients with periorbital cellulitis rarely have these signs. Patients with orbital cellulitis require inpatient IV antibiotics to prevent complications that could lead to permanent vision loss

Option Analysis

✅ Decreased visual acuity testing:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Absence of pain with extraocular eye movements:
Incorrect: Pain with extraocular movements is a sign of orbital cellulitis for which patients should be hospitalized; however, if there is no pain, then periorbital cellulitis is more likely, which can be treated with outpatient antibiotics.
❌ Sinus tenderness:
Incorrect: Both periorbital and orbital cellulitis can result from extension from infection of the sinuses. Therefore, the presence of sinus tenderness would not help determine the diagnosis and need for intravenous antibiotics.
❌ Significant swelling of the eyelids:
Incorrect: Both periorbital and orbital cellulitis can result in significant swelling of the eyelids. Therefore, this would not help determine the diagnosis and the need for intravenous antibiotics.
❌ Decreased activity level of the child:
Incorrect: Both conditions can lead to decreased activity levels in children, this would not help distinguish between the two. However, if there is significant lethargy with signs of systemic infection this would be more consistent with orbital cellulitis with or without sepsis.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl presents to the primary care office with three days of dysuria. Her parents report that she has been urinating more frequently and had one episode of incontinence. Her urine has a foul odor. Parents have been working on potty training, and the child has held urine for extended periods of time. She attends preschool three days per week and plays outside most evenings. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respiratory rate is 22/min and blood pressure is 90/50 mmHg. Cardiovascular and pulmonary examinations are within normal limits. Abdominal exams reveal mild discomfort in the suprapubic region. There is no costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis (UA) is positive for leukocyte esterase with 10 red blood cells per high power field. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Antibiotics and repeat urinalysis in two weeks
Exercise avoidance and repeat urinalysis in three months
Laboratory evaluation including c-ANCA and p-ANCA
Computed tomography scan of the abdomen

questions.solution:
This child presents with urinary frequency, urgency, dysuria, and foul urine odor, with urinalysis showing leukocyte esterase and hematuria. She likely has a urinary tract infection. Urinary tract infections are a common, transient cause of hematuria in children. The infection should be treated with antibiotics and the UA should be repeated twice (at least one week apart), to ensure that the hematuria is transient.

Common causes of transient hematuria in pediatric patients include urinary tract infections, exercise, and trauma (e.g., external source or iatrogenic cause such as cystoscopy or catheter placement). Also, menses can be mistaken for hematuria. When a patient presents with hematuria and one of these factors is present, the urinalysis should be repeated twice, at least one week apart, to ensure resolution of the presumptive cause. If the hematuria resolves, no further workup is needed. If the repeat urinalysis continues to be positive with over five red blood cells per high power field (RBC/HPF), the patient is considered to have persistent hematuria, requiring further workup. The morphology of the red blood cells can differentiate whether the process is glomerular, (dysmorphic red blood cells) or non-glomerular, (eumorphic red blood cells).

Option Analysis

✅ Antibiotics and repeat urinalysis in two weeks:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Exercise avoidance and repeat urinalysis in three months:
Incorrect: Transient hematuria may be seen with heavy exercise or trauma; however, the normal play of a 3-year-old is not likely to cause hematuria. Furthermore, this child likely has a urinary tract infection, and the UA should be repeated in one to two weeks following treatment.
❌ Antibiotics and renal ultrasound:
Incorrect: A renal ultrasound may be indicated if two repeat urinalyses remain positive for eumorphic red blood cells. However, given that the cause of hematuria in this child is likely infectious, and there are no signs suggestive of renal pathology, the UA should be repeated twice before pursuing additional imaging.
❌ Laboratory evaluation including c-ANCA and p-ANCA:
Incorrect: Laboratory evaluation with c-ANCA and p-ANCA is useful for evaluating patients with persistent hematuria with dysmorphic red blood cells when the clinical setting is concerning for vasculitis. This child likely has transient hematuria caused by a urinary tract infection; therefore, she should be treated empirically for infection and have a repeat UA performed.
❌ Computed tomography scan of the abdomen:
Incorrect: A computed tomography scan of the abdomen can be used to evaluate for nephrolithiasis or abdominal masses. However, renal ultrasonography would be the first step in abdominal imaging for most conditions associated with hematuria, especially in a child where radiation exposure should be limited. However, for this child, no imaging is indicated.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy with a past medical history of primary ciliary dyskinesia presents to the emergency department with a fever and cough for one day. This morning his parent noticed that he was working hard to breathe and brought him in for further evaluation. His parents state that he has been doing well and has had no significant infections or hospitalizations in the past year. He receives chest physiotherapy daily and is up to date on immunizations. He is at the 24<sup>th</sup> percentile for height and the 16<sup>th</sup> percentile for weight. Temperature is 38.7°C (101.7F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 28/min, blood pressure is 115/76 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. On examination, he is in mild respiratory distress with tachypnea, belly breathing, and intercostal retractions. Bilateral inner ear effusions are present as are nasal congestion and polyps. No murmur is appreciated on cardiopulmonary exam. Rales are heard over the right lower lobe. The patient is started on 2L/min oxygen, IV access is achieved, and he is placed on cardiac monitoring. Chest x-ray confirms right lower lobe pneumonia. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient has a history of primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) and presents with fever, cough, and increased work of breathing. Rales raise suspicion for pneumonia which is confirmed with chest x-ray. This patient is initially stabilized and placed on supplemental oxygen. Sputum culture should be sent before the initiation of empiric antibiotics to help guide antibiotic selection.

The first step in managing a patient with PCD is to perform an Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure (ABCDE) assessment and determine if the patient is stable or unstable. If the patient is unstable, necessary interventions such as obtaining IV access, placing the patient on continuous monitoring, and administering supplemental oxygen should be pursued.

Patients with PCD are at risk for bronchiectasis and recurrent respiratory tract infections, as well as sinusitis and otitis media. Common pathogens implicated in respiratory infections in patients with PCD include Haemophilus influenzae, Staphylococcus aureus, and Streptococcus pneumoniae. If the patient with a respiratory infection is stable, a sputum culture should be obtained before starting empiric antibiotics. Prior sputum cultures and sensitivities should also be reviewed to help guide the choice of antibiotic therapy.

Chest physiotherapy, hypertonic saline nebulizers, and rhDNAse can be started in the hospital to assist with airway clearance. They should be started after the patient is stabilized and treatment of underlying infection with antibiotics is started. They are routinely prescribed for patients with PCD to help prevent recurrent infections.

Option Analysis

✅ Obtain sputum culture:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Administer ceftriaxone:
Incorrect: Although antibiotics for pneumonia should be started as soon as possible, a sputum culture should be obtained first to help tailor antibiotic therapy in this patient. It is also recommended to review prior sputum cultures to guide the selection of antibiotics in patients with PCD.
❌ Start chest physiotherapy:
Incorrect: Chest physiotherapy is recommended for patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia; however, it should be initiated once the patient is stabilized and treatment is initiated for the underlying infection.
❌ Administer hypertonic saline nebulizer:
Incorrect: Hypertonic saline nebulizers are recommended for patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia who have recurrent respiratory infections or ongoing moderate-severe respiratory symptoms, however, nebulizers should be started after the patient is stabilized, sputum cultures are obtained, and antibiotics are started.
❌ Consult pulmonology:
Incorrect: Pulmonology should be consulted for a patient with primary ciliary dyskinesia, but not before the patient is stabilized, sputum cultures are collected, and empiric antibiotics are initiated for the underlying infection.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents to a pulmonologist for evaluation of a chronic productive cough, congestion, recurrent respiratory infections, and recurrent otitis media. Parents report the patient has been sick much more often than his peers. He was born full-term but did spend time in the NICU for respiratory distress. He is up to date on all vaccinations including influenza, COVID-19, and pneumococcal 13-valent conjugate vaccine (PCV13). He is at the 23<sup>rd</sup> percentile for height and the 12<sup>th</sup> percentile for weight. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1 F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 106/68 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98%. Head and neck examination shows bilateral middle ear effusions, nasal congestion, and polyps. Heart rate is regular, and no murmur is appreciated. Diffuse rhonchi are heard without increased work of breathing. The patient undergoes a full work-up. Nitrous oxide is found to be very low, and a genetic pulmonary disease is confirmed. Which of the following interventions is recommended?

choices.text: Vitamin A, D, E, K supplementation
Yearly surveillance of liver function tests (LFTs)

questions.solution:
Primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) is the most likely diagnosis in this patient with a history of neonatal respiratory distress, chronic cough, recurrent respiratory infections, and recurrent otitis media who is found to have low NO levels and a genetic pulmonary disease. Patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia should be up to date on immunizations for influenza, COVID-19, and pneumococcus. If a patient has only received PCV13, they need to receive a dose of pneumococcal 20-valent conjugate vaccine (PCV20) or pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23).

Similar management strategies are used for patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia and cystic fibrosis (CF). Maintaining airway clearance and preventing respiratory infections with chest physiotherapy and regular exercise for both diseases is important. Nebulized hypertonic saline and recombinant human deoxyribonuclease (rhDNase) are used in both diseases, but more often in patients with cystic fibrosis. Both types of patients should receive immunizations including PCV20 or PPSV23, influenza, and COVID-19. Respiratory infections should be treated promptly. Occasionally prophylactic Azithromycin is used in patients with recurrent bronchiectasis. If a patient is prone to Pseudomonas, nebulized tobramycin is often used.

Patients with cystic fibrosis often develop gastrointestinal symptoms and require additional nutritional and pancreatic support. This includes close monitoring of growth, pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy, supplementation with fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K), and oral salts. Some patients require insulin or ursodiol.

Surveillance includes chest computed tomography and routine sputum cultures in patients with PCD, chest x-rays, and regular oropharyngeal cultures in patients with CF. Due to the gastrointestinal complications seen in patients with CF, they should undergo routine screening with liver function tests and oral glucose tolerance testing.

For patients with CF and PCD, Ear, Nose, and Throat physicians (ENTs) are often consulted regarding possible tympanostomy with tube placement and nasal polypectomy. As with any genetic condition, genetic counseling should be performed.

Option Analysis

✅ Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Prophylactic Amoxicillin:
Incorrect: Antibiotics treat recurrent bacterial infections that often occur in patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia; however Prophylactic antibiotics are not typically prescribed.
❌ Vitamin A, D, E, K supplementation:
Incorrect: Patients with cystic fibrosis require supplements with fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K). This is not necessary for this patient who likely has primary ciliary dyskinesia.
❌ Yearly surveillance of liver function tests (LFTs):
Incorrect: Surveillance of LFTs is recommended for patients with cystic fibrosis. Mucous can block bile ducts preventing adequate excretion resulting in chronic inflammation and liver fibrosis. It is not typically necessary in patients with PCD.
❌ Biannual chest computed tomography (CT):
Incorrect: Some providers obtain yearly chest CTs on patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia to detect early airway and structural lung changes, although there isn’t consensus on frequency. Biannual chest CTs are not routinely recommended.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents for evaluation of a rash that developed over both legs 3 days ago. The patient has also been experiencing intermittent moderate abdominal pain that comes and goes and joint pain that comes and goes and migrates from one joint to another. He has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), blood pressure is 110/62 mmHg, pulse is 101/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Palpable reddish-purple lesions approximately 5mm in diameter and appearing in clusters are seen over the legs bilaterally (as shown in the image below). There is swelling, tenderness to palpation and pain with range of motion of the of the right knee. Cardiopulmonary exam is within normal limits. The abdomen is soft, nontender and without masses. CBC and coagulation studies are within normal limits. Which of the following additional findings is most likely, given the likely underlying condition?
 

Reproduced from wikipedia

choices.text: History of lupus erythematous in a first degree relative

questions.solution:
This 8-year-old boy presents with a palpable reddish-purple rash on the legs, abdominal pain and migratory joint pain and swelling. The most likely diagnosis is IgA vasculitis (Henoch-Schönlein purpura, or HSP). Approximately one half of cases of HSP occur in children who have recently experienced an upper respiratory infection, especially a streptococcal infection.

IgA vasculitis (Henoch-Schönlein purpura) is the most common systemic vasculitis of childhood and typically affects the skin, joints, intestines, and kidneys. It is a vasculitis of the small blood vessels due to deposition of immunoglobulin A. IgA vasculitis is typically a self-limited condition that improves after a few weeks of supportive care in the outpatient setting. However, some children may develop nephritis, which can result in kidney injury and, in rare cases, kidney failure.

Patients who develop HSP are typically between 3-15 years old with a mean age of onset of 6-7 years old. The classic finding is a palpable reddish-purple rash that typically appears over the legs and buttocks. Patients often have migratory joint pain, colicky abdominal pain, and a history of a recent upper respiratory tract infection. The signs and symptoms typically develop over days to weeks but may vary in the order of clinical presentation. Patients may also have nausea, vomiting, and gastrointestinal bleeding. Kidney disease is more prevalent in older children, with the most common findings being hematuria with or without red blood cell casts, and mild or no proteinuria.

Option Analysis

✅ Recent upper respiratory tract infection:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ History of lupus erythematous in a first degree relative:
Incorrect: A family history of autoimmune disease has not been shown to be associated with Ig A vasculitis (Henoch-Schönlein purpura), which is the most likely diagnosis in this child.
❌ Bilateral Conjunctivitis:
Incorrect: Bilateral Conjunctivitis can be seen with Kawasaki disease. Keratitis and uveitis are rarely seen with IgA vasculitis (Henoch-Schönlein purpura), which is the most likely diagnosis in this child. When these are present, other autoimmune diseases should be ruled out.
❌ Swollen, erythematous, smooth tongue:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with “strawberry tongue,” which can be seen with Kawasaki disease, which is not associated with IgA vasculitis, which is the most likely diagnosis in this child.
❌ Summertime illness:
Incorrect: Most cases of IgA vasculitis occur in the fall, winter, and spring months due to the association with upper respiratory illnesses.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old girl is referred to the emergency department by the pediatrician for a 10-day history of low-grade fevers. Parents report her only significant past medical history is intermittent asthma well controlled with as-needed albuterol. For the past month, parents have noticed a dry cough unresponsive to albuterol. She has been more fatigued lately and has lost 8 lbs. She is at the 54th percentile for height and 30th percentile for weight. They have had no recent travel. Immunizations are up to date. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 110/78 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears pale but is alert and lying quietly in the hospital bed. There is a 2/6 systolic murmur heard best at the left sternal border. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally and there is no increased work of breathing. Abdomen is soft, non-tender, with normoactive bowel sounds. Mild hepatosplenomegaly is appreciated. There is cervical, axillary, and inguinal lymphadenopathy. Blood work is obtained and shown below. Which of the following tests should be ordered next?

Laboratory value
Result
Leukocyte count
24.6/mm3
Hemoglobin
10.5 g/dL
Hematocrit
30.9%
Platelet count
122/mm3
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)
38 mm/hr
Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)
345  U/L
questions.solution:
This patient presents with prolonged low-grade fever, worsening dry cough, fatigue, weight loss, and findings of pallor, hepatosplenomegaly, and diffuse lymphadenopathy. Leukocytosis, anemia, and thrombocytopenia are seen on bloodwork. Together, these findings are concerning for lymphoma. A chest x-ray should be obtained next to gather immediate information about the extent of mediastinal involvement as well as the impact on the airway.
 

Image 1. Frontal chest radiograph in a 14-year-old boy with Hodgkin lymphoma shows a widened mediastinum (white solid arrow) due to a mediastinal mass with tracheal narrowing & deviation (blue open arrow).

In children >2 months of age who have a fever, it is important to first assess if there are signs and symptoms of localized infection or systemic infection.

If there is concern for localized infection, confirmatory testing such as chest x-ray, urinalysis/urine culture, and a rapid strep/throat culture may be obtained. In the setting of systemic symptoms, confirmatory testing may include NAAT or serologies.

If there are no signs and symptoms of infection, work-up depends on the age of the patient and degree of fever. Patients between 2-36 months with a temperature ≥39 °C require a work-up for an occult bacterial infection. This includes blood work including blood culture, urinalysis and urine culture, and possible cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) studies including CSF culture.

In patients without findings consistent with infection who are > 36 months with any degree of fever or 2-36 months with fevers between 38-39 °C, evaluation for malignancy should be performed. Blood workup should include a complete blood count (CBC) with peripheral smear, comprehensive metabolic panel, and LDH. Imaging is often required as well as biopsy including lymph node biopsy when lymphoma is suspected, bone marrow biopsy if leukemia is suspected, and tissue biopsy if a mass is present.

If there is no concern for malignancy, inflammatory conditions such as Kawasaki, systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (sJIA), and systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), should be considered. Work-up should include a CBC, comprehensive metabolic panel, urinalysis, antinuclear antibodies (ANA), and other autoimmune screening labs like anti-ds DNA, anti-Smith antibodies, and rheumatoid factor. When Kawasaki disease is suspected, an echocardiogram should be obtained to assess for coronary aneurysms.

If there is no concern for inflammatory conditions, a medication-induced fever should be ruled out before diagnosing the patient with a fever of unknown origin (FUO) or fever without an identified source as these are diagnoses of exclusion.

Option Analysis

✅ Chest x-ray:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lymph node biopsy:
Incorrect: A lymph node biopsy should be obtained in the work-up for lymphoma, but not before a chest x-ray is obtained.
❌ Mantoux test (PPD):
Incorrect: A Mantoux test (PPD) is used to test for tuberculosis. Although this patient has several symptoms that could be caused by tuberculosis, she has no high-risk features for exposure and has symptoms, physical exam findings, and bloodwork consistent with lymphoma. Workup should begin with a chest x-ray.
❌ Echocardiogram:
Incorrect: This patient is not showing any signs or symptoms of cardiac dysfunction or Kawasaki disease, so an echocardiogram is not indicated at this time.
❌ Antinuclear antibodies (ANA):
Incorrect: ANA antibody testing is a nonspecific test for autoimmune diseases. This patient’s presentation is consistent with lymphoma, and malignancy should be evaluated for starting with chest x-ray.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parent for a well-child examination. The parent expresses concern for autism spectrum disorder (ASD) due to a nephew having recently been diagnosed with ASD and the patient having many similar behaviors to his cousin. The child was born at 34 weeks’ gestation and spent two weeks in the neonatal intensive care unit before discharging home. He has no chronic medical condition and does not take any medication. Vital signs are within normal limits. A comprehensive neurodevelopmental evaluation is arranged to further evaluate for ASD. Which of the following sets of features would be most consistent with this diagnosis?

choices.text: EcholaliaPoor eye contactIndifference to temperatureHypersensitivity to light
Hand flappingIndifference to changes in routineLimited eye contactVertical nystagmus
Casual interest in many subjectsHypersensitivity to textureBody rockingEmpathy for peers
Monotone voiceUse of pincer graspVertical nystagmusConductive hearing loss
Indifference to painFrequent eye contactEcholaliaChild checks in with caregivers often

questions.solution:
This child with a premature birth presents due to parental concern for autism spectrum disorder (ASD). This child may be diagnosed with ASD if he displays persistent deficits in social communication and interaction across multiple contexts, and restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior. Examples of features that would support this diagnosis include echolalia, poor eye contact, indifference to temperature, and hypersensitivity to light.

The first step in evaluating a child with suspected autism spectrum disorder is to arrange a comprehensive neurodevelopmental evaluation. This evaluation will determine whether the patient meets the diagnostic criteria for ASD and includes a developmental and behavioral history; direct observation of behavior; cognitive, language, and motor testing; and assessment of vision and hearing. A diagnosis of ASD is made if there are persistent deficits in social communication and interaction across multiple contexts, not accounted for by developmental delays, and restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities. Children with ASD may also present with deficits in cognitive, language, motor skills, and visual or hearing impairment.
   

Option Analysis

✅ EcholaliaPoor eye contactIndifference to temperatureHypersensitivity to light:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Hand flappingIndifference to changes in routineLimited eye contactVertical nystagmus:
Incorrect: While hand flapping and limited eye contact are consistent with a diagnosis of ASD, children with ASD typically display excessive resistance to change, with strict adherence to routines. Vertical nystagmus is concerning for a pathological brain process and is not typical of ASD. 
❌ Casual interest in many subjectsHypersensitivity to textureBody rockingEmpathy for peers:
Incorrect: Hypersensitivity to texture and body rocking are features of ASD. Children with ASD often have hyperfixation on one specific subject rather than casual interest in many subjects, and often display limited social-emotional reciprocity. 
❌ Monotone voiceUse of pincer graspVertical nystagmusConductive hearing loss:
Incorrect: Monotone voice and conductive hearing loss can be seen in patients with ASD; however, use of the pincer grasp is an expected developmental milestone for all toddlers. Vertical nystagmus is concerning for a pathological brain process and is not typical of ASD.  
❌ Indifference to painFrequent eye contactEcholaliaChild checks in with caregivers often:
Incorrect: Indifference to pain and echolalia are features of ASD. But children with ASD can display poor eye contact and limited social-emotional reciprocity.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl presents to the pediatric clinic with her parents who are concerned that she has been experiencing pain in the left knee and right ankle for the past two months. They note that she appears to have difficulty walking after waking up in the morning. The parents have also noticed a rash on her scalp. She has no significant past medical history, and her vaccinations are up-to-date. On physical examination, there is a well-demarcated, erythematous rash covered with silver scales on her scalp and behind both ears. There is swelling, warmth, and pain with range of motion in the left knee and right ankle and swelling and tenderness to palpation over the insertion site of the right Achilles tendon. Which of the following additional findings would be most consistent with this patient’s likely underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This child presents with signs and symptoms (e.g., a rash with silvery scale, arthritis, enthesitis) consistent with psoriatic juvenile idiopathic psoriasis (JIA). Nail findings, such as nail pitting and onycholysis (separation of the nail from the bed) are seen in more than half of cases.

JIA has multiple subtypes with variable clinical features. Psoriatic JIA is characterized by the presence of arthritis (e.g., joint pain, morning stiffness, reduced range of motion) along with skin features of psoriasis (erythematous plaques with a silvery scale). Frank skin psoriasis may not always be present in children, but they may have other distinctive signs of psoriatic JIA such as nail pitting, dactylitis, and/or enthesitis.

Other subtypes of JIA present other distinctive features and findings. Patients with systemic JIA typically present with fever, which is associated with an evanescent, migratory, salmon-pink-colored rash that disappears with the resolution of the fever. There are often other systemic features, such as lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and serositis. Patients with oligoarticular JIA present with joint pain and swelling affecting < 5 joints. They may have evidence of joint disuse such as muscle atrophy and contractures. Leg length discrepancies may also be seen. It is typically seen in children around 2–3 years of age. Patients with polyarticular JIA have similar signs and symptoms involving ≥ 5 joints. Patients with enthesitis-related JIA are often older and present with sacroiliitis and anterior uveitis.       

Option Analysis

✅ Nail pitting:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ High fever:
Incorrect: A high fever, often accompanied by a migratory salmon-pink rash, is indicative of systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA). The rash described for this patient is more consistent with that seen in psoriatic JIA. 
❌ Muscle atrophy:
Incorrect: Muscle atrophy can occur with chronic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), most often with subtypes that present in young children (e.g., oligoarticular JIA), and lead to disuse of the affected limb. This patient’s rash and other findings are more consistent with psoriatic JIA. 
❌ Eye redness associated with pain:
Incorrect: Chronic uveitis can occur with psoriatic juvenile idiopathic arthritis. However, it is typically painless. 
❌ Lymphadenopathy:
Incorrect: Lymphadenopathy is common with systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA). The rash and symptoms described in this patient’s vignette are more consistent with psoriatic JIA which is not associated with lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents to the pediatrician's office for evaluation of shortness of breath for the past month. The patient states that she recently started track and has been noticeably short of breath from exertion. She also notes mild lower extremity swelling. The patient has minimal symptoms at rest and has not had any associated wheezing. She is otherwise healthy and does not take any medication daily. She immigrated from Guatemala to the United States with her family three years ago. As a young child, she had multiple upper respiratory infections, including multiple episodes of sore throat. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 120/71mmHg, pulse is 112/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates a tall, thin adolescent in no acute distress. Cardiopulmonary examination demonstrates a 2/6 holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex. 1+ pitting edema is noted on the lower extremities bilaterally. Which of the following is the best next step for diagnosing the most likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has evidence of rheumatic heart disease causing findings consistent with mild congestive heart failure, including exertional dyspnea, a murmur suspicious of mitral regurgitation, and lower extremity edema. Moreover, this patient has a history of residing in a resource-limited country and having multiple episodes of pharyngitis. When rheumatic heart disease is suspected, a transthoracic echocardiogram should be performed to confirm the presence of valvular lesions and disease.        
Acute rheumatic fever is often a clinical diagnosis. If there is suspicion of recent Group A streptococcus (GAS) infection and acute rheumatic fever, initial work-up can include rapid strep antigen test/throat culture, AntistreptolysinO(ASO)/AntiDNAseBantibodies, inflammatory markers, electrocardiogram, chest radiograph, and echocardiogram. Positive streptococcal antibodies or throat culture/rapid strep help confirm a preceding strep illness, but this is not necessary to diagnose acute rheumatic fever. Formal diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever is based upon patient’s meeting the Jones criteria.        

In contrast, rheumatic heart disease presents later, as a sequelae of damage to cardiac valves during the initial insult of untreated acute rheumatic fever. This condition should be suspected in patients with cardiopulmonary symptoms such as fatigue, shortness of breath, or palpitations along with a history of untreated strep infection or new mitral valve murmur. If there is concern for rheumatic heart disease (without acute rheumatic fever), evaluation includes an electrocardiogram, chest radiograph, and echocardiogram. Certain echocardiogram findings, such as mitral regurgitation concomitantly with two morphologic mitral valve features, can be used to make the diagnosis of rhematic heart disease.   

Option Analysis

✅ Transthoracic echocardiogram:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Transesophageal echocardiogram:
Incorrect: Transesophageal echocardiogram is an invasive test most often performed to evaluate for the presence of vegetation in patients with suspected endocarditis. This patient has a murmur and a history consistent with rheumatic heart disease; therefore, transthoracic echocardiography is the best next step in diagnosis.  
❌ Throat culture:
Incorrect: A throat culture will diagnose strep pharyngitis. Untreated strep pharyngitis can lead to rheumatic heart disease; however, throat culture is usually negative by the time rheumatic heart disease presents. A transthoracic echocardiogram is the gold standard for diagnosing rheumatic heart disease. 
❌ Antistreptolysin O (ASO)/AntiDNAse B antibodies:
Incorrect: The presence of ASO/AntiDNAse B antibodies can suggest a recent streptococcus infection. Although ASO/AntiDNAase B antibodies may be positive when evaluating for rheumatic heart disease, it does not confirm that the heart disease is secondary to a recent strep infection. Specific findings on a transthoracic echocardiogram will confirm a diagnosis of rheumatic heart disease. 
❌ Cardiac biopsy:
Incorrect: Cardiac biopsy is an invasive procedure often used to diagnose myocarditis or invasive cardiac disease (e.g. sarcoidosis). This patient has a murmur and a history consistent with rheumatic heart disease; therefore, transthoracic echocardiography is the best next step in diagnosis.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of shortness of breath. He is accompanied by his parent, who states they were eating lunch when their son developed a scratchy sensation in his throat followed by hives and facial swelling. His medical history is notable for eczema and seasonal allergies. Temperature is 36 °C (98.6 °F), heart rate is 130 beats/minute, blood pressure is 80/40 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 28/min with SaO2 of 82% on room air. On exam, the patient is audibly wheezing, using accessory muscles of respiration. His speech is garbled, and he cannot speak in clear, full sentences. Oropharyngeal exam reveals swollen lips and tongue. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This child presents to the emergency department in respiratory distress secondary to anaphylaxis. He is hypotensive, tachycardic, hypoxic, and therefore, unstable due to shock. He likely has a significant amount of tongue and upper airway edema and can no longer protect his airway. Intubation and mechanical ventilation should be performed immediately. IM epinephrine should be given to treat the underlying anaphylactic shock. There are NO absolute contraindications to epinephrine in the setting of anaphylaxis.       

In an unstable patient with suspected airway obstruction from anaphylaxis, attention should be focused first on airway, breathing, circulation, and mentation. The lips, tongue, and oropharynx should be assessed for angioedema, and a mentating patient should be asked to speak their name to be evaluated for associated periglottic or glottic swelling. The skin should be examined for urticaria or angioedema, which if present would help confirm the diagnosis. If the upper airway does not appear edematous, the patient should be placed in the recumbent position, with the lower extremities elevated to maximize perfusion of vital organs.   

Option Analysis

❌ 1L normal saline bolus   :
Incorrect: Airway stabilization is the immediate priority for this patient who presents with anaphylactic shock. He should be intubated and given IM epinephrine. A rapid infusion of normal saline at 20 mL/kg can then be started.  
❌ Albuterol  :
Incorrect: Albuterol can be used to treat bronchospasm that is resistant to intramuscular epinephrine, but first, this patient's airway should be stabilized with intubation and mechanical ventilation. 
✅ Intubation and mechanical ventilation :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Methylprednisolone :
Incorrect: This patient with anaphylactic shock should be emergently stabilized with intubation and mechanical ventilation and IM epinephrine should be administered. Methylprednisolone can be used as an adjunct treatment to reduce inflammation. 
❌ Diphenhydramine :
Incorrect: Diphenhydramine can be utilized as the primary treatment for non-anaphylactic allergic reactions, only used as an adjunct in patients with anaphylactic shock, and it should be given only after the airway has been stabilized and IM epinephrine is given.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parent following a witnessed seizure at home. The boy had seizure-like activity of the right lower extremity that lasted for approximately 25 minutes. The patient subsequently developed another episode lasting a similar amount of time. The parent states the patient has been tugging at his left ear for the past 24 hours. The boy has no other significant past medical history and no allergies to medication. Vaccinations are up-to-date. Temperature is 39.4°C (102.9°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 103/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows a toddler who is tired but otherwise has a normal neurologic exam. The left tympanic membrane is bulging with opacification and erythema. The oropharynx is within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. Antipyretic therapy is provided for fever control. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Caregiver education without the need for further treatment
Computed tomography (CT) scan of the brain

questions.solution:
This 3-year-old boy presents with a history of a focal seizure (motor activity limited to one extremity) lasting more than 15 minutes in duration that recurred in 24 hours. Since this patient does not have findings suggestive of a central nervous system (CNS) infection (e.g. headache, neck stiffness) and likely has acute bacterial otitis media, the best next step in management is to treat the underlying condition with amoxicillin and pursue workup with an electroencephalogram (EEG) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain.

The diagnostic evaluation of febrile seizures depends on whether they are simple or complex, and with or without signs of CNS infection. Patients with simple febrile seizures do not require inpatient evaluation and should be provided with antipyretic therapy, caregiver education, and treatment of any underlying condition if applicable (e.g. antibiotics for acute bacterial otitis media). In contrast, patients with complex febrile seizures should undergo further evaluation with EEG or MRI of the brain to identify possible intracranial structural abnormalities, especially in those with focal neurological signs. If signs of CNS infection are present, patients should also have a lumbar puncture.   

Option Analysis

✅ Amoxicillin:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Caregiver education without the need for further treatment:
Incorrect: This patient has several concerning features for a complex febrile seizure and requires further workup with electroencephalogram (EEG) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain, along with antibiotics for likely bacterial otitis media.  
❌ Lumbar puncture:
Incorrect: Lumbar puncture should be considered in patients with signs and symptoms of central nervous system infection (e.g., bulging fontanelles and irritability in babies, headache, and neck stiffness in older children). This patient's presentation is consistent with a complex febrile seizure in the setting of acute otitis media. He should be treated with antibiotics and have an electroencephalogram (EEG) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain.  
❌ Azithromycin:
Incorrect: This patient's presentation is consistent with a complex febrile seizure in the setting of likely acute bacterial otitis media. Azithromycin would not be the preferred first-line treatment for acute bacterial otitis media in this patient.  
❌ Computed tomography (CT) scan of the brain:
Incorrect: Neuroimaging with magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is warranted for this patient given that he has had a complex febrile seizure; however, an MRI, and not a CT scan, is recommended. Also, the patient should be treated for the underlying condition of acute bacterial otitis media with an appropriate antibiotic.

questions.text: A 7-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department by his parents for trouble breathing. He had mild upper respiratory symptoms starting three days ago with rhinorrhea and cough but developed difficulty breathing around bedtime that evening. He had a temperature of 101.1°F earlier today. His three-year-old brother had a cold last week. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.3°F), pulse is 156/min, respiratory rate is 54/min, blood pressure is 86/42 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 91% on room air. Weight is in the 64<sup>th</sup> percentile, height is in the 70<sup>th</sup> percentile, and head circumference is in the 66<sup>th</sup> percentile. On physical examination, the infant is calm and alert in his parent’s lap. Increased work of breathing is present with moderate subcostal and suprasternal retractions. Diffuse bilateral expiratory wheezing is noted on lung exam. There is no stridor and no focal lung findings. Which of the following would indicate the need for hospitalization for treatment of the acute condition?
questions.solution:
This infant presents with classic features of bronchiolitis, a lung infection that can be caused by several different viruses. A history of muscular dystrophy would be a risk factor for severe disease and complications and would be an indication for hospitalization for monitoring and supportive care to treat bronchiolitis.

Bronchiolitis most commonly occurs in children under the age of 2 years, often with a seasonal distribution peaking in fall and winter. The history will often include exposure to an older sibling or family member who recently had a “cold.” Classic features of bronchiolitis include the initial onset of mild rhinorrhea, fever, and cough for the first two to three days, followed by signs of respiratory distress as the infection moves to the lower airway. Vital signs may show tachypnea, tachycardia, and hypoxia. Nasal flaring or grunting can occur in more severe cases of respiratory distress. Abdominal breathing or suprasternal, intercostal, and subcostal retractions can be seen on examination. Auscultatory findings may include wheezing, crackles, and a prolonged expiratory phase. The child will often experience poor feeding due to difficulty breathing, and it is important to assess hydration status using findings such as fontanelle fullness and skin turgor on examination.

While bronchiolitis is typically mild and self-limited, several risk factors increase the likelihood of a child developing severe disease or complications. When these conditions are present, the threshold for hospitalization should be much lower as the disease can progress quickly. Risk factors for severe disease include prematurity, chronic lung or heart disease, immunocompromised state, and neuromuscular disorders.    

Option Analysis

✅ History of muscular dystrophy:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Birth at 39 weeks gestation:
Incorrect: 39 weeks gestation is considered a term delivery and wouldn't be a risk factor for severe disease indicating the need for hospitalization.  
❌ Birth weight of 3,000 grams:
Incorrect: Low birth weight is a risk factor for severe bronchiolitis requiring hospitalization. Low birth weight is defined by the World Health Organization as weight at birth of < 2500 grams (5.5 pounds). 
❌ Presence of a Still murmur:
